description: Spiritual Film Night: 'Samsara', A screening and discussion of the acclaimed documentary 'Samsara'. This film explores spiritual and cultural traditions from around the world, taking viewers on a visually stunning journey through life, death, and reincarnation. Following the film, there will be an open discussion to share thoughts and reflections. Snacks and drinks will be provided.
label: Religion & Spirituality

description:
Public Meeting: Affordable Healthcare for All - Wellington, Luxon’s cuts are making our health system worse. His choices are why it’s getting harder and more expensive to see a doctor or nurse. Because of Luxon’s underfunding, GP fees are heading towards $100. National has found hundreds of millions for tobacco companies while hospitals go understaffed and graduate nurses are left without jobs.
Labour will make it cheaper and easier to get care close to home, and make sure hospitals are there when you need them.
Join Labour Leader Chris Hipkins and spokesperson for health Dr Ayesha Verrall for a public meeting on getting the healthcare you deserve.
Public Meeting: Affordable Healthcare for All
Thursday 28 August, 6:00pm–7:30pm
St Peter’s Church on Willis Street
label: Government & Politics

description:
"SECRET" Comedy Warmup!, Every year, comedians from across the motu throw their hats in the ring for the Billy T Showcase, hoping to secure a coveted nomination.
Wellington has some fantastic acts in the mix this year and before they hit the big stage, they need a proper warm-up!
This comedy workshop gives the performers a chance to road-test their sharpest material, while the audience gets a rare behind-the-scenes look at the process.
Each act will perform their showcase set, then might turn to the crowd for specific feedback—helping them fine-tune their jokes for the big night.
The evening will be held together by previous Billy T nominee Gabby Anderson, with a stellar lineup including:
Alayne Dick
Jak Darling & Booth the Clown
Kipling DC
Lily Catastrophe
Mike Fowler
Opeti Vaka
Orin Ruaine-Prattley
& Samantha Hannah
Lineup is subject to change.
This is a FREE gig but please book a general admission ticket through this event listing to save your seat!
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
'TONES OF SILENCE' - FUTUNA CHAPEL IN B&W - PUBLIC TALKS, ‘TONES of SILENCE’ – FUTUNA CHAPEL in BLACK and WHITE
PUBLIC TALKS START AT 2:00PM
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work
Sunday 19th October.  Talks by Catherine Hammond and John Walsh
Sunday 2nd November. Talks by Malcolm Doidge and John Grace
BOOKINGS ARE PREFERRED TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
PRESENTERS
Catherine Hammond - Director Collections and Research, Auckland Museum
John Walsh – Writer – Walking Guides (Christchurch, Auckland, Wellington) 
John Grace – commercial lawyer and amateur B&W photographer
Dr. Malcolm Doidge - sculptor, video artist, photographer
CATHERINE HAMMOND - SUNDAY 18TH OCTOBER
Catherine Hammond is Director of Collections and Research at Auckland War Memorial Museum Tāmaki Paenga Hira, has worked in leadership roles in the arts and cultural sector in Aotearoa New Zealand for over two decades including Hocken Librarian at the University of Otago, and Research Library Manager at Auckland Art Gallery Toi o Tāmaki. Catherine is a trained librarian and published writer, editor, and curator, and has led the development of award-winning cultural heritage websites. Her research interests centre around the intersection of archives and Aotearoa art histories. She is Chair of the Guardians Kaitiaki of Alexander Turnbull Library and a Trustee of UNESCO Memory of the World Aotearoa New Zealand.
 Title of Catherine's talk
A Thousand Words: Photographic Archives in Aotearoa
Catherine will discuss the recent book and touring exhibition, A Different Light: First Photographs of Aotearoa and the role and impact of photographic archives as sites of research.
JOHN WALSH - SUNDAY 18TH OCTOBER
John Walsh is a leading New Zealand architecture writer. He edited Architecture New Zealand magazine for a decade, and has written numerous books on New Zealand architecture, among them the newly revised Auckland Architecture: A Walking Guide, which features photographs by Patrick Reynolds. (taken from AUCKLAND WRITERS FESTIVAL website)
JOHN GRACE - SUNDAY 2ND NOVEMBER
A selection of John's photographs make up the exhibition and he will also present a public talk about the photos, the vintage camera and equipment he uses, the history of photography and cameras used.
"Experiencing the chapel means interacting with it. From a photographic point of view, that means interacting optically and chemically to turn a solid, three-dimensional art form into a two-dimensional interpretation made up of tones of black, white and grey." John Grace - email- 18/06/25
DR. MALCOLM DOIDGE - SUNDAY 2ND NOVEMBER
Dr. Malcolm Doidge undertook a 360 time-lapse photography in the Chapel interior during the equinoxes and solstices of 2023 - 2024.  He produced a 2 – 3minute video of the timelapse project and this will be screened in the Chapel as part of the exhibition.  Malcolm will also give a presentation of his work and explore the digital processes involved in its production. He is an interdisciplinary sculptor and spatial designer. He uses digital time lapse and photogrammetry images for film poetry.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all koha received from the exhibition events will go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust.
label: Arts & Theatre

description: Watercolor Painting Techniques: A Creative Course, A course on watercolor painting techniques. Learn how to mix colors, create atmospheric effects, and use different brushwork to create beautiful and expressive watercolor paintings. This class is for artists of all levels.
label: Classes & Workshops

description: Customer Service Excellence, A fantastic one-day course to get staff communicating professionally and confidently with customers. Keep your customers coming back by empowering staff with core communication and customer service skills along with a ‘can do attitude’. For the better part of every day, we are communicating to and with others. This workshop will equip participants with the skills and techniques required to transform how you manage relationships with customers, colleagues and stakeholders. Have you ever thought about how you come across to others and what it’s like to be on the receiving end of you? This workshop will help participants to understand the different methods of communication. Whether it’s the speech you deliver to your customers and work colleagues, the level of attention you give your spouse when they are talking to you, or the look that you give to the cat, it all means something! Each and every one of us serves customers, whether we realise it or not. Maybe you’re in a frontline position serving the people who buy your products. Perhaps you’re serving staff members in other departments within your organisation. Learn ways to communicate with customers in a professional and positive manner, build rapport authentically, provide a great customer experience each and every time, build loyalty and repeat business, handle conflict and much more. This course also covers telephone etiquette, email and face-to-face. To book: email - info@biztrainers.co.nz or call 04 974 8790.
label: Business & Networking

description:
7 Days — Live, Since 2009, Kiwi comics have been delivering weekly laughs to television audiences. 7 Days is a homegrown panel show where local comedians take an irreverent look at the past week in news. Now they’re leaving the television studio behind and heading out on the road. Wellington’s Michael Fowler Centre is in their sights. Watch host Jeremy Corbett lead a band of comedians in a live version of the show. Dai Henwood, Hayley Sproull, Paul Ego, Josh Thomson, Ben Hurley, and Justine Smith intend to break all the rules. With no cameras, censors, or TV lawyers on hand, the show is bound to be a riot. 
Award-winning panel series 7 Days has introduced a wide range of comedy talents to New Zealand audiences. They compete across a wide range of games, including ‘My kid could draw that’, ‘Caption That’ and ‘Guess Who’. Get ready for quick-thinking stand-up comedy.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
SONGWRITERS NIGHT - OPEN MIC @ UNDERWORLD, Songwriters! Musos! Join us at Underworld Tavern for another round of Open Hell, Underworld's own Open Mic.
Format is two songs each. It can get busy, so turn up on time to guarantee a slot.
Originals preferred, but covers welcome.
Sing, play, listen, get inspired.
Koha to play. Come and join the fun!
label: Hobbies & Interests

description: Jewish Spirituality: An Introduction to Kabbalah, An introductory talk on the mystical teachings of Kabbalah. Learn about the Tree of Life, the divine emanations, and the practice of meditation in Jewish mysticism. This session is designed for those curious about the esoteric dimension of Judaism and its rich spiritual tradition. All are welcome, no prior knowledge is needed.
label: Religion & Spirituality

description:
Artists for Nature: Imaginal Disc, Enter a portal to a realm where insects meet art. Here, each insect is cherished for their unique beauty, their importance to the ecosystem and their marvelous life processes.

Through their dazzling video artworks, local artist Em Flux shares their queer, autistic worldview of the invertebrate world. They will be sharing a number of invertebrate-based video artworks and discuss the queer ecologies of insects, posthumanism and how art can be a tool to celebrate biodiversity. In these artworks, even the least appreciated creatures get a chance to shine!

This event will be held in the Rātā Cafe Balcony on the second floor of the Visitor's Centre. Doors Open 5.15pm, overflow parking is available on Birdwood Street.
label: Arts & Theatre

description: Christian Social Mixer, Come and mingle with other Christian singles, couples, and friends in a relaxed, friendly setting. This social mixer is a great opportunity to expand your network, make new friends, and build community with like-minded people who share your values. Light snacks and refreshments will be provided.
label: Religion & Spirituality

description:
August's Nomadic Speaker: Rachel Young, Rachel Young is a freelance graphic designer, traveller, and occasional van-dweller who’s spent the last few years navigating the messy, beautiful reality of creative nomad life.
For Rachel, being a ‘nomad’ has never been just about travel, but a mindset. Since leaving her home in the UK in 2019, she’s moved across the world, worked remotely from a van, taught graphic design in China, and rebuilt her creative career more than once.
Today, she blends her love of design with a passion for helping other creatives navigate the highs, lows, and mindset shifts of freelance life, while inspiring those around her to pursue their own dreams.
In this Friday's talk, she shares the unfiltered truths of freelancing on the move - from creative burnout to financial uncertainty - along with the mindset tools that can make the journey not just survivable, but meaningful and joyful.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
DIY Sign Making to Keep Māori Wards, Join Tiriti Action Group for a whānau-friendly afternoon creating your own sign in support of Māori wards. We will have banner materials, recycled blank coreflute, stencils, and paint where you can paint your own sign in support of the campaign to keep Māori Wards to put up in your front yard or window.
Saturday 23 August 2pm-5pm
Venue: Vogelmorn Hall

Learn about the itinerary, historical sites, and spiritual significance of visiting Jerusalem. This is a chance to ask questions, meet fellow travelers, and prepare for a life-changing journey of faith and discovery.
label: Religion & Spirituality

label: Music & Concerts

Unions Manawatu October Hui, Unions Manawatu October Hui
Unions Manawatu is the Local Affiliates Council (LAC) of the NZCTU.

these meetings run monthly (2nd Friday of the month) and they are open to all union officials, delegates and members.

If you are free and interested in what's going on locally for your unions then please come along.

Bi-monthly these meetings run until 12pm with the option to stay and have a shared Kai

description:
B.M.I : Bad Mōmona Individual (Playreading), Created by Īhaka Martyn. Play read by Kaisa Fa'atui

Tired of having no room for self love? Maybe burning 50kgs in 50 minutes will change that.

Join our inspiring fitness guru as he shows the audience how to shed your ego and excess fat. By utilising the power of manifestation, you too can change your pathetic little impulses. In fact, when was the last time you went to the gym? Maybe you should just skip this show and hit the treadmill instead, yeah?

Filled with self-helpless tips, banging tunes and kōrero hōhonu, this playreading will dissect the fraught relationships we have with our tinana, and where those nasty thoughts are really coming from.

Audience care: Contains body image themes and reference to “Fatphobia.”
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Book Launch - South by South by Charles Ferrall, Join us to celebrate the publication of Charles Ferrall's South by South: New Zealand and the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration. The book will be launched by Harry Ricketts.

- Thursday 18 September, 6pm
- Unity Books Wellington
- Free event – all welcome!

Joseph Kinsey is not a name many of us know – or not as well as we know the name Robert Falcon Scott. But from his base in Christchurch, Kinsey – book and art collector, philanthropist, science enthusiast, businessman – forged deep connections with the Antarctic expeditions and the explorers themselves through his tireless work as the agent for various expeditions. Two other New Zealanders also formed close friendships: Charles Bowen, a former politician, and Wellington lawyer Leonard Tripp, to whom Shackleton declared: ‘I love you as David and Jonathan loved.’

South by South tells the story of New Zealand’s role in ‘the Heroic Age’, that wave of exploration beginning at the end of the nineteenth century in which men set out to traverse the continent of Antarctica and, if they survived, to bring home their findings. The members of this New Zealander triumvirate were all believers in the British Empire, but the southern voyages were to an uninhabited land.

South by South brings to light many letters, newspaper articles, and pieces of official correspondence, much of which has not been published before, during the five expeditions of 1901–1916: the Discovery, Nimrod, Terra Nova, Aurora, and Endurance. In particular, Scott’s letters to Kinsey and Shackleton’s to Tripp tell of their hope, despair, exhaustion, and deep gratitude for their friendship. What they and the explorers wrote was influenced by nineteenth-century adventure stories which conveyed the Imperialist ideals of the time. If the impending conflict of 1914–18 was a very ‘literary war’, this was a very literary exploration.

Charles Ferrall is an associate professor at Te Herenga Waka–Victoria University of Wellington. Among his books are Modernist Writing and Reactionary Politics (2001); The Trials of Eric Mareo (2002), co-written with Rebecca Ellis; East by South: China in the Australasian Imagination (2006), co-edited with Paul Millar and Keren Smith; Juvenile Literature and British Society 1850–1950 (2009), co-written with Anna Jackson; Henry Lawson in New Zealand (2012); How We Remember: New Zealanders and the First World War (2014), co-edited with Harry Ricketts; and Remembering Gallipoli: Interviews with New Zealand Gallipoli Veterans (2015), co-edited with Christopher Pugsley.

Cover photograph: The ship Discovery leaving Lyttelton Harbour, 1901. Alexander Turnbull Library, Wellington, New Zealand
Cover design: Spencer Levine
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Bonfire, Created and directed by Matías Avaca

Bonfire is an intimate storytelling ritual where performers gather around the fire to share tales shaped by culture, memory, and imagination. Rooted in ancestral echoes, each story is poetic, powerful, and fleeting; never to be told the same way twice.

Inspired by the workshop The Stories That Made Us, the show blends magical realism, oral tradition, and ensemble connection.

With previous presentations in Auckland and Brisbane (as part of the 2025 Brisbane Improv Festival), Bonfire now arrives at the New Zealand Improv Festival, inviting audiences into a space of warmth, wonder, and shared humanity.

This show may include content related to family, identity, cultural heritage, and emotional themes. While performers are encouraged to approach these with care and sensitivity, the improvised nature of the show means themes may vary each night. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Anti-Pageant 2025, Anti-Pageant: The Next Drag Monster 2025
Presented by Allikins Productions | Created by The Den of Thurst

It’s time to summon all ghouls, ghosts, goblins, zombaes — and of course, our beloved theys — for the return of the Anti-Pageant this Halloween.

Prepare for a night of twisted glamour and unholy talent as we crown Aotearoa’s next Drag Monster for 2025. This is drag at its filthiest, fiercest, and most fabulously freaky.

Featuring a lineup of handpicked, up-and-coming alternative drag artists from across the motu, expect haunting looks, high drama, and performances that will leave you screaming (in the best way). Come unleash your inner demon, revel in the weird, and celebrate the beauty of being unapologetically other. We invite you to bring your best Halloween costumes and creations to join in the celebration.

Join us in the eerie depths of Ivy Bar and Cabaret this Halloween and witness the ascension of our next Drag Monster. It’s a night you won’t forget — and one you may never recover from.

Show Details

Doors open at 7:30pm.
Show runs from 8:00 pm to 11:30pm, with three short intermissions between sets.

Ticketing

General Admission (Standing): Unallocated standing room.

Sold out - Seated Tickets: Limited availability. If you're attending with a group and want to sit together, contact us ahead of time. Otherwise, please arrive early to secure your preferred spot.

Accessibility
The venue is located downstairs via a set of stairs with a handrail. If you require an alternative access option (is available), please get in touch with Allikins before the event.
Unfortunately, all of our seated options, including those reserved for guests with accessibility needs, are currently sold out. Please feel free to get in touch with us, and we’ll be happy to notify you if additional seating becomes available.

Safety & Content

Trigger warnings will be announced before each performance. We have a strict zero tolerance policy for abusive or discriminatory behavior.

No realistic look weapons (props) will be allowed into the venue.

Contact
Email: allikins.arts@gmail.com
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse, Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse
This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm.

Visit Upper Hutt Blockhouse as part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025.

The Upper Hutt Blockhouse is one of the few remaining buildings associated with the New Zealand Wars, as well as a monument to Pākehā settler anxiety, built in fear of an attack by Māori that never came.

Visit today and you’ll get a sense of the defensive ‘last stand’ mindset. On both floors you’ll find a series of balistraria, tightly angled gun slots through which members of the militia would defend their posts.

Keep an eye out, too, for an exposed panel where you can see the fine gravel that was packed between the exterior weatherboards and inch-thick interior boards to absorb the impact of answering gunfire. Don’t be fooled by the windows – they were added later. Originally, the loop holes you’ll spy on the walls were the only way to see out.

Inside the Blockhouse, there’s an exhibition from Whirinaki Whare Taonga, telling the early story of Upper Hutt and its Blockhouse.

We will have some knowledgeable people available to share stories, answer questions and some light refreshments. Drop in between 11-1pm and stay as long as you like!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $10 - $15
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/visit-the-upper-hutt-blockhouse/


Health & Safety:
Please note as an historic building the Upper Hutt Blockhouse is not suitable for those with accessibility needs.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Bull Rush, THIS SHOW IS R13.

With a roster of Tāmaki Makaurau's best and brightest performers, expect spit-take-worthy gags, epic stories, heartbreaking tales, and live improvised music at Bull Rush.

So gather your mates for a night of never before seen, totally made up, improvised comedy.

Mess with the bull, feel the rush.

Since 2020, Bull Rush has been making it up as they go. With several seasons (Jingle Bull(Rush), Ghoul Rush, Bull Rush (1822) under their belt, these self-professed improv nerds know how to put on a bloody good show.

Winners of Best Improv Group at the 2024 NZ Comedy Guild Awards, among other accolades (not to brag).

“From start to finish, the show kept me laughing, and by the end, I found myself not only impressed by the performers' quick wit and timing but also rediscovering my appreciation for the art of theatre.”

95bfm.com

R13 - This show may contain potential references to sex, violence as death. As this show is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content or themes beyond what is in the description above. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.

Image credit: John Rata
label: Arts & Theatre

Joseph Kinsey is not a name many of us know – or not as well as we know the name Robert Falcon Scott. But from his base in Christchurch, Kinsey – book and art collector, philanthropist, science enthusiast, businessman – forged deep connections with the Antarctic expeditions and the explorers themselves through his tireless work as the agent for various expeditions. Two other New Zealanders also formed close friendships: Charles Bowen, a former politician, and Wellington lawyer Leonard Tripp, to whom Shackleton declared: ‘I love you as David and Jonathan loved.’

South by South tells the story of New Zealand’s role in ‘the Heroic Age’, that wave of exploration beginning at the end of the nineteenth century in which men set out to traverse the continent of Antarctica and, if they survived, to bring home their findings. The members of this New Zealander triumvirate were all believers in the British Empire, but the southern voyages were to an uninhabited land.

South by South brings to light many letters, newspaper articles, and pieces of official correspondence, much of which has not been published before, during the five expeditions of 1901–1916: the Discovery, Nimrod, Terra Nova, Aurora, and Endurance. In particular, Scott’s letters to Kinsey and Shackleton’s to Tripp tell of their hope, despair, exhaustion, and deep gratitude for their friendship. What they and the explorers wrote was influenced by nineteenth-century adventure stories which conveyed the Imperialist ideals of the time. If the impending conflict of 1914–18 was a very ‘literary war’, this was a very literary exploration.

Charles Ferrall is an associate professor at Te Herenga Waka–Victoria University of Wellington. Among his books are Modernist Writing and Reactionary Politics (2001); The Trials of Eric Mareo (2002), co-written with Rebecca Ellis; East by South: China in the Australasian Imagination (2006), co-edited with Paul Millar and Keren Smith; Juvenile Literature and British Society 1850–1950 (2009), co-written with Anna Jackson; Henry Lawson in New Zealand (2012); How We Remember: New Zealanders and the First World War (2014), co-edited with Harry Ricketts; and Remembering Gallipoli: Interviews with New Zealand Gallipoli Veterans (2015), co-edited with Christopher Pugsley.

Cover photograph: The ship Discovery leaving Lyttelton Harbour, 1901. Alexander Turnbull Library, Wellington, New Zealand
Cover design: Spencer Levine

description:
Urban Wine Walk - Pōneke Wellington, The streets and laneways of Pōneke Wellington are set to come alive this Spring as a line-up of eight venues each play host to an incredible winemaker, who'll be there ready to pour and chat you through an unforgettable afternoon.


HOW IT WORKS
Kick things off at your chosen starting spot with something to eat, and then let the adventure unfold. Wander at your own pace, glass in hand, discovering incredible wines and venues along the way.

With a stellar line-up of winemakers, good vibes at every stop, and a guaranteed sell-out crowd, the Urban Wine Walk is the ultimate self-guided tasting experience you and your crew won’t want to miss!


PARTICIPATING VENUES & WINEMAKERS
1 - Choice Bros Ft. Coney Wines (NZ)
2 - Glou Glou Ft. Halite (NZ)
3 - Little Beer Quarter Ft. Hopes Grove & Aard (NZ)
4 - Lulu Bar Ft. Margrain Vineyard (NZ)
5 - Noble Rot Ft. VALLI (NZ)
6 - Panhead Tory St Ft. The Good Way (NZ)
7 - The Arborist Rooftop Bar Ft. Matawhero (NZ)
8 - The Tasting Room Ft. Tettonica Wines (NZ)

*Please note that traditional venue menus may vary due to the nature of the event.


TICKETS
Vino Lover Pass – $79 + Booking Fee (Limited Availability)

WHAT’S INCLUDED
Wine Tastings – Up to 3 wines per winemaker along the trail
$10 Food Voucher – Redeem at your nominated starting venue (before 1pm)
$25 Wine Voucher – Put towards event-day wine orders (six-pack minimum, participating producers only)
Event Essentials – Your official wristband & keepsake tasting glass


EVENT REGISTRATION & COLLECTION
Before heading to your nominated starting venue, swing by the official registration point to collect your wristband, tasting glass & vouchers.

Where: Panhead Tory St (1 Tory St)
When: Saturday 18th October | 11am – 1pm

Please note: The Urban Wine Walk officially runs from 12-4pm. Arrive early to grab your event pack and avoid the rush!


REFUND POLICY
Tickets are non-refundable (we’re all in for good times rain, hail or shine!). The only exception is if the event is cancelled or postponed by the organisers – then we’ve got you covered.


GETTING AROUND
One of the best parts about the Urban Wine Walk...? It’s totally self-guided! After checking in at your nominated starting venue, the day is yours! Wander at your own pace, discover new spots and sip your way through the trail however you like.


Sorry kids, Urban Wine Walk is strictly 18 Years and Over!


----------

Neighbourhood Events Co. recognises the unique role of Māori as Tangata Whenua and embraces Te Tiriti o Waitangi recognising Māori as Tino rangatiratanga of Aotearoa/New Zealand while embracing the three guiding principles of the Treaty – Partnership, Participation and Protection. We will endeavour to implement bicultural policies and practices that incorporate and value Māori cultural concepts, values and practices.

description:
Charlotte Grimshaw: The annual NZSA Janet Frame Memorial Lecture, In her 2025 NZSA Janet Frame Memorial Lecture, Charlotte Grimshaw will report from the frontlines of fiction and memoir, discuss veracity, integrity and clarity in a so-called “post-truth world,” and share ideas she’s formed about authenticity after a whole life lived in fiction.

Grimshaw will describe her ongoing quest for answers, including a recent personal discovery of material in the Turnbull Library archive that shattered some final illusions, and fuelled her determination to go on expressing ideas and writing accurate human stories, no matter what. Don't miss this one-off, very special event.

Presented in partnership with New Zealand Society of Authors Te Puni Kaituhi O Aotearoa (PEN NZ) Inc, and National Library of New Zealand Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa.

This event is free to attend, and will be followed by supper and light refreshments. Please register to secure your place. All welcome.

Charlotte Grimshaw spent two decades publishing fiction after growing up in the family of a writer. In 2021 she published a bestselling memoir, The Mirror Book, about her experiences in the literary family. She described this as an account of the creation of her authentic self.  In her latest novel, The Black Monk (March, 2026), she has continued her exploration of authenticity, blending the “micro” interior world of guilt, truth and lies with the “macro” world of geopolitics and history. Charlotte is the critically acclaimed author of eleven works, including novels, two outstanding collections of linked stories, a best-selling memoir, journalism and book reviewing.

Charlotte Grimshaw is The NZ Society of Authors Te Puni Kaituhi o Aotearoa 2025 President of Honour. This prestigious honour is bestowed on a senior writer and long-serving NZSA member in recognition of their contribution to writing, writers and the literary arts sector in Aotearoa. Each year the NZSA President of Honour delivers the Janet Frame Memorial Lecture.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Comedy on the Coast presents All Roads Lead to Kapiti, Comedy on the Coast presents All Roads Lead to Kapiti
Kapiti Coast, NZ – Prepare to swap your Netflix night for something far funnier—All Roads Lead to Kapiti rolls into the Kapiti Playhouse on 20 September. Doors open at 7:30 pm, the laughs land at 8:00 pm.

Line-Up That’ll Make You Snort-Laugh

Richie Faavesi – "The 2024 Raw Comedy Quest finalist (and Whanganui’s chocolate-humour king) brings brutally honest, father-and-husband-life tales with enough grit and heart to dark-horse the dark side of comedy."
NZ Herald

MC Marc Hamilton – The smooth operator keeping the laughs rolling and the mic mayhem in check.

Emma Jean – A raw new voice and one of the Raw Comedy Quest finalists for 2025—expect freshness, edge, and zero filter.

Reon Matterman – Thrives on weaving truth bombs with sharp wit—something you’ll want to laugh and think about.

Advait Kirtikar – "Qualified actuary by day, Billy T-nominated comedian by night. His super-dry delivery and razor timing earned him awards, accolades, and the uncanny ability to make actuarial science sound sexy. He’s also a two-degree black-belt rock-climber-ex-gymnast blend of absurdity."
Scoop

Why It Matters

This isn’t just comedy—it’s a cross-section of NZ's freshest and fiercest comedic voices, from local legends to rising stars. Whether you're in for the belly laughs, the smart quips, or just wondering if an actuary can be funny—this is your Saturday night.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Confessions Booth, ✨ Confessions Booth - Hosted by a Fabulous Drag Host ✨
Wellington, it’s time to spill your secrets… or just sip and enjoy everyone else’s! 👀
Step into the Confessions Booth for a cheeky, interactive night of cocktails, laughs, and anonymous confessions, hosted by a fabulous drag MC. Part comedy, part interactive theatre, part party - guaranteed to keep you laughing, sipping, and maybe confessing…
Here’s how it works:
On arrival, grab a drink and submit a confession on a card or via QR code. Totally optional - sipping cocktails is a perfectly valid choice!
Confessions must be about you only - keep other people’s skeletons in their closet.
You can submit anonymously, or add your name for a little extra spice and interaction with the host (and a chance to win a price).
Selected confessions will be read aloud by our drag MC, who will add cheeky commentary, playful roasts, and audience Q&A.
Not every confession will make it to the stage, but every secret counts and contributes to the fun.
Between confession sets, enjoy music, cocktails, and mingling. After the main show, the party continues with a pop, disco, and house playlist.
Ticket Tiers:
GA - $25: Entry only.
Upgraded - $35: Entry + welcome bubbly 🥂
VIP - $55: Entry + welcome drink (cocktail, wine, beer or Pal) + charcuterie cup + priority seating.
📍 Where: Whisky & Wood, Wellington
📅 When: Thursday 23 October, 7:00pm
Sip. Spill. Repeat. Whether you’re confessing your darkest secrets or just watching the chaos unfold, this is a night of laughs, drinks, and drama you won’t forget.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Bull Rush, THIS SHOW IS R13.

With a roster of Tāmaki Makaurau's best and brightest performers, expect spit-take-worthy gags, epic stories, heartbreaking tales, and live improvised music at Bull Rush.

So gather your mates for a night of never before seen, totally made up, improvised comedy.

Mess with the bull, feel the rush.

Since 2020, Bull Rush has been making it up as they go. With several seasons (Jingle Bull(Rush), Ghoul Rush, Bull Rush (1822) under their belt, these self-professed improv nerds know how to put on a bloody good show.

Winners of Best Improv Group at the 2024 NZ Comedy Guild Awards, among other accolades (not to brag).

“From start to finish, the show kept me laughing, and by the end, I found myself not only impressed by the performers' quick wit and timing but also rediscovering my appreciation for the art of theatre.”

95bfm.com

R13 - This show may contain potential references to sex, violence as death. As this show is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content or themes beyond what is in the description above. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.

Image credit: John Rata
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Eddie Izzard — The Remix: The First 35 Years, Ever wondered what became of Darth Vader and Mr Stevens, or the monkey in the tree, and did the pears ever ripen? English comic Eddie Izzard has been spinning wildly funny and surreal tales for 35 years. Her huge and devoted fan base is in for a treat as she embarks on a tour. In Eddie Izzard — The Remix: The First 35 Years, she reimagines some of her favourite comedy highlights. She delves into material from the touring show The Ambassadors (1993) through to Wunderbar (2019). For the audience, it’s a glorious chance to hear a new take on classic material and hear another new mad-capped twist to the story. As always, with Eddie, there will be unexpected tangents and hilarious interludes. No night will be the same. 
This show promises to be a beautiful, hilarious journey spanning a 35-year career. It will be thought-provoking, intelligent and suitably surreal. Who could resist?
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Echoes of the Past, Echoes of the Past
Presented by Best on Tap

In keeping with the theme of the festival, Best on Tap ponders what has led us to 'be here now'?

What people, actions, and objects have combined to shape this place we know as Wellington/Te Whanganui a Tara?

What paths have led us to make this our home?

What decisions, genes, and character traits echo through generations to make us who we are today?

This show will traverse time to explore these rich themes, all with a good helping of Best on Tap truth-based, grounded, spontaneous theatre.

After all, what were our ancestors doing if not improvising?

Inspired by Felipe Ortiz (Colombia)

Best on Tap is a Wellington-based improvisation troupe who use truth-based play to create compelling and satisfying narratives. This is spontaneous theatre that honours and entertains.

As this show is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content or themes beyond what is in the description above. The show may contain mature themes and language, but not gratuitously. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.
label: Arts & Theatre

Bedlam & Squalor, Garrett St
October 9th | 7:00 PM
Free entry – no cover charge!
Join us for a night of live jazz as the 2025 NZSM Jazz Performance 3rd-year class takes the stage!
Three dynamic small ensembles will present a diverse and exciting mix of original work and jazz repertoire, celebrating the culmination of three years of study at Te Kōkī — New Zealand School of Music.
Support the next generation of Aotearoa’s jazz artists — this is not one to miss!

description:
Film Talks At Aratoi Presents the Bride of Frankenstein (1935), Film Talks at Aratoi presents The Bride of Frankenstein (1935)
Halloween Film Night 2025

Get ready for a night of cinematic chills and festive frights! Since 2022, Film Talks’ Halloween Film Night has brought Wairarapa audiences together to celebrate classic horror in a fun, immersive atmosphere.

This year, join us on Halloween night for James Whale’s masterpiece, The Bride of Frankenstein (1935). Widely regarded as one of the greatest horror films ever made, it combines unforgettable imagery, Gothic atmosphere, and a surprising touch of dark humour.

Doors open at 6:45 pm, and the movie begins at 7 pm at Aratoi, 12 Bruce Street, Masterton. Running time: 75 minutes.

Costumes encouraged! Spot prizes will be awarded for the best dressed, adding to the spirit of the night. Bring friends, family, or come on your own and join a community of film lovers for playful scares, shared laughs, and a celebration of classic cinema.

Reserve Your Seats. Koha welcome — suggested $5. Your contribution helps keep Film Talks alive and accessible for our community.

Presented by Film Talks, and Aratoi, in association with the Wellington Heritage Festival.

Step into the shadows this Halloween and celebrate the 90th anniversary of one of cinema’s most haunting Gothic classics!
label: Film & Media

Sam's Art House Special Exhibition Preschool Class, Sam's Art House Special Exhibition Preschool Class - Johnsonville Shopping Centre

Friday 29th August 10:00am - 11:00am or 11.30-12.30pm.

Shop 29, Johnsonville Shopping Centre, 34 Johnsonville Road (shop 29 is opposite the Food Court).

Come and join as for a special Budding Artists session at the Inaugural Sam's Art House Student Exhibition.

Sam is running 2 special budding artists (preschool) sessions, These are free but must be booked on Sam's Art House Website as limited spaces. Bring your preschooler (3-4 year olds only) and create alongside them and Sam.

You will not want to miss this!

Drag has exploded here in Aotearoa with new performers emerging every week and we're giving them the chance to show us their stuff.
This stunning resurgence of drag has arrived with thanks from powerhouses in the Wellington drag scene, stars of RuPaul's Drag Race, The Boulet Brothers Dragula, and many more!

From kings, queens, and all the beautiful theys in-between, get ready to cheer these newbies on their debut night, scream their name and say SHANTAY, you stay!

Doors open 9:00PM
Shows start at 9:30PM

Alright, Wellington now let's get into FORMATION!

Please contact Olivia Dreams or Ivy Bar and Cabaret if wheelchair access is required.

*On purchasing tickets please contact the Bar if you wish to book a table for your group. Please arrive earlier to get a seat before the show kicks off (very limited seating)
GA tickets are the same for seating and standing. Venue seating is essentially first in, first served.

*The Cloud 9 tickets on offer - These are General Admission tickets with a different cost to help events and productions like this thrive. It is so lovely and humbling to know the cast and crew are recognised for their art. The extra contribution helps to ensure artists get paid and more amazing events can be produced in the future.

description:
NZ Brewers Fest - Monster Mash, NZ Brewers Fest - Monster Mash
🦇A Day of Decadence, Darkness and Delights 🕷️

Join us from midday until the shadows stretch long, as Brewtown transforms into a haunted haven of unholy delights for NZ Brewers Fest 2025 – Monster Mash!

🍻Fiendishly good Beer!
It wouldn’t be NZBF without great beer, and this year 20 of Aotearoa’s best breweries will descend on Brewtown to pour every style you could possibly desire, from crisp Lagers, cold IPAs and hoppy Pale Ales, to funky Sours, smoky Porters, rich Pastry Stouts – and everything in between!

Visit Brewtown’s own custom Unimog Bar for 13 beers handpicked by our craft beer experts, but get in quick – we only have 1 keg of each, and they won’t last long!

🍸Haunting Spirits & Wine!
New for this year! Step into our haunted cocktail bar for some seriously spooky spirits! Our mixologists have been hard at work creating some devilishly delicious drops just for you.

We’re bringing in some of the best wines the Wairarapa has to offer, so whether you prefer a crisp Sauv, a fruity Pinot or a refreshing Frosé there will be something to enjoy.

Still not enough for you? Then head down to the Everything Else Bar, for NZ crafted ciders, as well as bourbon, rum, gin and vodka alongside a range of low and no alcohol beers, cocktails and soft drinks.

🌮Monstrously Good Kai!
The NZBF food court hosts the region’s top foodies, bringing you big, bold, flavour-packed festival eats that’ll satisfy both the living and the undead.
Watch this space as we announce our festive foodie lineup!

⚔️Enthralling Entertainment!
Lose yourself in a cabaret of the bizarre, where the performances are as dark as they are dazzling. Expect sultry burlesque, twisted characters and moments that will thrill, chill, and have you begging for more.

Witness the brutal thrill of buhurt armoured combat, as warriors face off in full medieval kit in a raw display of might and mayhem.

Dance the day away at the main stage, as Welly’s top talent smash out tune after tune, all building up to a headline show from Brewtown favourites, The Blueprint – as they bring a special set just for Monster Mash! Trust us, you haven’t seen them like this before…

Grab your mates and get stuck in at the Games Zone, where a bit of friendly rivalry meets festive fun, and the loser buys the next round.

Enjoy dressing up? Go all out in your most terrifying, theatrical or jaw-dropping costume — and you might just take out the crown in our epic Best Dressed Competition, with spooky-good prizes up for grabs.

With affordable return coaches from Welly and Petone and great discounts for group tickets it's scarily easy to get involved!
🎃 R18
label: Festivals

description:
Friday Laughs with Lesa Macleod-Whiting and El Jaguar, Saturday Laughs at the Royal Hotel brings top comedy talent to the heart of Featherston

This month's show features -
El Jaguar
Canadian comedy act El Jaguar is coming to wrestle his way into hilarity. From Canada, to New Zealand, and throughout Australia, El Jaguar is making a name for himself on the comedy scene using only his fast wits and tight lycra.
From the dusty streets of central America, rising triumphant as the luchador everyone wanted to be in the World Wrestling Federation circa 1990, then into obscurity: El Jaguar is making a comeback… and it’s going to be hilarious.

And MC Lesa Macleod-Whiting - 2025 Billy T Award nominee
Lesa is a Wellington-based writer, improviser and comedian. She has been a regular on the Wellington improv scene since 2016 and began doing stand-up in July 2020, going on to nab the Runner Up spot at the Wellington Raw Comedy Quest. She has a penchant for characters, accents and fast-paced silliness.
Winner – Best Newcomer – 2020 Wellington Comedy Awards Nominated – Best Newcomer (Lower North Island) – 2020 NZ Comedy Guild Awards

More acts to be announced!

This event brought to you with support from TrustHouse Ltd

Suitable for all ages! Don't miss out, this is a once in a lifetime opportunity.

11am Show $5 child/$10 adult, Under 2's free. Door sales available if not sold out prior.
6pm Show $20, includes drinks and nibbles. Bookings essential.

Light IT Up Inclusive Theatre is a theatre group dedicated to giving performance opportunities for the differently abled in our community. We are based at The Shed Project Kapiti in Paraparaumu. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is our second show. It follows the very successful sold out shows of The Wizard of Oz in 2024.

With headline act, Kura Forrester

Winner of the 2019 Billy T Award, Kura is fast becoming one of the standout comedian actors of New Zealand.

description:
GISH: Live at Foxton Hotel, GISH: Live at Foxton Hotel
Join us for GISH: Live at Foxton Hotel!

Date: Thursday, 23 October 2025
Time: 7:00pm - 9:00pm
Location: Foxton Hotel, Foxton, Horowhenua

Comedy icon GISH is back with a brand-new tour across Aotearoa. For over 20 years, GISH has been one of New Zealand’s most beloved comedians, famous for his outrageous parodies that mix six strings with dodgy things. Get ready for a night where no song is safe. Joining him is Canadian freestyle sensation Jesse Firebrand, a razor-sharp musical comedian known for lightning-fast improvisation comedy songs, tearing through the Australian scene, with no one in New Zealand doing what he does. Your host for the night is Anthony Wilson, an Auckland-based comic and crowd favourite who has performed across Aotearoa, Australia, and the UK, known for quick wit, polished storytelling, and pub-worthy tales. There will also be a special guest on the night.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
George Fenn is: Sexy Ghost Boy (Pōneke), Begin with a circle. Work your way up, slowly. Bravely. The Macarena happens to completion. Scream.

This is how you summon Sexy Ghost Boy, the award winning and hilariously f***able spirit, haunting Pōneke this October.

The show dissects the unspoken rituals and micro neurosis we have around Sex and the presentation of ourselves as sexual agents. Using Clown and Burlesque this wordless performance inspires the audience to heroically rebel against insecurity. Described by witnesses as a hot mess mash up of Mr Bean and Marina Abramović, this show has split the sides of audiences across New Zealand.

-Organised Chaos Award / Auckland Fringe 2024
-Bizarre and Charming Award / Hasting Fringe 2024
-Nominated for Outstanding Performer / Dunedin Fringe 2025

Tickets $30 waged / $20 unwaged.

The show is strictly R18. It contains sexual themes and nudity up to underwear.

Creative team:
George Fenn (he/she/they) is a genre bending comedy theatre maker based in New Zealand who specializes in audience interaction. Their passion is inspired in opposition to the coercive trends of Comedic Interaction, and prioritises negotiating audience’s boundaries and building experiences where power is exchanged and humor is shared.

Anne Cunliffe (she/her) is an emerging producer and comedy nerd who is using the skills learned during her decade long public servant career to excel in Arts Management.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
POP Go the Festival Singers: Island Bay Presbyterian Church, The Festival Singers invite you to a enjoy unforgettable music in POP go the Festival Singers – a dazzling celebration of popular songs from the 1920s right through to today. Expect energy, variety, and entertainment as we journey through swing, rock ’n’ roll, Motown, disco, soft rock, and contemporary pop.
The programme sparkles with classics and favourites: a Beach Boys Medley full of surfside sunshine, Ruru Karaitiana’s iconic Blue Smoke, Elvis Presley’s Hound Dog, and Bobby Darin’s Beyond the Sea. We’ll groove with Pharrell Williams’ Happy, cheer to Survivor’s Eye of the Tiger, and celebrate Kiwi pride in Crowded House’s Weather with You. Heartfelt beauty shines through Simon and Garfunkel’s Bridge Over Troubled Water and Billy Joel’s And So It Goes, while fun abounds with The Lion Sleeps Tonight and Gershwin’s sultry Summertime.
Swing makes its mark with Glenn Miller’s Chattanooga Choo Choo and In the Mood, while a rousing Queen Medley and an exuberant ABBA Medley bring the concert to a thrilling close. Along the way, enjoy contemporary sparkle with Dua Lipa’s Levitating and the timeless artistry of these unforgettable hits.
With the incomparable Jonathan Berkahn at the piano, every piece shines with character and style. This concert promises nostalgia, joy, and toe-tapping fun – a true trip down memory lane with something for everyone.
Join us and be part of a celebration of music that entertains, connects, and uplifts.
label: Festivals

description:
GOMIL (Grumpy Old Man In Lycra), GOMIL (Grumpy Old Man In Lycra)
The Lycra is back: GOMIL – the hilarious new sequel to MAMIL hits the road across New Zealand!

One of New Zealand’s biggest theatrical success stories is back in the saddle! Following the phenomenal popularity of MAMIL (Middle Aged Man in Lycra), which played to over 70,000 people across the country, comes its laugh-out-loud sequel: GOMIL – Grumpy Old Man in Lycra. And this time, it’s going national.

From the comedic genius of writer and director Gregory Cooper (MAMIL, That Bloody Woman) and starring Kiwi acting royalty Mark Hadlow ONZM (King Kong, The Hobbit, SNAG), GOMIL is primed to bring a fresh wave of laughter, Lycra, and life’s mid-life absurdities to 14 cities throughout New Zealand in a major national tour kicking off this September.

After a critically acclaimed, sold-out debut season in Ōtautahi Christchurch, GOMIL is shifting gears and going full speed ahead across Aotearoa. Audiences who laughed (and winced) along with the unforgettable antics in MAMIL will now follow the journey of our favourite cyclist as he faces a new life stage: grumpier, greyer, and still clad in way too much Lycra.

Hadlow, one of the country’s most beloved performers, reprises his role with impeccable comic timing and emotional depth, bringing to life a story that’s not only hilarious, but also touching, timely, and unashamedly relatable.

Whether you’re a weekend warrior, a reluctant spouse, or just someone who enjoys watching others sweat the small (and stretchy) stuff, GOMIL is a must-see. This show digs deep into the world of ageing men, fragile egos, friendship, family, and the undeniable need to keep moving—no matter how creaky your knees may be.

Get ready to laugh, reflect, and maybe even wince in recognition as GOMIL pedals its way across the country this spring. It’s more than a show—it’s a celebration of growing older (and slightly wider) with humour, heart, and a healthy dose of spandex.

Don’t miss the next chapter in this iconic Kiwi comedy saga. GOMIL is coming to a theatre near you—lycra, laughter and all.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
NZIFF: Twinless, A grieving brother finds an unlikely connection at a support group for siblings who have lost a twin, but his burgeoning bromance threatens to turn into something darker in this uncomfortably sharp-witted comedy.

When his brother is suddenly killed in a car accident, estranged sibling Roman (Dylan O’Brien) suffers the unique pain of being permanently severed from his twin. Inseparable in childhood, the brothers drifted apart as adults, brother Rocky (also O’Brien) living out and proud in Portland while Roman lived a (decidedly hetero) tradie life in hometown Idaho. It seems he’ll never have the chance to work through his complicated feelings towards his twin until stumbling upon a bereavement group for just such a purpose.

There he meets Dennis (James Sweeney). Neurotic, sarcastic, gay, he’s the opposite that attracts as the pair bond over trauma and a deep need for attachment. They quickly become each other’s emotional support twin-surrogate, on call for late night grocery trips, afterwork bitch sessions, and road trip singalongs. But odd couple bliss can’t last, as Dennis has more than friendship in mind, Roman grapples with explosive anger issues, and dark secrets inevitably come to light.

Sweeny’s sophomore effort as writer, director, and co-star walks an entertaining balance between discomfort and hilarity. With finely calibrated performances from both leads, Twinless is witty, warped, and surprisingly warm hearted. — Adrian Hatwell
label: Film & Media

description:
Glimmers of Gold | Embroidery by Jo Dixey, A gorgeous new exhibition pops up in Old St Paul's vestry this September featuring 79 hand embroidered golden humans.
Embroiderer Jo Dixey is constantly fascinated by the short interactions we have as humans that leave us with calm or happy feelings; feelings that can last for the rest of the day or sometimes much longer.
'This can be sharing a smile with a stranger on a beautiful day or even in the rain, chatting with people in a long queue, collectively watching a great movie. Being open to these moments enhances our lives and the lives of those around us,' Dixey says.
'In psychology, these tiny moments that stimulate positive feelings are called glimmers.'
Gold is a chemical element with the symbol Au and atomic number 79.
'Welcome to Glimmers of Gold.'
About Jo Dixey
Dixey is a Royal School of Needlework trained embroiderer. She teaches small groups a variety of embroidery techniques, works on commissions which have included large altar cloths, university banners and work for the fashion and movie industries, and repairs old embroideries. She holds exhibitions of her embroidered pieces every few years.
In 2017, Dixey published her first book Stitch People, which was later re-released as Creative Thread.
Her work is held in private and public collections in New Zealand and overseas.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Hatch Showcase, Fresh voices, bold stories. HATCH puts emerging talent in the spotlight!

TAHI Festival’s student showcase, HATCH, champions our next generation of solo performers. In partnership with Te Auaha, Toi Whakaari: NZ Drama School, and Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington, HATCH supports students through workshops, mentorship, and creative development, culminating in a high-energy showcase at BATS Theatre. Show info below.

Cursed Child: The return of Mr Haki
Written and performed by Leia Edmonds
Mr Haki is Leia’s childhood imaginary friend. He returns from the grave to confront her about his death. Cursed Child: The return of Mr Haki is a funny, slightly creepy, and nostalgic tale about the mind of a strange little girl. Contains mental health themes, and depictions of injury or medical distress.

HĀNGĪ PANTS
Written and performed by Waikamania Seve
It's 9:04pm, a Saturday like any other. Scandaleyes smeared on, soju burning sweet, cherry pomegranate nicotine clouding the air. K Road’s about to come alive, but Hāngī Pants is already unpacking the mess. Her lovers, her losses, her lust. Contains flashing lights, course language, themes of sexual assault, substance abuse, and eating disorders; and depictions of sex and semi-nudity.

Warm Night At Normal School
Written and performed by Gabriel Murphy
Gabriel missions across the sticky floors and strobe lights of the school disco to ask the girl he likes to dance with him. But it’s not as easy as it sounds. Recommended for audiences aged 13+. Contains flashing lights and some coarse language.

Enter: Child
Written and performed by Aroha Morrison
Wide-eyed, happy to be there, and - well - utterly clueless. Child leads with curiosity - will you follow?

Lost Memory
Written and performed by George Long
A man is trying to tell the story of meeting someone really important. But unfortunately life changes over time.

Show title to come
Written and performed by Charlie Roigard.
Show info to come.
label: Arts & Theatre

All welcome, see you there!

description:
Heartbreak Hotel, This one's for the young hearts, the old hearts, and the broken hearts.
Direct from a season at London’s Soho Theatre, Circa Theatre and EBKM are delighted to present a limited season of the Heartbreak Hotel. 11 Shows Only.
‘One of the best productions I’ve seen this year.’
★★★★★ Time Out Melbourne
‘It hijacks your nervous system and fast tracks its way into your soul.’
★★★★ Scotsman
“A brilliant production which I loved”
Suzie Miller, writer of Tony award-winning Prima Facie
Story, science and a synth combine in an exhilarating new play that examines what happens in our bodies when we’re bereft.
From acclaimed Wellington-based theatre company EBKM, who brought their ground-breaking Gravity & Grace to Circa Theatre last year (Production of the Year, Wellington Theatre Awards 2024), Heartbreak Hotel tracks a woman’s broken heart in a wrenching and relatable journey that’s studded with classic break-up songs and razor-sharp observations on the physiology of love.
Featuring award-winning performances from Karin McCracken (Gravity & Grace, Yes Yes Yes) and Circa Theatre mainstay Simon Leary (Blithe Spirit, Gravity & Grace, Transmission Beta), as well as exquisite direction from Eleanor Bishop (Gravity & Grace, Girls and Boys), Heartbreak Hotel is a hilarious, honest take on a universal human experience.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
James Nokise: One Night Rant | Wellington, James Nokise: One Night Rant | Wellington
Irreverent, incorrigible, and just ever so outraged, award-winning comedian James Nokise lets loose in Wellington for one night only!

Politicians, policies, preachers, and protests are all in the line of fire as Nokise brings his fast paced, semi-chaotic, always cathartic, blend of humour and hot takes back to NZ for a hilarious hour of big laughs and the occasional frustrated scream.

One Night Rant is political comedy at its sharpest. From parliament scandals to global chaos, Nokise rips into the news cycle, mixing big laughs with bite-sized truths. This is a one-hour comedy special designed for anyone who’s ever shouted at the TV, despaired at the headlines, or secretly enjoyed watching politicians squirm.


About James Nokise

A multi-talented comedian, playwright, columnist, podcaster, theatre maker, and social commentator, James Nokise is known for his fearless approach and his ability to give a voice to underrepresented issues.

Over the course of his illustrious career James has been nominated twice for the Billy T Award (2005, 2006) and the Fred Award for Best New Zealand Show (2013), which he subsequently took out in 2019 for his show God Damn Fancy Man. He won Best Male Comedian at the NZ Comedy Guild Awards (2013), Spirit of the Festival at the 2021 NZ Comedy Fest and the Topp Prize (2024). James was also the winner of best documentary at the 2025 NZ radio awards for his series The Last Voyage of the Rainbow Warrior, and winner of the Best International Podcast at the 2025 Asia Podcast Awards.

James has an extensive touring career, including over a decade of shows in the NZ International Comedy Festival and multiple Comedy Gala performances, as well as years on the international Fringe Festival circuit, performing successful seasons in Edinburgh, Perth, and New York.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
It’s Alive!, Follow two young aspiring scientists as they sneak into their mum's secret lab to conduct their Best Experiment Ever — only for things to go horribly wrong, leading to the accidental creation of a puppet! Will the puppet be a friend? Or will they cause chaos that the kids will need to clean up before mum gets home?

Created by Francesca Browne, It's Alive! is brought to you by Improverished, the improvised theatre company behind family friendly shows like Can I Get an Underground Location and a Mythical Creature? and Random Fairytale Generator. Combining theatre, comedy, science, and improvisation, It's Alive! is full of silliness and joy.

All science experiments have been designed with careful consultation with chemists to ensure the safety of the audience.

Designed especially for tamariki ages 5 to 12 and their whānau. We do not recommend this show for children aged 3 and under.

The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Is It Off?, Created and performed by Mamaeroa (Mo) Munn

This sold-out Pōneke favourite returns for one night only at Hannah Playhouse!

An oversharer with a splash of OCD, comedian, improviser and playwright Mo Munn was once called “unhinged” by a reviewer - and now she’s made it her whole personality! In her first solo hour, Mo squishes stand up, experimental and improvised comedy together for a rapid-fire whiplash of a show! Think one woman comedy buffet, packed with chaotic jokes, outlandish stories and a touch of spectacle. Fresh from debuting at the NZ International Comedy Fest, and taking home two comedy awards, Is it off? will keep audiences on their toes, delivering a comedy experience more hectic than a high school rave.

“… her show goes off in a very good way. It deserves to travel far and wide, as long as the oven is up for that." - John Smythe, Theatreview

" She jabs and slices at her audience and draws laughs instead of blood.... Thematically it's perfect" - Wellyott

General admission - pay what you can: $8 -$40
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
EYA Presents: The Bible and the Sacraments Bible Study, What are the Sacraments? Where do they come from? What do they mean? And why are they so central to our Catholic Faith?
In The Bible and the Sacraments, you’ll discover the deeply biblical roots of the Seven Sacraments and how they are more than mere Church rituals, but streams of life flowing from the living Body of Christ.
Throughout this study, you’ll discover how God has always dealt with His people through “sacraments,” and how the sacraments of the Old Testament find their ultimate fulfillment in the Seven Sacraments instituted by Christ and celebrated in the Catholic Church to this day.
Eucharistia Young Adults (EYA) introduces our second Bible study for 2025! This eleven-lesson Bible study by St Paul Center will delve into the beauty of the sacraments of the Catholic Church.
Please bring your Bible, journal, pen - and of course, your lovely self! Bring your friends, co-workers, family members, the more the merrier!
__________________
Every Wednesday | 16 July 2025 - 08 October 2025
St Mary's of the Angels Parish Hall
Everyone is most welcome!
label: Religion & Spirituality

Serve your best Rihanna fantasy in this lip-sync category. Shine bright like a Diamond, bring the Wild Thoughts, and make the judges scream Where Have You Been all their lives! You will be judged by the delivery of the words in the song and your performance.

--------
Ballroom is a safe space created in the 1960's, forged by the Black, Latinx and queer Americans in protest against the racism and queerphobia that they faced from the non-queer community and white queer community. It is a space held to protect trans womxn of colour, so as guests and participants within this culture it is imperative that we all do our best to respect and honour this sacred space. Homophobia, Transphobia, and any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
To learn more about the culture of Ballroom check out this link: 
https://artsandculture.google.com/project/ballroom. 
The HOUSE OF MARAMA honours the whenua in which this event is able to take place on, belonging to the true sovereigns: 
Te Ātiawa iwi. We also stand in solidarity with indigenous peoples across the world facing injustice. 
TOITŪ TE TIRITI
FREE PALESTINE
FREE CONGO
FREE WEST PAPUA
FREE KANAKY
FREE INDIGENOUS PEOPLE EVERYWHERE. 
LAND BACK.
Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @ova_collective on Instagram.
Please do not hesitate to contact us via houseofmarama@gmail.com or on any of our socials for any questions or concerns you may have.
---------
BALLROOM TERMINOLOGY*
OTA = Open to All, not limited to a specific gender identity/expression, or category style.
SHAKE VS SHAKE = We wanna see you shake that ass, shake that hair, shake those thighs. We want to see why YOU have the best shake.
FACE = Serve FACE, highlighting your structure, eyes, teeth, skin and nose. Makeup allowed.
BODY =The ability to sell your confidence in yourself, specifically through your body (not through sex appeal).
PERFORMANCE = Performing and battling in a style of Vogue (Old Way, New Way, or Vogue Fem).
label: Arts & Theatre

Kotahitanga: Artist Series | Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana, Kotahitanga: Artist Series | Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana
Join Te Waka Huia for the final Kotahitanga event featuring a collaborative response to He Kura Toi Tangata from Wellington taonga Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana.

Thursday 18 September | 6pm–8pm

About Riki Gooch

Dr Riki Neihana Gooch lives in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa. His work spans multiple disciplines, including composition, performance, sound art, production, and academic research. He has led and conducted large-scale ensemble projects, performed in a wide range of collaborative settings, and created work for both recorded and live contexts. His ongoing projects include solo and group performances, conduction ensembles, DJ sets, and sound-based installations. He is also involved in cultural leadership and mentorship roles, holding wānanga and contributing to intergenerational knowledge exchange within the arts.


About Bennett Pomana

Bennett Pomana (Te Aitanga-a-Māhaki, Ngāi Tāmanuhiri) is a musician raised in Upper Hutt, with roots in Tūranganui-a-Kiwa. A longtime contributor to Aotearoa’s hip hop legacy, he has been part of pioneering groups including Upper Hutt Posse and Dam Native. His work is deeply influenced by his Māori identity, drawing inspiration from whakapapa, lived experience, and the ongoing pursuit of justice and expression through sound.


This event has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

Kotahitanga: Artist Series - Tusiata Avia, We are honoured to host acclaimed poet; Tusiata Avia who will be opening Kotahitanga with her response to He Kura Toi Tangata.

Expect nothing less than the power of the word steeped in truth and machete-sharpened wit from this New Zealand Samoan poetry pantheon.

6:30pm Interval
6:45pm Artist Q&A
7pm Closing Karakia and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition
8pm Bar closes, event ends



About Tusiata Avia

Tusiata Avia MNZM is a poet, writer and performer. She has published 5 books of poetry, children’s books, short film, radio documentary. Her iconic play Wild Dogs Under My Skirt showed Off-Broadway in 2020, where it won the Fringe Encore Outstanding Production of the Year. Her most recent play, The Savage Coloniser Show won Best New Play at Wellington Theatre Awards 2024. Both plays are based on books of poetry of the same name.

Tusiata was awarded a Member of the New Zealand Order of Merit for services to poetry and in 2024, the Prime Ministers Award for Literary Achievement: Poetry.


This event has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

description:
Thorndon Fair 2025, Thorndon Fair 2025
Wellington’s iconic street fair is back!

Since 1977, the Thorndon Fair has been a highlight of the capital’s summer calendar — and in 2025, we’re bringing the energy, creativity and community spirit back to the streets of Thorndon.

With over 250 stallholders from across Aotearoa, this is your chance to discover:
🖼️ Unique art and crafts
🍴 Delicious food and drink
👚 Fashion, accessories and lifestyle products
📚 Books, gifts, toys, and treats for pets
🌿 Outdoor and experience products
🎶 Live music and entertainment all day

Whether you're shopping, looking for a fun day out with the whānau, or just love a good local market — there’s something for everyone.

Around 40% of our stallholders travel 100km or more to be here, so many of the products you’ll find are unique to Wellington on the day.

Get ready for a drag showdown like no other as Wellingtons Lip Sync Assassins hit the stage with high drama, higher heels, and killer performances that’ll leave you gagging for more! Our fiercest queens and kings are ready to slay the stage in a lip-sync battle to the death (joking of course)!

Watch as a lineup of unstoppable talent goes head-to-head in a night of iconic anthems, jaw-dropping moves, and show-stopping stunts. From power ballads to pop bangers, each number is a deadly display of pure performance power.
WHO WILL BE CROWNED WELLINGTONS LIP SYNC ASSASSIN?

Crack open a cold one and get set for a night of mean kōrero and wild comedy from this spontaneous tira whakaari. Like all good garage parties, this show will be jam-packed with crack up storytelling, cheeky banter, and plenty of laughs.

Kōrero Paki is a Māori and Pacifica improv group who have performed in the NZ International Comedy Fest and the NZ Improv Festival. A group of improvisers and stand up comedians, Kōrero Paki is focused on comedic storytelling improv.

description:
Folk Bitch Trio – Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Folk Bitch Trio – Te Whanganui-a-Tara
Folk Bitch Trio - 'Now Would Be A Good Time' Album Tour
with special guest Georgia Knight

Now Would Be A Good Time, the debut album by Folk Bitch Trio, tells vivid, visceral stories. Their music sounds familiar, and it’s built on a foundation of the music they’ve loved throughout their lives–gnarled Americana, classic rock, piquant, clear-eyed balladry. But the songs are modern, youthful, singing acutely through dissociative daydreams and galling breakups, sexual fantasies and media overload, all the petty resentments and minor humiliations of being in your early twenties in the 2020s.

Heide Peverelle (they/them), Jeanie Pilkington (she/her) and Gracie Sinclair (she/her) have known each other since high school, and first started singing together five years ago. Peverelle recalls sending Pilkington a heartbroken—in their words “bad”—song they had written called “Edie”; Pilkington remembers the song differently. “I felt so inspired that my teenage peer had written something so honest and original,” she recalls. It wasn’t long before she messaged Peverelle and Sinclair, asking if they’d be interested in starting a “folk bitch trio.” As soon as they started singing together, their connection deepened, and “the chemistry of being inspired by each other was evident from the get-go,” says Sinclair.

Listening to Folk Bitch Trio, it’s clear that this is a band of three distinct points of view, with contrasting and complementary backgrounds and visions. Pilkington grew up with two musician parents and brings formative memories of watching them perform, of listening to Gillian Welch and Lucinda Williams, and of her own imagined path as a career musician. Peverelle spends their spare time making art and furniture; those hobbies, as well as their love of pop music old and new, articulate a love for the tactile, the home-grown and the hand-made. Sinclair is the self-proclaimed jester of the group, but her taste skews dark, gothic, baroque and dramatic, expressed as a love of opera and ballet as well as musicians as wide-ranging as Patti Smith, Nirvana and Tchaikovsky.

Folk music has a bad habit of being presented as a deathly serious concern. It’s the music you cry to, it’s overly sacred, it’s solemnly considered by critic-historians. But Folk Bitch Trio have a shared sense of humour that is embedded deep in their music and that sets it alight, safe from the self-serious traps of the genre. Now Would Be A Good Time is funny and darkly ironic in the manner of writers like Mary Gaitskill or Otessa Moshfegh. On “Gods A Different Sword” they crack that “My body keeps the score/But if you tell me that you need it/I can get up off my floor,” a nod to the clichéd, over-referenced millennial self-help book, as they wryly sing about sex within earshot of housemates, and wring sexual innuendo from physics terminology.

description:
Monument, Sculpting the future of our nation

“Succession meets Barbie” -Showcase Victoria
Edith Aldridge is the youngest woman to be elected leader of her country. In a lush presidential suite, she has just ninety minutes to get ready for the most monumental day of her life. But things are not going to plan. Due to heavy fog, her team is stuck in another city. Enter Rosie, a twenty-two year old makeup artist from the David Jones counter, sent last minute to help Edith get camera ready.
From very different worlds, these two women, though face to face, do not see eye to eye in this provocative, slick and funny play that is “sparkling fresh and urgently of the now”.

The team that brought you PRIMA FACIE, brings you this dynamic new work that “explores the role that makeup and fashion play in how we perceive and receive women in power.” -review quotes from Arts Hub & Australian Arts Review.


Written by Emily Sheehan
Produced by Kavanah Productions & BRAVE Theatre
Directed by Lyndee-Jane Rutherford

description:
Kids Rock 4 Palestine, Kids Rock For Palestine
One Day. One Stage. One Cause.
This event is organised by kids in Pōneke to raise funds for kids in Palestine.
Join us for a one-day-only music fundraiser where young voices take centre stage to amplify hope and raise money for children in Palestine.
This isn’t just a concert, it’s a movement. Under-18 musicians, solo artists, and bands (some joined by over-18 allies) are coming together to rock out with purpose, showing that music knows no borders and compassion has no age limit.
These young performers are using their talents to stand in solidarity with kids just like them who are living through unimaginable circumstances.
Organiser Eddie 12: "We see children in Palestine who are being bombed and shot and are starving. We kids want to help. So that is what we are doing."
There will be stalls and crafting available for kids attending - Please come and support so we can raise money for Gaza's families.
100% of proceeds go directly to emergency aid and child-focused relief in Palestine - Convoys of Good and Kiwi Trust for Palestinian Childrens Relief.
Witness the next generation of artists and activists sharing the stage and raising their voices. Please support them with your attendance. Show them young people can make a difference.
Be part of an event where music becomes action, and community becomes change.
Do you want to volunteer to help? Email aotearoa2gaza@gmail.com
ALL UNDER 18s MUST ATTEND WITH A PARENT OR GUARDIAN.

description:
Made to bloom, exhibition by Josefine Gronkrans, We have a solo exhibition coming up from one of our ceramic artists Josefine Gronkrans
The opening night is 14th October, Tuesday at 5:30 pm
Vincents gallery : Willis St Village
5/148 Willis St
Wellington
14th October - 4th November
Pencil the date.
Nau mai haere mai.
Josefine Gronkrans bio
I'm a ceramicists from a rural part of Wellington who take inspiration from the beauty of Creation. I moved to beautiful Aotearoa from Sweden a few years ago, and my journey with ceramics started in 2023 and I've been elbows deep in clay ever since. I use flora found all over the world, and outside my doorsteps, to shape my artwork. My ceramic pieces are all hand made and no piece will be the other alike. I mainly throw a shape on the wheel and then let it tell me what it wants to become.
This exhibition is guided by Ecclesiastes 3:1-11. I think life is beautiful in it's times of joy, but also in the times of struggle, where we can grow and learn.
A Time for Everything
There is a time for everything,
and a season for every activity under the heavens:
a time to be born and a time to die,
a time to plant and a time to uproot,
a time to kill and a time to heal,
a time to tear down and a time to build,
a time to weep and a time to laugh,
a time to mourn and a time to dance,
a time to scatter stones and a time to gather them,
a time to embrace and a time to refrain from embracing,
a time to search and a time to give up,
a time to keep and a time to throw away,
a time to tear and a time to mend,
a time to be silent and a time to speak,
a time to love and a time to hate,
a time for war and a time for peace.
What do workers gain from their toil? I have seen the burden God has laid on the human race. He has made everything beautiful in its time. He has also set eternity in the human heart; yet no one can fathom what God has done from beginning to end.
label: Arts & Theatre

Oops! All Donkeys, Oops! All Donkeys
Directed by Christine Brooks

Make. Pull. Carry. Work. Repeat.

Donkeys! Are you not tired? Atomised and alienated? It’s time to lay down your burdens and join us at our retreat. Be among friends. Feel the cool gleam of the moon upon your ears. Find and then heal your inner donkey. A most rare vision awaits.

From the creator of Love Isthmus: Dystopia Edition (“a truly bizarre and apocalyptic hour of improv” - The Wellingtonista), Murder on a Boat (“really, really, really good” - Regional News), and The Solarpunk Archives (“creative antics that leave the audience howling with laughter” - Theatreview) comes this festival premiere of the show concept that came to the director in a dream.

description:
New Zealand International Comedy Festival, Every May, the capital comes alive with laughter, thanks to the New Zealand International Comedy Festival (NZICF). New Zealand’s homegrown talent shares the stage with some of the world’s most exciting comedians. You could catch a big-name international artist, or discover a new local rising star. 
Since it began in 1993, the aim of the festival has been to champion the craft of comedy so everyone can share a laugh. Every year, a huge group of comedians descend on Wellington from local shores and beyond to deliver three weeks of merriment. 
The festival offers a diverse range of high-quality laughs. It showcases the best of local comedy and gives audiences a taste of some of the world’s best acts. Catch over 100 comics performing at The Opera House, BATS Theatre, Fringe Bar, San Fran, and more.
