description:
Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE, Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE WAIKANAE SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
2-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
2.15-2.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
2.45-3pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!

description:
John Campbell’s Destiny Church Investigation: Part 2 Under His Command, John Campbell investigated Destiny Church in a five-part documentary screened in April this year.
Join us to watch Part 2 of John Campbell’s Destiny Church investigation. John Campbell highlights some consistent themes of Brian Tamaki's Destiny Church: far-right prejudices, manifest anger, and hatred.
In Auckland on 21 June, Destiny Church organised a march to take "a bold public stand for Christian values, Kiwi identity and the future of this nation".
On Saturday, 13 September, Brian Tamaki attended the London “Unite the Kingdom” protest organised by far-right political activist Tommy Robinson that claimed to celebrate 'free speech', but also contained chants of hate, racist conspiracy theories, and Christian nationalist slogans. Among disturbing scenes, some people in the crowd ripped up a flag that read 'Secular Humanism'. To them, the very idea that people of all backgrounds and beliefs can live together with equality and respect is something to fear and destroy. For decades, the far right in the USA has painted humanism as a bogeyman, blaming it for liberal values, the rights of women, and the rights of LGBT people. It shows that those who thrive on fear are deliberately targeting the very values that underpin human rights and human dignity. Humanism is not a fringe or ‘woke’ idea. It is about fairness. It is about reason. It is about believing in the good that people are capable of when they are free to live their lives without fear or prejudice. These protests, which Brian Tamaki is supporting, are a show of force from those who wish to undo progress, to divide communities, and to undermine cherished freedoms.
We have a growing concern for secular values in our community. We cannot be silent. It is essential to keep compassion alive in public life and politics. After watching the documentary, we will discuss our concerns and how we might respond.
Time: Oct 6, 2025 06:30 PM Auckland, Wellington
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/88183700512...

description:
Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // California Home & Garden, Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // California Home & Garden
After several SOLD OUT workshops in Wellington here is the next one... Oct 2025

Learn the magical art of Kintsugi with Artist Ema Frost in this new Workshop. You can bring along a piece of your own pottery to restore in this beautiful style. (I'll also have a few as back up if you don't have your own piece) (All Levels)

Monday 13th October - 10:00am - 12:00pm

Have you ever wanted to try Kintsugi.... It's an ancient Japanese art form where you fix broken pottery with gold - making its imperfections its beauty. - A truly wonderful philosophy to live by. Nothing is ever really broken but new life and meaning is brought back making your piece a work of art and truly something special. You can also apply this technique on various materials like glass, wood, greenstone and shells.

Kintsugi
It's called kintsugi (金継ぎ), or kintsukuroi (金繕い), literally golden (“kin”) and repair (“tsugi”). This traditional Japanese art uses a precious metal – liquid gold, liquid silver or lacquer dusted with powdered gold – to bring together the pieces of a broken pottery item and at the same time enhance the breaks.

You will take away your wonderful finished work, plus your new skills which will enable you to further your own Kintsugi in your own time.

What you will take away:
A finished artwork piece
A understanding of Kintsugi
Knowledge and History of this beautiful art form.

* California Home & Garden, 316 Waiwhetu Rd, Lower Hutt, Wellington 5011. NEW ZEALAND
* Monday 13th October
* 10:00am - 12:00pm
* $175

description:
Dan Hayles Presents | On The Grid, On The Grid is about the marking, passing and embellishing of time. The Grid is life, time, tone, tonality, rhythm, gravity, momentum, and style. 

The musicians work at times together, other times separately as 3 ensembles (horn quintet, string quartet, piano trio), and other times as combinations conversing and improvising amongst themselves. The music covers a selection of different styles and feels within and outside the jazz sound - and it's ready for your participation as a listener of melodies, dancer of beats, expresser of moods, theorist of lore, interpreter of meaning, and feeler of feels.

On The Grid consists of brand new music arranged and composed especially for the Jazz Composer Orchestra series, originally curated and presented by Michael Costeloe with funding from Creative New Zealand in 2025. This show celebrates the release on CD of the group's first ever performance - buy a copy and help us take On The Grid to more audiences around Aotearoa and the world.

Sylvester Green - Trumpet
Tyaan Singh - Alto Saxophone
Louisa Williamson - Tenor Saxophone and Flute
Chris Buckland - Tenor Saxophone and Clarinet
Matthew Allison - Trombone
Seth Boy - Bass
Abe Baillie - Drums

Part of the Wellington Jazz Festival 2025

description:
Live & Work in Japan! Q&A Evening with JET Programme Alumni, Have you ever wanted to live and work in Japan?
Come talk
to some people who've done it!
Every year, a diverse range of New Zealanders representing a variety of backgrounds, ages, interests, and cultures start a life-changing adventure in Japan-and next year that could include you!
With applications for the New Zealand JET Programme around the corner, you may have questions about what it's actually like to be sent off to live and teach in Japan for a year or more!
The JET Alumni Association of Wellington, in coordination with The Embassy of Japan, have organised a casual evening event for prospective applicants to ask those questions, and hear some stories to help you make a better decision about if the JET Programme is right for you.
Q&A event details
Date: 6th October 2025
Time: 17:30 - 19:30
Location: Yoshi Sushi & Bento (Press Hall, Willis Street)
Doors open from 5:30, with Q&A starting from 6:00.
Enjoy free
courtesy of Yoshi Sushi & Bento.
(Drinks, including Japanese
will also be available for purchase).
Admission to the event is FREE!
So come along and bring your friends
to this great opportunity to meet a handful of the thousands of Kiwis who've taken part in this programme over the past 40 years
Anyone interested in applying is welcome to attend!

What is the Japan Exchange Teaching (JET) Programme, you ask?
The JET Programme is an overseas employment opportunity to live and work in Japan for a year or more! You could soon head abroad on the adventure of a lifetime, and get paid for it!
Programme criteria includes the following-are you:
A New Zealand citizen?
Already graduated?
Or will have your Bachelor's Degree/Teaching Diploma conferred by early July 2026?
Interested in international activities?
Interested in teaching English to young people and living in Japan?

Positions available:
Assistant Language Teacher (ALT)
ALTs help the Japanese foreign language teachers in class and help prepare teaching materials and class activities. They may assist in English language clubs and other extra-curricular activities. Knowledge of Japanese is not required to be an ALT.
Coordinator for International Relations (CIR)
CIRs work in local government offices and are involved in international activities, which might include editing publications, translation work, advising on the planning and implementation of exchange programmes, and interpreting at international events. A functional knowledge of written and spoken Japanese is required to be a CIR.
For more information about the New Zealand JET Programme, visit:
https://www.nz.emb-japan.go.jp/itpr_en/jet.html
https://www.facebook.com/JETProgrammeNZ/
We hope to see you there!

description:
Katherine Mansfield's Thorndon: Guided Walking Tour, Katherine Mansfield's Thorndon: Guided Walking Tour
Part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025

"How hard is it to escape from places. However carefully one goes they hold you – you leave little bits of yourself fluttering on the fences – like rags and shreds of your very life.” Katherine Mansfield in a letter to Ida Baker, 1922

Explore the Thorndon that Katherine Mansfield knew and the traces of her legacy that remain in the landscape today. Beginning with an introductory talk, a viewing of the exhibition 75 Tinakori Road: “This marvel had come to the lane” and a hot drink at Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, the guided walking tour will finish at the National Library of New Zealand.

Please note: This is a guided walking tour which will involve approx. 30 minutes of walking on flat ground with frequents stops. Participants are encouraged to wear comfortable shoes and bring appropriate protection from sun and rain. The tour will begin upstairs at Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, if you have accessibility requirements, please see the accessibility information on our website or contact us to discuss.

Bad weather postponement dates: The tour will go ahead if there is light rain, so please bring a raincoat. If there is heavy rain and/or strong winds the Saturday 18 October tour will be postponed to Saturday 25 October; the Thursday 23 October tour will be postponed to Thursday 30 October. Participants will be notified by email and text message (if a mobile number is provided when booking) by 9am on the day of the tour if there is a postponement.

(Image: The Katherine Mansfield Memorial photographed by Charles P S Boyer, c1930s. Wellington City Council Archives, 00157-99)

MMC Evening Connection! #2
Created in response to requests for more after-hours activities, these evenings gathering is all about community, storytelling, and belonging.
Whether you're new to Marlborough or a long-time local, join us for a relaxed Friday evening of conversation and connection in a welcoming space. This is your chance to meet others, share experiences, and celebrate the diverse cultures that make up our region.

Come along for Kōrero, laughter, and meaningful connection.
Bring a friend or make a few new ones!

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.

Marlborough Sports Awards 2025, Marlborough Sports Awards 2025
Join us for Marlborough's premier sports awards function. The 2025 live awards dinner, recognising all our nominees and winners.

About this Event



2025 Sport Tasman Marlborough Sports Awards
Saturday 22nd November. Marlborough Events Centre
6 pm meet and mingle, to be seated by 6.30pm.
The Marlborough Sports Awards is an opportunity to acknowledge some of our top sportspeople amongst family, friends and the wider community. The 58th annual Awards will take place at the Marlborough Events Centre at 6.00pm on Saturday 22nd November 2025.

Dress Code: Formal Dress Attire (no jeans please)
Join us in celebrating the success of Marlborough's leading athletes through to our grassroots heroes, and to recognise one person's lifetime contribution to sport when they are awarded the prestigious 'Marlborough Medal'.
MC: Our 2025 Masters of Ceremony will be returning back to his home stomping ground to provide some vibrant entertainment.Tony Lyall is one of Aotearoa's leading MC's with a background working in 7 Days, The Project, Radio Hauraki alongside his sporting success leading the Match Days for Black Caps, NZ Cricket and the Blues Rugby.
We have some exciting new categories for 2025!

Premier / National / International Awards
Emerging Young Talent of the Year (Under 19yrs) x 2
Sportswoman of the Year
Sportsman of the Year
Supreme Team of the Year
Overall Sportsperson of the Year

Aspiring / Regional / Awards
Community Team of the Year

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
Letters out Loud 2025 — Part of Friends of the Turnbull Library Public Programme Series, A 1940 newspaper exhorted its readers to ‘write a letter! Take a little chunk of your heart and spread it over some paper; it goes, oh, such a long way!’
Letters out Loud will expose some of those heart-felt issues people addressed on paper in the past. Well-known personalities will read letters from the Alexander Turnbull Library Collections which reveal concerns, among other things:
* the oldest extant Māori letter, written and read by a child
* the ups and downs of farm life
* Yehudi Menuhin in the bath
* a Member of Parliament in love
* on board the sinking Wahine in 1968.
Brought to life by familiar voices
Letters out Loud will be an evening of historical texts brought to life by familiar voices. Come and enjoy an enlivening of the past that has many resonances for today. Speakers include Ngahiwi Apanui- Barr, Una Cruickshank, Tanea Heke, Michele Leggott, David O’Donnell, Karen O’Leary, Trevor Richards, Vaughan Slinn, and Jennifer Ward-Lealand.
Doors open at 5pm for drinks and nibbles, readings begin at 6pm.
Book your tickets
Tickets to this gala fundraising event include a souvenir programme and refreshments.
https://events.humanitix.com/copy-of-letters-out-loud
All profits go to support grants for research at the Alexander Turnbull Library. The Friends of the Turnbull Library (FOTL) offer grants of $20,000 available to scholars whose research involves the use of the collections of the Alexander Turnbull Library.
https://turnbullfriends.org.nz/research-grant/
label: Community & Culture

description:
Wellington Timebank fundraiser screening of Tinā, Wellington Timebank fundraiser screening of Tinā
Get your tickets here - https://events.humanitix.com/wtb-fundraiser-screening-of-tina

Join us for this special screening of this award winning Aotearoa-made film - Tinā (2024). If you missed it in the cinemas the first time round, you can now watch it from the comfort of the Newtown Community Centre!

Doors open at 5pm
Film starts at 6pm (running time is 2 hours 4 minutes)

Tickets are just $25 waged / $20 unwaged (all tickets include snacks) and proceeds go toward keeping your Timebank in operation.

About the film:
Award-winning writer/director Miki Magasiva (The Panthers, We Are Still Here) makes his feature debut with Tinā (Samoan for "mother"). Samoan music teacher Mareta (Anapela Polataivao) is plunged into grief after losing her daughter in the Christchurch quakes. Mareta takes a relieving role at an elite private school, where she inspires her students to perform at a big choral competition. In the trailer Mareta faces a condescending interview at Saint Francis, and her growing relationship with "spoiled, rich kids" annoys a family member. Tinā was chosen to open the 2024 Hawai’i International Film Festival.

The Guardian says "It’s a big-hearted tear-jerker about the power of art – and it’s already breaking records in its home country, where it’s received the widest-ever release for a local film and become the sixth-highest grossing New Zealand film of all time."

This film is rated M (contains violence, offensive language and suicide references).

description:
Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - Banksy Heart Balloons, The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Wellington! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: No drinks are included in the ticket price, but drinks are available for purchase.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

description:
Over the Rainbow, Over the Rainbow
There’s no place like Pōneke.

Queer historian Will Hansen and legendary barman Malcolm Vaughan kōrero the capital’s vibrant LGBTQIA+ nightlife for Wellington Heritage Festival.


About Will

Will Hansen (he/him) is a transgender historian based in Pōneke. He is the recipient of a Judith Binney Trust Writing Award and is currently working on turning his PhD thesis – ‘Queer Activism in Aotearoa, 1961-2013’ into a book. Will is also a trustee of Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa.


About Mal

Malcolm Vaughan is a Wellington gay icon. Before the Homosexual Law Reform Act of 1986, Mal worked at a series of bars and late-night haunts in the capital. More than just places to drink, venues like The Dominion, Bamboo Bar, Casper’s, The Dome (to name a few) provided a safe place in the capital for the city’s rainbow community to meet without prejudice. Today, Malcolm alongside husband, Scotty Kennedy ow and run the iconic Cuba Street establishment Scotty & Mal’s Cocktail and Lounge Bar.

Advocates for many LGBTQIA+ causes, they have supported many community initiatives over the years. In 2000 they co-founded the After Life Memorial Trust, now called the Chrissy Wītoko Memorial Trust, which originally provided financial support for AIDS patients of the rainbow community. The Trust continues to provide a wide range of support for the Wellington rainbow community.
label: Community & Culture

Open Mic Night at Eva, Eva Pub's Open Mic Night: A Celebration of Wellington's Finest Musicians!

Join us every Thursday night at Eva Pub for an unforgettable celebration of Wellington's vibrant music scene!
With an electrifying array of local talent and plenty of opportunities for you to shine, there's no better place to experience the magic of live music than your favorite local hangout.

What to Expect:

Supportive Atmosphere: Hosted every week, our Open Mic Night is more than just an event; it's a community. Our friendly host will help you settle in, assist with setup, and organize the sets to ensure a seamless and enjoyable experience.
Community of Creatives: Experience the warmth of a community that appreciates and supports local and new performances. Whether you're a regular or a first-timer, our stage welcomes you with open arms.
Why You Should Be Here:
Discover Hidden Gems: Uncover the hidden musical gems that Wellington has to offer. Our Open Mic Night is a melting pot of diverse talents waiting to be discovered.
Join In or Enjoy as a Spectator: Whether you're a performer or a music enthusiast, our Open Mic Night is the perfect place to share your talent or simply enjoy a night of entertaintment.
Secure Your Spot:
Don't miss out! Reserve your spot now for Eva Pub's Open Mic Night
Let's make Thursday nights at Eva Pub the highlight of your week as we come together to celebrate the incredible music that our city has to offer. See you there!

description:
PANEL TALK: BALLROOM CULTURE, Ballroom is a queer subculture. The Ballroom scene today was created by Black and Latinx trans women in the late 1960s in Harlem, New York. Since then, ballroom has taken over the world with scenes in Europe, Asia, Africa, South America and Oceania.
The Aotearoa Ballroom scene was ignited by Māori and MVPFAFF+ youth in Tāmaki Makaurau over 10 years ago, and has since inspired other leaders across the motu to forge their own Ballroom communities in their respective cities. 
In preparation for The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball, hear from influential figures who have made significant contributions to their own scenes. With international Icons and Legends coming to Aotearoa for the first time, there has never been a better time to learn and enhance our own knowledge and experience of Ballroom. 
Featuring ballroom leaders Arturo Mulan (NYC, USA), Matyouz Royalty (Paris, EU), Jaycee Iman (Auckland, NZ), Karamera Marama and Romé Marama.
Panellists
Icon Arturo Mulan (NYC Father of the International House of Miyake-Mugler) (he/him) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the beating heart of Ballroom, NYC. Arturo has been involved in Ballroom since 1996 and has established himself as a visionary choreographer and community leader, with the title of NYC father of the international mainstream House of Miyake Mugler. His influence spans competitive wins, global workshops, and has dedicated his time to bringing diverse artistry into ballroom culture, and ballroom culture into diverse arts opportunities; such as Legendary - Season 2 (HBO Max), Brooklyn Nets performances, Cats the Jellicle Ball on Broadway and more.
Icon Tantine Matyouz Royalty (International Godmother of the International House of Gorgeous Gucci) (he/she/they) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the Paris Ballroom scene and is the creator of the ‘Fashion Killa’ category. They discovered voguing and ballroom culture in 2009 during a trip to New York which they believe changed their life. Their impact within ballroom spans several categories: Commentator vs Commentator, Hands Performance, Runway and Fashion categories. Matyouz has become a staple commentator and music artist within the ballroom community, with a repertoire of modelling and influencer opportunities in their resumé.
Legendary Overall Founding Mother Jaycee Iman aka Jaycee Tanuvasa (she/her) is an inter-disciplinary Sāmoan artist and choreographer of fa’afafine, femme queen & trans experience. Born and raised in South Auckland, Tāmaki Makaurau, her work is firmly rooted in community as she places autonomy and story sovereignty at the core of each of her projects. She celebrates the fullness of young, queer, brown life and works collaboratively to create empowering and responsive reflections of this across a range of media such as theatre, film and activations.
Founding Mother Karamera Marama (he/they) is an emerging multi-disciplinary, queer and Māori artist professing in Graphic Design, Dance and Performance Arts. They are the Co-Founding Mother of the trailblazing Kiki House of Marama, Co-Director of Pōneke-based queer arts collective OVĀ and member of the Aotearoa Ballroom council. Karamera has been involved in Ballroom since 2020 competing in Performance and Fashion categories and winning numerous grand prizes across Aotearoa & so-called Australia respectfully; most notably within Vogue Fem categories.
Founding Mother Romé Marama (he/him) whakapapa to Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Kahungunu, Ngāti Hineuru, and Ngāti Tūwharetoa. He is an emerging multi-disciplinary performing artist, as well as the Co-Founding Mother of the House of Marama and Co-Founding Director of OVĀ. For the past five years, he has been a prominent figure in Aotearoa Ballroom, both competing and facilitating events. Renowned in the RUNWAY category, Romé has secured multiple Grand Prize titles across Aotearoa and so-called Australia.
Facilitator: Kasi Marama (he/him/barb) 
Kasi Valu ('Eua, Ma'ufanga, Lapaha / Tonga) Full-Time sergeant of Gag city #Barbz Part-Time hater of the Rihanna #Navy and Casual staff member of the #Beyhive. Retired Hater of the #swifties and founding member of Azealia Banks support group. Actor, Writer, and Producer. His work currently centres on the experiences, wit, complexities, and universality of Pacific peoples, all whilst being an all-time fia botz, professional guesser and self-deprecating in this miserable world.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Pacific Peoples and the Underclass of Aotearoa New Zealand: Repositioning the Narrative, In 2018, over 380,000 people in Aotearoa New Zealand identified with at least one Pacific ethnicity. Despite being a youthful and growing community, Pacific peoples are statistically entrenched in a cycle of disadvantage that cannot be ignored.
In almost every measure—health, education, income, home ownership, and justice—Pacific people are overrepresented in poor outcomes.
We are not just facing a Pacific problem; we are looking at the face of New Zealand’s underclass—systemic, intergenerational, and largely invisible in mainstream policy conversations. Despite progress for some groups, the Pacific population remains on the wrong side of the statistical ledger.
Pacific peoples experience:
• The highest rates of avoidable hospitalisations and chronic conditions.
• Worst material deprivation across nearly every indicator.
• Persistently low home ownership rates.
• A widening education achievement gap, often masked by ethnic averages.
• Underrepresentation in decision-making, leadership, and governance roles.
While initiatives for Māori advancement are critical and must continue, Pacific peoples require their own distinct policy lens. A “one-size-fits-all” approach under a pan-ethnic umbrella risks making the Pacific experience invisible.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

Tickets:

Adults: $20

Children: $12

Family of 3: $40

Family of 4: $55

description:
Embody Your Flow - Reconnect to the wisdom of your menstrual cycle, Embody Your Flow - Reconnect to the wisdom of your menstrual cycle
Explore how to recognise your body’s rhythms, needs and strengths throughout your menstrual cycle, and discover supportive practices grounded in somatic and embodied awareness.

Attuning to the wisdom of the menstrual cycle offers a meaningful way to honour your natural rhythms, nurturing ease, creativity, and deeper connection.

This course is trauma-informed and inclusive. No prior somatics experience is necessary, and all who menstruate are welcome.

****************
Bookings:
https://www.trybooking.com/nz/events/landing/16754?embed

Or email

Ticket prices range from $50-$75. If finance is a barrier please reach out.

****************
Amy Richards is a yoga teacher based in Pōneke, with a Certificate in MindBody Therapy. She is drawn to the ways intentional movement and embodied awareness can shape our inner experience and relationships. Grounded in a trauma-informed approach, her work invites exploration of connection with sensation and emotion through the body.

Her practice is influenced by Tantric Shaivism, contact improvisation, Open Floor dance, Hakomi somatic psychotherapy, Somatic Experiencing, Authentic Relating, and Nonviolent Communication.


Photo credit: Image by pikisuperstar on Freepik
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Pride In Place: Creating a Community Walk Tour, Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.
Please sign-up here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).
label: Community & Culture

description:
Raumati South Repair Cafe - 21 Sep, Raumati South Repair Cafe - 21 Sep
Got something that needs fixing? Come along to the Raumati South Repair Café on Sunday, 21 Sep where our talented volunteers will help breathe new life into your belongings.

We’re here to fix and advise on:

🧵 Sewing & mending
⚡ Electrical items
💻 IT troubleshooting
🚲 Bicycle maintenance
🌿 Garden tool and knife sharpening
💍 Jewellery repairs
🪡 Sewing machine check-ups
🔧 General repairs (give it a go!)

Enjoy some cake and a cuppa in our cafe while connecting with our amazing community – let’s reduce waste and keep our treasures going strong!

📍 Location: Raumati South Memorial Hall, Tennis Court Road
🕰️ Time: Please arrive before 12:30 so we can make sure our volunteers have enough time to work on your items.

Bring your bits and bobs, and let’s make something old feel new again. See you there!

description:
Richter City Roller Derby vs Sulphur City Steam Rollers Double Header, We’ve got some derby action coming your way on Saturday, 20 September at Kilbirnie Rec Centre – a doubly exciting event with our friends from Sulphur City Steam Rollers!
At 5pm, our B Team will kick the evening off with Sulphur City’s Runaways.
At 7pm, our A Team will be facing off against Sulphur City’s Motley Crew.
Make sure to grab a Karma Drink or Garage Project beer on your way to the stands. We will also have plenty of tasty, homemade food options to keep you fuelled between games!
There will be raffle prizes drawn on the day with goodies from our amazing sponsors at Iko Iko, Rich Coffee and Thunderpants. Huge shout out to Kapinua for their ongoing support.
We’ll see you trackside!

Ticket prices:
Adult - $15
Concession - $12
Under 12s – free

With the help of his best friend (Steve Buscemi) and a beautiful bookstore owner (Salma Hayek), the Mariachi tracks Bucho, takes on his army of desperados, and leaves a trail of blood of his own

description:
Sip & Connect: A Chai-Coffee Morning for the Assam Community – Round Three!!, Nomoskaar Raiz,
Due to popular demand, we’re brewing up another Coffee & Chai Catch-Up! Whether you’re a tea aficionado or a coffee enthusiast, come join us for another round of warm drinks, great company, and even better conversations.
Event Details:
📅 Date: 14th Sep 2025 (Sunday)
⏰ Time: 10:00 AM – 12:00 PM
📍 Locations:
Auckland: Shubh Restaurant and Takeaways, 520-524 Sandringham Road, Sandringham
Wellington: Tandoori Dhaba, 5 Mark Avenue, Paparangi, Wellington
Christchurch: TBA
What to expect:
✨ More lively conversations and lots of laughs
✨ Fresh stories , plus some new coffee & tea puns to keep things brewing
✨ A welcoming space to reconnect and make new friends in our Axomiya community
Please RSVP so we can save your seat and keep the good vibes flowing!
Whether you missed the first catch-up or want to relive the fun, we can’t wait to see you there. Let’s sip, chat, and celebrate our shared love for tea, coffee, and community!
Warm Regards,
Assam Society of New Zealand

description:
Gluten Free Cake Decorating Workshop - with GF high tea!, Gluten Free Cake Decorating Workshop - with GF high tea!
Gluten intolerant/celiac? This one's for you!!

This is not going to be your average cake decorating workshop, not only will you create your own floral wreath cake but you will also enjoy High Tea while you are doing it, an experience filled with joy, creativity and treats and 100% gluten free.

Includes:

*Your own delicious cake to ice and decorate and then take home with you.

*Learn how to create a smooth finish with buttercream icing.

*Learn how to create piped flowers, palette knife leaves and other piped details.

*All the equipment you need to create the Floral Wreath Cake during the class.

*Demo and instruction by me, plus help along the way.

*Yummy treats in High Tea style to eat, plus all the cups of tea you can drink.

*All the prep and cleanup sorted so you just get to do the fun part.

This will be held in my kitchen studio in Lower Hutt.

Cake decorating experience is not needed, all skill levels
welcome.

Please note I am not celiac registered as I do make non GF things in my kitchen but will be doing my best not to cross contaminate, but there is not a guarantee on that.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Vincent Vega Plays Tarintino, A night of surf, soul and rockn'roll bangers from Quentin Tarantino's cult classic films, played with great vengeance & furious anger by Wellingtons favourite surf-rock saviours Vincent Vega. Expect tunes from Pulp Fiction, Reservoir Dogs, Once Upon A Time In Hollywood, The Hateful Eight, Death Proof and more.

Featuring special guests Lisa Tomlins on vocals and Louis TM on keys and vocals, as well as the usual suspects in Richard Te One (drums), Nick Lissette (bass) and Chris Armour (guitar)

Music from 9:30pm FREE ENTRY

description:
Lunch Speaker Series, Noble Rot invites you to enjoy a relaxed lunch in style. While away your afternoon with a leisurely three-course menu as they keep the wine flowing amongst you and your friends. They've lined up two incredible guest speakers at the forefront of the wine industry to entertain you with their stories, knowledge and insights into current trends in a relaxed but intimate atmosphere. You'll wish all learning was done this way. It’s the perfect excuse to treat your friends, your mum or your date.
 
Guest Speakers & Dates:

Saturday 9th — ‘Small Region, Big Sky’
Katherine Jacobs and her husband Jeremy embarked on a dream to produce some of Martinborough’s finest wines from their special vineyard in Te Muna, and they’ve achieved great success! Katherine will speak about upcoming trends, big dreams and hidden secrets in our favourite region’s wine scene.
 
Saturday 23rd — ‘A Rosie Afternoon’ 
Enjoy the company of Rosie Finn of Neudorf Vineyards, second generation of one of New Zealand's most prestigious wineries in Nelson. You’ll have the opportunity to ask Rosie all about current trends as she combines the story of her family winery’s historic roots and its impact on the landscape of New Zealand fine wines.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Site Visit - Studio of Pacific Architecture - Te Aro Double-Header!, Join us on Wednesday 20 August, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of two very different but geographically close projects in Te Aro. The National War Memorial and FPC Martin Square are both undergoing major refurbishment - join us for a look behind the scenes!
National War Memorial: Refurbishing a Wellington Icon
Step behind the scaffolding and witness the National War Memorial Project – a complex seismic strengthening project where heritage sensitivity is of utmost importance. With construction works being carried out by Maycroft Construction, join us for the rare opportunity to explore a significant piece of the capital’s cultural fabric.
Known to many as the backdrop of ANZAC Day commemorations, this national memorial is undergoing a meticulous refurbishment to ensure its legacy endures for generations to come.
 What’s Happening On Site:
Seismic strengthening of the tower and bell frame 
Stone remediation to preserve its historic façade
Asphalt roofing works
The real challenge? Balancing modern engineering with heritage preservation. Every upgrade is being carried out with deep respect for the building’s historical significance.

Then, just around the corner, we will move on to another refurbishment project – at a much different scale and for a very different purpose!
 FPC Martin Square: from Workshop to Office Space
Leading industrial design-and-build specialists First Principles Constructors are celebrating seven years of innovation with a bold move - into a brand-new headquarters in central Wellington. Take a look inside the transformation of a former engineering workshop into the new HQ for FPC. With exposed services, raw materials, and an industrial aesthetic, this compact yet clever refurbishment shows how much can be achieved in a small urban footprint. Construction is well underway by Aoraki Construction, with completion coming up in September.
What’s Happening On Site:
•     Structural steel installation, new roofing, cladding, a new concrete mezzanine slab
•     Interior fit-out works
•     Full building services upgrades
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Wednesday, 20th August, meet at 2.45pm for a 3.00pm start at the National War Memorial
📍 LOCATION: Meet at the National War Memorial (19 Buckle Street) to explore this site first. We will then walk over to 21 Martin Square as a group, for the next site visit.
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 18 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots. (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 🎉 After the site visits, unwind with drinks and nibbles sponsored by First Principles Constructors at a nearby venue (TBC) – a chance to connect, reflect, and chat all things design and construction.
🧡 Huge thanks to Studio of Pacific Architecture, Aoraki Construction, Maycroft Construction, and First Principles Constructors for teaming up to make this event possible.
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Rainbow Elders: Our Aspirations, Our Well-Being, Our Rights - a panel discussion, Rainbow Elders: Our Aspirations, Our Well-Being, Our Rights - a panel discussion
Te Kāhui Tika Tangata Human Rights Commission is proud to host this discussion for International Day of Older Persons in partnership with Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa (formerly LAGANZ).

Panelists from the Wellington rainbow community - 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗶 𝗠𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗹, 𝗞𝗲𝘃𝗶𝗻 𝗛𝗮𝘂𝗻𝘂𝗶 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗟𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘆 𝗖𝗼𝘄𝗮𝗻 - will join Chief Commissioner Dr Stephen Rainbow for the discussion and a brief Q and A session. 🌈🎙️💫

Prudence Walker, Disability Rights Commissioner and Rainbow rights spokesperson will host the panel.

𝗣𝗿𝗲-𝗿𝗲𝗴𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗱𝘂𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝘀𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴. Pre-register here: https://events.humanitix.com/rainbow-elders-our-aspirations-our-well-being-our-rights-a-panel-discussion 🎟️🎟️🎟️

The discussion runs from 10.30am to 11.30am.

NZSL will be available. The venue is accessible.

Light refreshments will be available.

A recording of the discussion may be made available afterwards via the Commission's website.
❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🩷
label: Community & Culture

description:
Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour, Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour
Gather your friends, whānau, or neighbours who might find it tricky to access the gardens, and enjoy a relaxing, self-guided drive through a spectacular spring floral display at Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.

Simply drive along the one-way route past the Display Garden and soak in the colours of tulips, forget-me-nots, dianthus, primulas, chrysanthemums, daffodils, and more.

How it works:
• No registration needed — just turn up and enter through the Glenmore Street gates.
• Follow the designated one-way route through the gardens, keeping within your vehicle at all times.
• Exit through the West/White Gate to return to Glenmore Street.
• Feel free to enjoy the route as many times as you like during opening hours.

Please note:
• Drive slowly (maximum 10 km/h), and watch carefully for pedestrians, especially children.
• Stay in your vehicle for the entire tour to keep everyone safe and comfortable.
• Follow all signage and do not turn around within the garden grounds.

This event is self-guided and unstaffed. If you need assistance during your visit, please call 04 499 1400.
For enquiries, email or call 04 499 1400.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band, Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band
Spring has sprung, the days are getting longer, the rain is falling sideways. Must be about time we had another céilí! Join The Great Beag Céilí Band at St Michael’s Hall in Kelburn for a rousing evening of dancing to foot-stomping celtic tunes. Our Autumn céilí sold out so make sure you get your tickets early!

If you’ve never been to a céilí (or ceilidh) before, fear not - céilí dancing is very easy! No fancy moves or any previous experience required: our caller will explain each dance, and we’ll all walk it through a couple of times before adding the music.

This is social dancing so bring all your friends! No need to bring a specific partner - there’ll be lots of friendly people to dance with.

Discounted online tickets are available on Humanitix until midnight on September 26th: $24 / $16 concession
https://events.humanitix.com/beag-ceili-spring-ceili-2025

Some door sales may be available on the day: $30 / $20 concession (cash only)

—

Doors open 7:30pm

Adults and age 10+ welcome. Under 16s accompanied by an adult.

Light refreshments will be available. We recommend bringing a water bottle to grab a quick drink between dances - hydration is key!
This is an alcohol-free event.

Getting here: St Michael’s Hall is located at 81 Upland Road in Kelburn Village, just behind the church.
There is very limited on-street parking in the village. We recommend public transport: the 4, 18, 21, and 22 buses stop regularly right outside coming up from Te Aro or down from Northland and Karori.

Be safe online: Tickets are only available online from the Humanitix event. Do not buy tickets from other sources such as Facebook comments or resale sites - these are always scams. If you can no longer attend, please contact us via Humanitix, our socials, or email to discuss refunds.

Health notice: Céilí dancing is a great way to meet lots of people. If you are feeling unwell then please stay home and rest this time, we will see you at the next one.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Plants and Human Health - Guided Walk, What are the connections between kōwhai and lung health; tōtara and eye health; yew, flax and cancer suppression; pōhutukawa, koromiko and gut health; and more. In this one-hour downhill walk we will ‘get up close’ to both native and exotic plants to talk about these connections.

Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Matthew Bourne’s Swan Lake – The Legend Returns, We are delighted to share some exciting news – for the very first time in New Zealand, the RNZB Foundation has secured the rights for a special one-off screening of Matthew Bourne’s Swan Lake – The Legend Returns, filmed live at London’s Sadler’s Wells Theatre in 2019.
Matthew Bourne’s groundbreaking Swan Lake offers an exciting reimagining of the traditional ballet loved by millions and it has taken the dance world by storm. Even if you have been fortunate enough to see the live stage performance, this screen version brings another dimension to the ballet - quite simply, it’s breathtaking!
label: Film & Media

description:
Te Wiki o Te Reo Māori ko Marama, Te Wiki o Te Reo Māori ko Marama
Tēnā koutou e te kaingākau ki te reo Māori.
Nau mai, whakapiri mai mo tetahi wiki whakahirahira ki te whare Marama.
Kia kanikani
Kia kai
Kia puku kata
Kia whakarongo ake i te tūī, tūī, tutuiā!
Haeremai me tō whānau katoa!

Celebrate Te Wiki o te Reo Māori with us at Moon. Everything Always have curated a special lineup of some of Aotearoa’s best Indigenous hip-hop, R&B, indie/alt rock, electronic and spoken word artists!
Come dance.
Come eat.
Come laugh.

description:
THREE JOYFUL HOUSES - AOTEAROA FESTIVAL OF ARCHITECTURE - SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER, THREE JOYFUL HOUSES by IAN ATHFIELD
SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER @ FUTUNA CHAPEL - KARORI
Three joyful houses, three families and three client stories about the commissioning, designing, building and living in homes designed by Ian Athfield.
SPENCER and DIANE LOGAN
1974 - 1978
WINDY POINT – EASTBOURNE
Photographer unknown
Spencer Logan and his wife Diane will talk about the commissioning of their first new home, its design, construction, the cleaning of thousands of bricks, and living in this unique collection of a pair of recycled brick towers with timber clad ‘saddlebags’. 
ROSS, CUSHLA and TESS JAMIESON
1974 - 1978
MAHINA BAY
Ross and Cushla have lived in their home on the Eastern hills above Mahina Bay for 48 years. They will, along with their youngest daughter, recount their experiences of working with Ian Athfield in the commissioning of the design of their home, the construction process and then living in this hillside hugging collection of building, and how this home may have influenced their living and the raising of a family of four children.
JONATHAN CUSTANCE   - THE CUSTANCE HOUSE 1981 – 1982
HAVELOCK NORTH
“The Custance House replaced an early modern home that burnt to the ground in 1981 leaving only the swimming pool unscathed.  Ray and Ann Custance, who were friends of the Athfields, sought a bold replacement.  With their son, industrial and interior designer Jonathan Custance, they prepared a four page brief for a new building….. “
Text taken from Athfield Architects by Julia Gatley 2012 AUP.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. 
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when registering for Architect tickets

description:
Tram 17 Inauguration (Fathers Day 2025), Join us at the Wellington Tramway Museum as we put our latest restoration project into active service at the museum!
Tram 17 was built in 1904 by the Wellington City Council Tramways as a four wheeled box (Palace) style tram. By 1917 the system had grown and 17 was rebuilt into its current form adding a set of trucks converting the tram to 8 wheels. Tram tram saw regular service until the 1940’s where it was eventually use for peak time travel, before being withdrawn in the late 50’s.
It was then sold, and taken to Bell road in Raumati on the Kapiti coast where it served as a beach hutt until the 80’s where it was donated to the Wellington tramway museum for display and eventual restoration.
2014 a conservation and restoration plan was put together, and the tram was shipped out to the Wheelwright Shop in the Wairarapa for a full body overhaul. It was transported back to the museum in 2017 and put on public display until new trucks (wheelsets) could be manufacturedby A&G price in Thames.
Since 2019 the tram has undergone new wiring, and extensive testing and running in and is now ready to take passengers along our museum.
Tram 17 is a wonderful achievement by all
Those involved, and we cannot wait to welcome you this Father’s Day to enjoy a ride on this heritage tram, saved from the scrap heap, and then saved again from rotting away.
Please note: We intend to run tram 17, however due to the nature and style of the tram, its operation is weather dependent. If we deem that the tram cannot run, we will advise accordingly.

description:
Voice of Aroha Anniversary Gala 2025, ✨ Experience a Night of Celebration and Impact in Wellington! ✨
Join us at the Voice of Aroha Anniversary Gala on Saturday, November 1st, 2025, for an unforgettable evening of reflection, connection, and aroha. 🎉 Immerse yourself in inspiring stories, captivating performances, and the warmth of community — all while making a real difference in the lives of refugee and migrant communities across Aotearoa.
🌟 Voice of Aroha 6th Anniversary Gala 🌟
For six incredible years, Voice of Aroha has amplified untold voices, empowered youth, and brought people together through storytelling, leadership, and celebration.
💡 This year has been filled with achievements and new opportunities for our young people, but it has also been one of the toughest yet, with limited funding. To keep our mahi alive and ensure our youth continue to thrive, we need your support. Will you stand with us?
🗓️ Date: Saturday, November 1, 2025
🕕 Time: 6:00 PM – 9:00 PM
📍 Location: The Hub, Kelburn Campus (Te Herenga Waka – Victoria University of Wellington)
✨ What to Expect:
🌟 Inspiring youth voices
🌟 Beautiful cultural performances
🌟 Dinner with whānau for a great cause
🌟 Raffle tickets + prizes to be won 🎟️
🌟 A night of aroha, unity & impact
💫 Every ticket is a donation. Your generosity directly supports Voice of Aroha’s ongoing mahi — empowering youth, creating inclusive spaces, and ensuring refugee and migrant voices are heard, valued, and celebrated.
🎟️ Get your ticket today and be part of this milestone celebration! Together, we’ll ensure our mission not only continues but grows stronger, making a lasting difference for generations to come.

description:
GISH: Live, Comedy icon GISH is back with a brand-new show! For over 20 years, GISH has been one of New Zealand’s most beloved comedians, famous for his outrageous parodies that mix six strings with dodgy things. Get ready for a night where no song is safe.

Joining him is Canadian freestyle sensation Jesse Firebrand — a razor-sharp musical comedian who’s been tearing through the Australian scene with lightning-fast improvisation comedy songs. There’s nobody in New Zealand doing what Jesse does, and you’ll see why he’s one to watch.

Your host for the night is Anthony Wilson, an Auckland-based comic and crowd favourite who’s performed across Aotearoa, Australia, and the UK. With quick wit, polished storytelling, and pub-worthy tales, he’ll keep the show rolling. We’ll also have a special guest on the night.

Tickets will go fast. Grab yours now and spread the word!

Stay updated here: facebook.com/ComedyOnTheRocks

description:
Plimmerton Rotary Garden Tour 2025, Join us for a Springtime treat- a tour of ten gardens around the Pauatahanui Harbour.

The gardens are varied, from bijou suburban hideaways to a lifestyle block, and from an 1860s cottage garden to a modern design gem. They are testaments to the care and creativity of their owners.

Included is the iconic Heritage Rose Garden beside St Alban’s church in Pauatahanui, which features legacy and modern rose varieties around the burial ground.

Gardeners will be inspired by the experience - it will be an unforgettable day out.

Times - Gardens are open from 9.30 am to 4.30 pm on both days, except for the Pauatahanui Rose Garden/Burial Ground, which will be closed on Sunday morning until 1 pm.

Garden competition – A prize voted for by entrants for the “Best Garden” for Consultancy Services has been offered by Distinctive Home and Landscapes Limited to the value of $600. Other spot prizes will be drawn at the end of each day for entrants.

Ticket holders:


Note that when ticketing, select the Zone to start at: Camborne, Paremata/Aotea, Whitby, or Pauatahanui.

Preplan your garden tour from the map provided when tickets are issued, and have the plan available on the day.

Note that every effort is made to ensure gardens are as safe as practicable. All gardens are entered at visitors’ risk.

must obtain the garden owner's consent if you wish to take cuttings.

Note that the event will occur wet or fine, pets are not allowed, and no ticket refunds will be available.


This is a Plimmerton Rotary fundraiser for community benefit, and net proceeds will be shared by:


Gillies McIndoe Foundation, founded by Dr Swee Tan, benefits research work in developing accessible life-changing treatment options for brain cancer, vascular birthmarks and keloid scars through the use of affordable repurposed medications. https://www.gmri.org.nz/

“HAROLD” - North Wellington Life Education Trust - visits primary schools with an intriguing mobile classroom, furthering the Education of unique Life Skills for primary school children in the Porirua Johnsonville regions. northwellington@lifeed.org.nz


A special thanks to Titahi Bay Horticultural Society for their early support.

description:
WINTER SERIES: Crop Swap Te Whanganui a Tara X Wellington Timebank, WINTER SERIES: Crop Swap Te Whanganui a Tara X Wellington Timebank
Crop Swap is a FREE heart-warming monthly community gathering to share what we have with each other. Think of it like a community garden potluck when each offering regardless of the amount adds up to a bounty.

Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share🌱

WHEN?
☕ Come along at 10:30am for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free @Peoples coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along.
Swapping kicks off from 11.00am.

WHERE?
You can find us in the community room on the ground floor of block C of the Newtown Park Apartments, 320 Mansfield St, Newtown, Wellington.

IDEAS OF WHAT TO BRING
🧡Bring a friend!
🍪Maybe you like baking?
🍋 Surplus lemons?
🌱excess seedlings
📖 Have garden books or magazines to destash?
🥬Too much silver beet going crazy?
🫘Left over seeds from summer to share?
💐Got some foraged flowers?

Crop Swap is the place for you!
Note; giving isn't necessary but we do welcome koha of help / waiata / pūtea towards costs like room hire / milaka etc.

description:
WSKN Christmas Event / SKISL, WSKN Christmas Event / SKISL
Hi everyone - welcome to the WSKN Christmas SKISL / Paddle to Mana!

On Saturday 13th December we will have a Christmas event on Mana Island, departing Titahi Bay at 10am (so arriving at 9:30) getting to Mana around 10:40, keen ones can do stuff prior to lunch around 12:00, then there might be groups that head back at different time slots, but we can work that out on the day. Return could therefore either be 1:30 or 2:30 with the latest return to Titahi Bay being 3pm.

We've made this event later than the normal SKISL so that it's easier for folks to drive down from Palmerston North, and also because it is a lunch event.

The lawn on Mana is really nice, sheltered and pleasant and there are also good walks. Mana is of course a sanctuary so you must check your boats for any wildlife especially ants that may have gotten in past the hatches. Also we cannot have any fires

Plan B: If weather nukes Mana, we'll try for Green Point or Onehunga Bay in Whitireia Park by driving there.

Plan C: We will postpone to 21 December

description:
Wellington Spring Festival – Government House Garden tour, As part of Wellington's Spring Fetival, explore Government House gardens with the BARK garden team (90 minute tour)

Government House was opened in Newtown in 1910, and its extensive gardens have been in continuous development since then. As part of the Spring Festival, the Government House garden team is offering guided walks through our gardens. Tours will go ahead regardless of weather. Tours will not enter the main house.

Bookings are essential for the free tour. Places are limited: https://gg.govt.nz/government-house/government-house-wellington/government-house-tours/upcoming

Some parts of our grounds are not mobility friendly. Please contact the Visitor Centre direct if you have any questions regarding accessibility.

Groups wanting to organise a garden tour or house tour can email our Visitor Centre team direct: bookings@govthouse.govt.nz

If you have any questions or need more information, please email us at bookings@govthouse.govt.nz, or call us at 04-382-0837. You will receive a reminder email 24 hours before your tour.

description:
You Should Be Dancing - Wellington, You Should Be Dancing - Wellington
You Should Be Dancing is back!

A disco dancing celebration. A boogie wonderland featuring classic tunes groovy enough to make even a statue move. A club night of super danceable disco hits!

If you love disco, or just want to shake your thing and have a great time, this night is for you.

All kinds of nice people are welcome. Dress up or down. Good times will be had on the grooviest dance floor with the most glamorous tunes and the greatest vibe. What have you got to lose?!

If you’re into...Earth, Wind & Fire, The Bee Gees, ABBA, Diana Ross, Cher, Boney M, Donna Summer, Kool and the Gang, Chic, Gloria Gaynor, KC & The Sunshine Band, The Trammps, Sylvester, Sister Sledge, The Nolans, The Jackson 5, Shalamar, Womack & Womack, Ottawan, The Village People, Chaka Khan, Evelyn Champagne King, Patrice Rushen, Silver Convention, Divine, Pointer Sisters, Bohannon, Patrick Cowley, Patrick Hernandez, Eruption, Rose Royce, Giorgio Moroder, Evelyn Thomas, Gwen Guthrie, Anita Ward, The Weather Girls, The Whispers, The O’ Jays, The Brothers Johnson, Candi Staton, Amanda Lear, and more more more...you will love this night.

You Should Be Dancing has a love of disco and dancing. We take great pleasure in getting together with friends, playing the best tunes, forgetting about work for a while and grooving the night away. We love to party and we pull out all the stops to keep the dance floor moving to the music. These events are always outrageous fun, so why not come down and get into it.

description:
Women Loving Women Speed Dating, Celebrate love and connection at our Speed Dating event for women who love women!

This is a unique opportunity to meet amazing women, forge new friendships, and discover potential romantic connections in a warm, inclusive, and supportive atmosphere.
We have the use of a private function space upstairs.

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little. You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

Our event is designed to respect all boundaries and foster open, honest communication. Not everyone you meet will be your type, but we expect you to be polite. You only have to chat to them for seven minutes!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Ludovico Einaudi, His music has been performed live on an Arctic ice-floe and as soundtracks for Oscar and Golden Globe-winning films. Italian pianist and composer Ludovico Einaudi is returning to Wellington with a new album to explore with audiences. The Michael Fowler Centre will be filled with Ludovico’s special mix of neo-classical, pop, ambient, rock, and experimental styles. His modern soundscapes are renowned for being able to cross artistic and generational boundaries. Because of this, he has become one of the world’s most-streamed classical music artists. 
Ludovico began composing in the 1980s for theatre and ballet. He has since gone on to write for film and television and produce multi-million-selling albums. His most recent is ‘The Summer Portraits’. Written in 2025, it is the result of a cascade of personal memories triggered by sun, summer, and family holidays. Here, he returns to the lush full-band textures of earlier works. You’ll get to hear this first-hand, so don’t miss your chance.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Procurement & Contract Myths – The Good, The Bad & The Ugly., Procurement & Contract Myths – The Good, The Bad & The Ugly.
At MOX, we're a small, family-run business based in beautiful Aotearoa, New Zealand. Founded and led by two partners who've shared life's journey for over 25 years, we bring a unique blend of personal commitment and professional expertise to every interaction.

We're not your typical consultants. Instead, we're hands-on experts in procurement and contract management, driven by a desire to create real, lasting change. Our mission is to empower businesses of all sizes, helping you secure the best deals, avoid pitfalls, and gain the kind of commercial protection usually reserved for the big players. We believe in enabling your success by ensuring your contracts and purchasing processes truly work for you.

Procurement & Contract Myths – The Good, The Bad & The Ugly.

Procurement Case Studies - The Bad: How things can go wrong and cost you $$$.
Contract Myth Busting - The Ugly: Why we should embrace contracts; they aren’t “ugly”.
Best Practice - The Good: How good procurement & contracts will “save the day” and protect your business.
Contract Counselling: Tell us about your “bad(s)”. We will guide you on how you can make it “good”.
We have an amazing new innovation that we want to introduce at the session (during the Best Practice part) called Kitset Contract. Kitset Contract is going to empower sole traders & small to medium sized enterprises to truly be able to create and use their own contracts; Allowing them to better protect their business and their hard earned $$$.

Everyone who attends the session will receive a discount code meaning their first contract will be only $49.99 (a $100 discount).

RSVP Here: https://www.kapitichamber.org.nz/events#!event/2025/8/5/l-d-procurement-contract-myths-8211-the-good-the-bad-the-ugly

description:
2025 Annual South Coast Cleanup, Welcome to the 16th annual South Coast Cleanup, 10:30AM-12:00PM 13th September 2025.
As well as caring for our coasts and oceans, it’s all about community! Join us at any of our cleanup locations for a morning of litter collection and family fun.

WHEN
We kick off at 10:30am on the 13 September. We host clean up sites at 12 locations between Owhiro Bay to Breaker Bay on the Wellington South Coast. All rubbish will be gathered up around 12.15pm and taken to Lyall Bay by the playground to form one huge rubbish mountain that will be collected by the council.

Pitch in for a rubbish pile up at 12:30 at Lyall Bay playground where we will mound up our rubbish and admire our collective efforts! Then we will head to Parrotdog for a drink / kai after!

WHERE
Our fantastic friendly volunteer groups will be scattered along the coastline between Owhiro Bay and Breaker Bay. You can turn up at any of our volunteer sites:

Site 1 - Owhiro Bay hosted by Project Jonah
Site 2 - Dive Wellington hosted by Dive Wellington
Site 3 - Island Bay West hosted by Mountains to Sea and Island Bay Residents Association
Site 4 - Island Bay Snorkel Trail hosted by Friends of Taputeranga
Site 5 - Houghton Bay hosted by Houghton Valley School
Site 6 - Te Raekkaihau Point hosted by Ghost Diving
Site 7 - Lyall Bay West hosted by Underwater Club Wellington
Site 8 - Lyall Bay Central hosted by Lyall Bay Coastal Care
Site 9 - Lyall Bay East hosted by Earth Science NZ (formerly NIWA)
Site 10 - Moa Point hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 11 - Tarakena Bay hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 12 - Breaker Bay hosted by Breaker Bay Residents Association

description:
Jonathan Kay - Massey University Lecturer/Master of Fine Arts Coordinator, Jonathan Kay is a photographic artist, researcher, and lecturer based at Massey University in Te Whanganui-a-Tara/Wellington. His work explores the intersection of art and science, using photography to reveal the unseen and challenge conventional notions of landscape. Over the past seven years, his research has focused on developing a site-specific and responsive approach to photographic interventions within the landscape.
Drawing inspiration from scientific 'fieldwork,' Kay’s practice involves close observation and data collection, using these methods to uncover new insights into specific environments. However, his approach extends beyond the typical scientific framework by leveraging the unique possibilities of the photographic medium. This process enables him to move beyond the traditional, idealized representation of landscapes, offering deeper, more complex interpretations.
September 25, Tararua Tramping Club (4 Moncrieff St, Mt Victoria), Doors Open at 7pm
If you’re curious about the Wellington Photographic Society, you’re welcome to attend two meetings for free before deciding whether to join. It’s a great way to meet the community and see what we’re all about!
https://wps.wps.org.nz/

description:
Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Botany Tours for Conservation Week at Te Papa, Come behind the scenes to visit the Botany collection which houses more than 300,000 plant specimens collected in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.
There are two tours available:
Tuesday 2nd September BOH 11.30 – 12.30pm
Thursday 4th September BOH 3.30 – 4.30PM
You will find out how we store and take care of these valuable collections, and the research they support. There will be a chance to see our precious botanical taonga, including botanical specimens and art, and have a closer look at the very first plants collected by the European naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander over 250 years ago during Captain James Cook’s first voyage to New Zealand.

description:
Community Planting Belmont Regional Park, Help us reforest the hills of Belmont Regional Park. By planting native trees and shrubs, we will restore the native ngahere/forests and create an ecological corridor for wildlife to travel between Wellington, Porirua, Kāpiti and the Hutt Valley.

We have partnered with GWRC, PCC, and local iwi to restore the hills of Belmont Park. Starting on the west hillside, our aim this year is to plant 5,000 native plants to create a forest for the future! This project aims to bring the community together to restore the hillsides of the Belmont Regional Park.

We provide all the tools and training, no prior experience needed. We can even provide transport to the site. Just bring your energy and lunch. We will provide you with a yummy morning tea.

Come have some fun planting with us and TAKE ACTION FOR NATURE!

This event is part of Conservation Week 2025 - www.doc.govt.nz/conservationweek

Sign up for this event on our website ConservationVolunteers.co.nz or email Wellington@cvnz.org.nz

description:
Denniston - a place worth fighting for., The Denniston Plateau is one of Aotearoa's most unique landscapes and is rated by the Department of Conservation as a key ecologically valuable site. It is a unique ‘lost world’ ecosystem home to a remarkable array of life. A fast-track application to mine 20-million tonnes of coal in the area is expected to be filed this year.
Join us for an engaging session to:
Hear from experts about Denniston Plateau’s extraordinary biodiversity and ecology.
View a photo exhibition by West Coast photographer Neil Silverwood capturing the Plateau’s beauty.
Learn about the proposal to expand coal mining in the area
Wine, beer and appetisers are provided. You may be asked to show proof of identity upon arrival.

description:
Artistic Potential: Marine Reserves - A presentation/talk, A presentation and talk facilitated by Katy Cottrell, Matteo Collina and Alice Rogers.
Marine Reserves have obvious benefits to the environment, protecting species and providing underwater appeal to snorkelers and divers but a little realised benefit is what they can offer to artists of all mediums. Join artist Katy Cottrell as she chats with academic researcher Matteo Collina and director of the Victoria University Coastal Ecology Lab – Alice Rogers. Alice and Matteo will talk about their work with marine reserves from a scientific perspective and how this has inspired the artworks by Katy Cottrell and Rick Allender for their exhibition Taputeranga: Above and Below.

description:
Destination Earth, Expect your senses to be stirred in a new art installation. Destination Earth aims to inspire climate action through art. It incorporates satellite data, real-time generative music, and responds to audience movement in real-time. Using video and immersive sound, audiences will be challenged to reconsider the rhythm of living as humans. 
You are invited to dive into the flow of the Southern Ocean and explore the pulse of the Antarctic circumpolar current. Participate by adjusting your walking patterns and breathing to ‘regenerate’ the world around you. Motion sensors will pick up your activity and adjust the environment to suit. At a sensorial level the effects of climate change will come to life. 

Destination Earth is a collaboration between Cellule Studio (UK) and Victoria University of Wellington. The work, by artist Salome Bazin, mixes art, science, and technology. It emphasises the urgent need to slow down human activity.  

A bi-cultural perspective is also central to the experience. Māori symbolic views of the ocean are included, offering a richer narrative of the global climate.
 
Image credit: Cellule Studio, directed by Salomé Bazin.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures, Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures
📅 Wednesday, 1 October 2025
🕔 5:00–7:30 PM (Networking from 5:00 PM | Panels 5:30–7:30 PM)
📍 Te Aro Campus, Faculty of Architecture and Design Innovation, Victoria University of Wellington (139 Vivian Street)
The built environment is at the heart of Aotearoa’s response to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals SDGs). The way we plan, design, and construct our cities influences how we live — and how we tackle challenges such as climate change (SDG 13), sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11), affordable housing and equity (SDG 10),
responsible consumption and production (SDG 12), and partnerships for action (SDG 17).
This event is part of SDG Action Month 2025, a global campaign that highlights how communities, institutions, and industries are accelerating progress toward the 2030 Agenda.
For Aotearoa, the conversation is urgent: how can planning, design, and construction shape a sustainable, equitable, and climate-resilient future?
The evening will open with a keynote address that sets the stage with global perspectives on sustainability and the role of the built environment in achieving the SDGs.
Two panels will then explore critical themes:
• Planning + Place + People — equity, housing futures, cultural identity, indigenous leadership, and policy alignment.
• Materials + Methods + Innovation—construction technology, green standards, digital tools, and carbon-conscious practice.
Alongside the discussions, attendees can view a Student Showcase from the School of Architecture and the School of Design Innovation, and contribute to a Blueprint Wall by writing their own pledges on SDG Commitment Cards, ensuring the event concludes with collective action as well as ideas.
📌 Free to attend | Open to all | RSVP required
label: Conservation & Environment
