description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

A wonderful range of exhibitors, 'Ask an Expert' sessions, latest trends, innovations and exclusive show specials it’s the place to be for inspiration for indoors and out.
For more information visit homeandgardenshow.co.nz or 'Like us' on Facebook.
We are working very hard to keep our events safe and we ask that you please stay home if you are unwell.
Show opening hours: Friday & Saturday 10-5pm, Sunday 10-4pm
FAQs
1. What are my transport/parking options for getting to and from the event?
Parking is available at the venue, at a cost of $10. Please note parking is card payment only (entry to the Show is card or cash).
2. What is the best time to attend?
Peak visitor times are normally between 11am - 2pm so the crowds are less outside of these times.
3. What days is the ticket valid for?
General Admission entry tickets is for one entry only and is valid for any one of the 3 event days.
Gold Card Special 1/2 price tickets valid for Friday only.
4. Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event?
A printed ticket or showing the barcode on your phone to the entry staff is required.

description:
Field trip: Innes Bush, Field trip: Innes Bush
Botanise a 38-hectare area of covenanted native bush, one of the largest private areas of protected conservation land close to Wellington. See 80-year-old regenerating bush, with large rimu and beech trees that were spared from historic felling. Also kāmahi on the higher areas and relict rimu, tōtara, miro and large black beech with a preponderance of kiekie/Freycinetia banksii on the wet gully floor and lower contours. Further information here: https://qeiinationaltrust.org.nz/newprotectioninwainuiomata/

Meet: 9.30 a.m. at 353 Moores Valley Rd. Travel via Wainuiomata Rd to intersection with Main Rd, next to Moores Valley Rd turn-off, then to end of road to no. 353.

Co-leaders: Laura Girvan-West 021 583 934/; Paul Bell-Butler .
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Stitch a Still Life, Create your own A4 size Still Life with a vase or a bowl containing three dimensional flowers, fruit and /or leaves.
Linen fabric will be available in a range of colours for you to create your own background textured with simple stitches.
A bowl or vase for your flowers and fruit will be appliqued.
Some threads and fabrics will be provided but if you have something special you would like to incorporate into the Still Life you are welcome to bring it along and we can discuss how to best use it. For example, the bowl for the cherries is from an old, embroidered doily and the cherries are red velvet. A piece of lace may look good on the table.
You may not finish completely, but you will have been taught and practised each step.
Advice and options for finishing your piece of work for display will be given.
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Friends AGM with guest speakers, Join the Friends of Wellington Botanic Garden for our Annual General Meeting and a pair of inspiring botanical presentations. You don’t have to be a member to attend — everyone’s invited!
Programme
Each presentation is 30 minutes, with time for questions.
Paul Bell-Butler
Botanist and PhD candidate, Paul is delving into the hidden world of leafy liverworts (family Lophocoleaceae). His research combines modern molecular techniques with traditional botany to reveal how these overlooked plants shape ecosystems and influence seed germination.
Clare Shearman
Plant Collection Team Manager at Wellington Botanic Garden, Clare brings a career spanning historic English estates to iconic New Zealand gardens. Fresh from the prestigious Longwood Gardens Fellows program in the USA, she shares insights into garden design, conservation, and how public gardens nurture wellbeing and connection.
Come along to hear their stories, celebrate our beautiful gardens, and meet fellow plant enthusiasts.
Located in the Treehouse Seminar Room, Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.
For more info about the Friends: https://friendsofthewellingtonbotanic.wordpress.com/
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Denniston - a place worth fighting for., The Denniston Plateau is one of Aotearoa's most unique landscapes and is rated by the Department of Conservation as a key ecologically valuable site. It is a unique ‘lost world’ ecosystem home to a remarkable array of life. A fast-track application to mine 20-million tonnes of coal in the area is expected to be filed this year.
Join us for an engaging session to:
Hear from experts about Denniston Plateau’s extraordinary biodiversity and ecology.
View a photo exhibition by West Coast photographer Neil Silverwood capturing the Plateau’s beauty.
Learn about the proposal to expand coal mining in the area
Wine, beer and appetisers are provided. You may be asked to show proof of identity upon arrival.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
2025 Mini-Wellycon, It's the small version of NZ's biggest board game convention - that means less distractions and more time playing games.
Labour Weekend - 25th & 26th October 2025. Tickets on sale 12th September 2025.
As well as a vast array of games to play in the central library (brought along by attendees), there's giveaways, Play-to-Win prizes, buy/sell table and friendly volunteers to help you choose something you'll like.
Tickets from: Adults $30.00, Children $15.00
Building Community through Games

description: Psychology of Parenting: A Seminar, A seminar on the psychology of parenting. Explore the latest research on child development, parenting styles, and effective communication to raise happy, healthy, and resilient children. This seminar is for parents and caregivers of all levels.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration Navigating Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Perspective, f🌍 Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration
Hosted by UNANZ Wellington in partnership with the British High Commission, Wellington
Join us for an engaging evening of insight and diplomacy as we explore how the United Kingdom, New Zealand, and the United Nations are working together to drive global climate leadership.
This timely event brings together perspectives on international cooperation, policy innovation, and the urgent challenges of our climate future. John Pearson, Deputy British High Commissioner at the British High Commission, will deliver a keynote speech followed by an open Q&A, offering a unique chance for attendees to ask questions and be part of the conversation.
Whether you're passionate about sustainability, international relations, or meaningful dialogue, this event offers value, inspiration, and connection.
Why attend?
Learn about climate diplomacy in action
Engage with leaders shaping global climate responses
Network with professionals, students, and changemakers
Enjoy light refreshments in a diplomatic setting
🗓️ Date: Tuesday, 26 August 2025
🕔 Time: 5:00 PM – 6:30 PM
📍 Venue: British High Commission, Wellington
🎟️ RSVP Required – Limited Spaces
Networking Reception: From 6:30 pm with canapes and drinks kindly sponsored by the British High Commission.
FOR ANY DIETARY:
Please email us at ishant.ghulyani@unanz.org.nz
Don't miss this opportunity to be part of a global conversation, right here in Wellington.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Hōkai Tahi Winter Woodlands Pizza Evening, We’re inviting you to a cozy night out with heart.
Our Winter Woodlands Pizza Evening is a special fundraiser supporting Hōkai Tahi.
Based in the Wairarapa, Hōkai Tahi walks alongside women and whānau through pregnancy, baby loss, and the early years of parenting - offering time, space, and resources when they are needed most.
Indulge in a delicious 3-course meal (wood-fired pizza included, of course!) with non-alcoholic drinks provided.
A limited bar menu will be available, or feel free to BYO.
Alongside your meal, enjoy live music, a live auction of locally donated treasures, and for those feeling adventurous, a short glow worm walk through the native bush (don’t forget your torch, sturdy shoes, and warm layers - hot water bottles welcome!).
Details:
Watermill Bakery, 33 Blakes Road, Mt Holdsworth
Saturday 1st November 2025
5:30–8:30pm
$75 per adult - $20 per child (under 14)
Look out for our friendly parking warden in hi-vis on arrival and simply give your name to be guided in.
Please note there’s no reception at the venue, so make any arrangements before you head our way.
Share an evening of great food, live entertainment, and woodland magic - all in support of a truly worthwhile cause.
Every ticket sold helps Hōkai Tahi continue supporting local whānau through life’s most tender moments.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Tami Neilson in Wellington, Tami Neilson in Wellington

🎤 Catch Tami Neilson Live at The Opera House Wellington on Friday, October 3, 2025! 🎤
Ready to experience the night of your life? Tami Neilson is bringing their infectious energy and hit songs like You Were Mine, Walk (Back to Your Arms) and Sandy Cheeks Theme to The Opera House Wellington on Friday, October 3, 2025, and it's going to be one for the ages. With 34.3K+ fans behind them, this concert is set to blow the roof off.

Multiple shows may be on the agenda, but this one is the talk of the town. Be ready to sing, dance, and feel all the feels as Tami Neilson takes you on a musical journey.

Event Rundown:

📅 Date: Friday, October 3, 2025
⏰ Time: 8:00 PM
📍 Venue: The Opera House Wellington

Performing their biggest hits and some surprises that will only happen live, this concert will be the talk of your group chat for weeks.

Why You Have to Be There
Tami Neilson has 304K+ monthly listeners, and their viral singles are dominating every playlist. Now's your chance to catch them live and see why the world is obsessed.

🎟️ Get Your Tickets Before They Sell Out! 🎟️
Tickets for Tami Neilson in Wellington are going fast. Don't be the one who hears about it later—grab yours now and be part of an unforgettable night!
label: Music & Concerts

description:
The Wellington Calling Open Mic: Daylight Savings Theme!, Wellington's premier event venue Whisky and Wood is hosting its 5th open mic event: Wellington Calling and we're looking for diverse acts to contribute!

Our last event event had 15 performers and we want you to contribute to the next!

Each performer gets the chance to have a six- minute set with a microphone, guitar and keyboard provided.

This is an originals only event. We want to encourage new creative voices to be heard.

“We want to provide a positive and encouraging environment for established and fledgling acts to shine in. It's a pretty inspiring place to perform,” says host Steven Hood.

Each performer will need to sign up in person before 7pm and registrations of interest need to be emailed to openwandw@gmail.com before May 25.

The feature act is Mustang a upcoming three-piece with dreamy harmonies. Their songs are emotional tributes to clarity, light and wonder. Expect to be moved!

Their music can be heard at: https://www.instagram.com/mustang_band24/

Entry is with Koha.

Light food and drinks will be available to purchase.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to assist you with repairs such as missing buttons, tears, holes and hemming. We will supply a selection of patches and buttons, but you are also welcome to bring your own if you have something specific in mind.

description:
Kai Sovereignty - Parihaka's Maara Kai and Growing for Communities, Climate and Community Activist Tuhi-ao Bailey will talk about Parihaka’s steps towards kai sovereignty, their award winning māra kai and planning a papakāinga to be resilient in the face of Climate Change.
This will be followed by an action-focused discussion led by chef and grower Mara Masarotti on how to connect urban growers with spaces to grow kai at scale.

Kid Friendly!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
String Bean Puppets: Once In a Full Moon, Be captivated these school holidays by the gorgeous puppet show, Once in a Full Moon, performed by Anna Bailey of String Bean Puppets.

Deep in the bush, a lonely kiwi looks up at the sky and mistakes the full moon for a giant egg. Can kiwis fly? Can moons fall from the sky? Can wishes come true? This magical string puppet adventure introduces the audience to an intimate encounter with a few of Aotearoa New Zealand's special native creatures.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Manu Park Site Viewing, Manu Park Site Viewing
Meet us and find out how you can build your dream home in a new subdivision that combines outstanding natural beauty and a real sense of community.
The agent is on-site at the end of Karuhiruhi Street every Sunday between 10.00am - 11.00am.
Since its establishment in 2018, Manu Park has become a highly sought-after community, with Stages One and Two fully sold out. Don’t miss your chance to secure a piece of this paradise in Stage 3, where only 8 sections remain.
Manu Park isn’t just a place to live—it’s a place to belong. Designed with families in mind, it offers a safe and welcoming environment where kids can ride their bikes down quiet streets, explore nature on their doorstep, and grow up knowing their neighbours. Centrally located near Waikanae township it offers expansive open spaces and a strong sense of community; Manu Park is a neighbourhood where friendships flourish and families thrive.
Nestled within protected native bush, Manu Park offers breathtaking surroundings, generously sized sections, and the opportunity to build a home tailored to your vision and lifestyle. Named after the Māori word for bird, it sits beside the renowned Nga Manu Nature Reserve, close to Waikanae’s excellent schools and amenities, just minutes from the beach, and under an hour from Wellington city.
Teaming up with local building companies, Manu Park offers House and Land packages for a seamless home-building experience. Visit Manu Park to explore Design and Build opportunities to create a home that perfectly fits your lifestyle.
Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a vibrant community where nature and modern living come together. Visit manupark.nz to learn more and secure your section today
label: Conservation & Environment

Enjoy browsing this market dedicated to the darker side in honour of Halloween.

description:
PEPEKE meeting - Channels to advocate for invertebrates, The topic is “Channels to advocate for invertebrates”, which we hope to include into our program more often.
We will kick this off with talented Massey students:
India Lindsay (concept art designer) will talk about her board game “Entopia”, a clever game about adaptations and invasive species.
Em Flux will also demonstrate her passion for invertebrates using video installations.
Followed by an activity, where you can get creative as well.
Topic: Pepeke
Time: Aug 27, 2025 07:00 PM Auckland, Wellington
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/84862084139...
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Our Beloved Indigenous Vegetation - Guided Walk, In this approximately one-hour downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on several native plants from the ubiquitous, such as our well-known cabbage tree, kōwhai and podocarps, to lesser-knowns such as shrubby toroaro/mingimingi, Bartlett's rātā, Three Kings kaikōmako and Three Kings vine/akapukaea. We will also discuss the phenomenon of species radiation exemplified by Hebe and Kauri.

Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.

Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Plants for Health and Healing - Part 1 - Guided Walk, Join the Friends of the Garden to discover some of the herbal and medicinal properties of plants in the Main Garden area this is a 60-minute walk.
Meet at the Duck Pond in the Main Garden
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.
This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefit
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
October Just Sew, Join us for our Just Sew - October edition!

Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life – and learn new skills along the way.

Book online and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.

These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.

Bookings are prioritised, but we will do our best to fit in walk-ins if there’s space.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate, Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate
Landfills are designed to last 1,000 years! In this chaotic time of consumerism and climate change, we are facing some big challenges that we need to start facing head on! You can do nothing, and nothing will change, or you can be an imperative cog in the machine that works towards a healthier planet. If you want a place to start your waste minimisation journey or even want to reinforce what you already know, then this 2-hour seminar is for you!

Why join us? You will:

LEARN about what happens to our waste once it leaves the curbside.
ACQUIRE tips/tricks and life hacks that will help you deal with/manage your waste better.
BE CHALLENGED to reduce your waste.

Don't miss out on this opportunity full of witty humor, reality checks, and encouragement that may also challenge your thinking around trash! Secure your spot in this 2-hour seminar today by buying a ticket.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Plants for Health and Healing - Part 2 - Guided Walk, On this walk we continue our exploration of the herbal and medicinal properties of plants.

Meet at the Herb Garden Lookout for this 60-minute walk.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
Big Christmas Spectacular, Is that the sound of Santa’s sleigh? The familiar jingle of bells will be accompanied by live music, dance, and humour at a huge yuletide celebration. The Big Christmas Spectacular makes its Wellington debut at The Opera House in December. What better way to kick start the holiday season than a live show? There will be ballet, contemporary, tap, jazz, and stunning chorus lines. Award-winning musical theatre stars will collaborate with 25 dazzling dancers and live musicians. Together, they’ll transport you to a winter wonderland. 
Christmas jingles, hilarious comedy moments, and world-class show dancing make this perfect for all ages.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Reimagining Construction: Participatory, Circular, and Open by Design, This presentation examines how the principles of participatory, circular, and open design can transform construction by bringing human and ecological values into the heart of how we build.
Drawing from both ancient timber framing traditions and modern innovations, it demonstrates how modularity and standardisation unlock flexibility, efficiency, and customisation while supporting sustainable, locally-rooted solutions.
A key focus is placed on design for disassembly and reassembly, enabling buildings and their components to be reused and adapted over time—reducing waste, lowering environmental impact, and fostering resilience for current and future communities.
label: Conservation & Environment

description: Pukehuia Park - NZ Clean Up, Join us for a rubbish pick-up to Keep New Zealand Beautiful during Clean Up Week 2025. We'll be working in Pukehuia Park from 1pm - 3pm on Sunday 21 September. All welcome. Gloves and rubbish bags provided.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Resilient Waters: NZ–German Conference, Strengthening Urban Water Systems Against Extreme Weather – German Insights for Aotearoa

New Zealand’s water infrastructure is under growing pressure from climate change, ageing systems, and extreme weather events. Ensuring safe drinking water, reliable wastewater management, and resilient infrastructure requires fresh thinking and innovative solutions.
The Resilient Waters Conference, hosted by the German-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce (GNZCC), will bring together German innovators and New Zealand stakeholders for a high-level forum dedicated to future-proofing New Zealand’s water systems.
At this conference, a delegation of German companies will present cutting-edge technologies and intelligent system solutions designed to improve water resilience in the face of climate change. The programme will feature expert presentations, sector-specific insights, and networking opportunities with a professional audience from water utilities, engineering firms, city councils, and decision-making bodies.
Following the conference, the programme for the delegation will continue with B2B meetings, expert roundtables, and site visits in Wellington, Hawke’s Bay, and Auckland from 17–21 November 2025. These tailored sessions will connect German companies directly with New Zealand stakeholders to exchange knowledge, explore collaboration, and identify concrete opportunities for partnership.
 This initiative is organised by the German-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce (GNZCC) in collaboration with German partner AHP International and funded by the German Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWE).
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Pre Loved Women's Clothing Sale - Fundraiser, Our pre-loved women's clothing sale have been such a hit, we are bringing it to Lower Hutt for the first time!

Our amazing volunteers have been hard at work finding some fantastic pre-loved clothes for a fashionable fundraiser- with a difference!
Not only are you doing your bit for the environment by not sending clothes to the landfill, but the funds raised go towards making a real difference in the lives of the children at the Children's Home.

Come along to the sale and pick up some great bargains- it's a win-win-win situation!

Please share with your networks based in Wellington.

Check out our website for more information about the charity. www.karunai-illam.org
label: Conservation & Environment

description: Sermon Series: The Parables of Jesus, A sermon series exploring the parables of Jesus Christ and their timeless wisdom. Each week, we will delve into a different parable and uncover its meaning for our lives today. This series is suitable for all ages and levels of faith, and will provide practical insights for living a more Christ-like life. All are welcome.
label: Religion & Spirituality

description:
The Lighthouse Trio at The Pito-one Depot, The Lighthouse Trio at The Pito-one Depot
Join us as we explore some new interpretations of familiar melodies and unheard compositions! The trio will play original arrangements of favourite tunes as well as come brand new original songs. Expect mysterious ballads, soulful blues, and exhilarating bop.

The Lighthouse Trio is made up of three of Wellington's busiest players; Alex Trask, Jeremy Grant, and Elijah Mulheron. Alex is a highly regarded alto saxophonist who is seen all around town leading bands and playing for some of the leading musical organisations, including the RNZAF band and formerly the Rodger Fox Big Band. Elijah is the busiest bassist in town and often appears with Wellington legends such as Callum Allardice and John Rae. Jeremy is an extremely captivating guitarist and the creative force behind the arrangements you will hear.

The trio is celebrating the release of their debut EP with a tour of their own backyard, playing for the first time in Pito-one and Raumati, and finishing with a gig in central Wellington. Come along for an evening of fresh music presented in a relaxed setting, we hope to see you there!

Door sales available for $20
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Scaling Sustainably with Brianne West, founder of Ethique and Incrediballs, Part of the Pegasus Startup World Cup and Sustainable Spring Series
 Globally recognised environmentalist and entrepreneur, Brianne West, redefined industry norms with her bold vision and innovation, transforming a kitchen experiment in Christchurch into a global beauty revolution.
Ethique was the world’s first zero-waste beauty brand and named in Time Magazine’s Best inventions of 2020. It expanded rapidly, saving millions of plastic bottles from landfill in over 20 countries.
Brianne has won many awards including being an Obama Foundation Leader (AsiaPac), Exporter of the Year (American Chamber of Commerce), and NZ EY Young Entrepreneur of the Year, and was a finalist in the 2024 Kiwibank New Zealand Innovator of the year award.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her incredible journey on scaling, and later exiting a purpose driven, sustainable business. Learn about her current venture, Incrediballs which is set to disrupt the beverage industry, and gain practical insights on how to enter new markets while remaining true to your values.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her remarkable journey of scaling - and ultimately exiting, a purpose-driven, sustainable business. She’ll introduce her latest venture, Incrediballs, poised to disrupt the beverage industry, while offering practical insights on breaking into new markets without compromising your values.
Brianne West is a judge for the Pegasus Startup World Cup held on 9 October 2025 at Te Raukura ki Kāpiti. Learn more and book a ticket to the Pegasus Startup World Cup here.
Snacks provided, if you would like to order a coffee, please arrive earlier to avoid noise.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Sustainable Spring - Pizza Box Solar Oven, Sustainable Spring - Pizza Box Solar Oven
The Department of Conservation has launched a nationwide call to...
Always Be Naturing
Encouraging all of us to connect with and give back to nature.
At Ngā Manu, we couldn’t agree more! These school holidays, your whānau can discover how fun and easy it is to Always Be Naturing:

PLAN YOUR ADVENTURE

Plus, throughout the holidays, your whānau can enjoy daily Lil’ Explorer Trail, eel feeding, Native Bird Close Encounters, and the Kiwi Night Encounter - all experiences that bring the concept of “naturing” to life.

MAKE YOUR OWN SOLAR OVEN
Thursday 2nd October (Tickets $5)
Discover the magic of the sun’s energy and build a simple solar cooker to take home—an inspiring blend of science, sustainability, and fun just before Summer!

Note: Ticket prices do not include entry to the reserve but we invite you to enjoy half price entry with every ticket sold.
label: Conservation & Environment

Roll for Hope 2025, A tabletop roleplaying games event, all proceeds will go to Make-A-Wish. Please visit our website for more information on games and times - https://rollforhope.nz
With a range of games including Dungeons & Dragons, Savage Worlds, Pirate Borg, Paranoia, homegrown games, playtests, and more, there's sure to be something for everyone.
The doors will open at 9.30am, with the first session starting at 10am. There will be three sessions of games in a variety of systems and genres; 10am-1pm, 2-5pm, and 6.15-9.15pm, Book for anywhere between 1-3 sessions for $8 per session, with a 20% discount if you book all three.
A survey link will be emailed closer to the event for attendees to rank their game preference so that we can assign people to games, check spam if you don't receive the email.

description:
Te Aro Zero Waste Just Sew Repair Cafe, Repairing rather than buying is a great way to take climate action in your own life - and learn new skills along the way!
Book through our website and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight items for repair to our September Just Sew!
Our skilled volunteers will be here to assist you with repairs such as missing buttons, tears, holes and hemming. We will supply a selection of patches and buttons, but you are also welcome to bring your own if you have something specific in mind.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion, Step into the colourful, buzzing world of pollination! Join the Wellington Gardens Education Team for a day of hands-on fun exploring how plants and pollinators work together to keep nature thriving.

Meet the Beekeepers – Learn how bees keep the hive running, why they’re super pollinators, and try on real beekeeper gear
Sensory Pollination Play Station – Transfer “pollen” between flowers in a fun sensory tray
Outdoor Pollinator Bingo Trail – Explore the gardens to spot different pollinators
Wind Pollination Station – Make mini fans and paper “pollen” to see how the wind carries pollen from one plant to another

Bring the whānau, follow the buzz, and leave with a new appreciation for the small creatures (and breezes!) that make big things happen.
label: Conservation & Environment

description: August Walk and Weed, Come and help support the local awa, and water quality for the harbour. We are weeding around local planting to ensure they survive, and picking up rubbish in and around the awa. Meet at Dimmock st side of Onepoto park. We have rubbish grabbers and bags, bring gumboots and gloves. Walk and weeds are the last Sunday of every month.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
The Power of Community - Dr Amanda Cahill, "What does it take for communities to lead the renewable energy transition - not just be consulted?"
If one person is positioned well to respond to that question, it is Dr Amanda Cahill.
Goodlife Collective, Sustainability Trust and WEAll Aotearoa are proud to be co-hosting Dr Amanda Cahill, founder of The Next Economy
Don't miss this opportunity to hear Amanda's insights from her work in Australia, which demonstrate how acting on climate change can help catalyse fairer, more regenerative wellbeing economies.
Amanda has worked at the intersection of government, local councils, big companies and communities for 30 years, to support communities to transition to a thriving future.
Amanda is the Founder of The Next Economy, where she supports regional communities across Australia to manage the impacts of decarbonisation and climate change in a way that builds more equitable and regenerative economies. Most of this work has been in coal and industrial regions, where she has brought together government, industry, workers and community groups to co-design transition strategies despite deep-seated tensions. Her work draws on 30 years’ experience working with changemakers across the world to address economic and health inequalities, environmental degradation, women’s rights and climate justice.
Event Programme:
5:15pm - doors open, drinks & nibbles
5:45pm - Welcome & Introduction
6:00-6:30pm - Talk from Dr Amanda Cahill
6:40 - Dialogues & Q&A
7:00(ish!): Networking

About Sustainability Trust: Sustainability Trust are your local experts in sustainability, healthy homes, ethical electricity and supporting our local communities.
About WEAll Aotearoa: WEAll Aotearoa is a non-partisan and independent ‘think and do’ tank working to redesign Aotearoa New Zealand’s economy around the wellbeing of our people and te taiao. WEAll use an evidence-informed approach and focus upstream to develop practical, long-term solutions for the public good.

About Goodlife Collective: Goodlife Collective designs and delivers events and experiences to build connection between people, nature and valuable ideas, in service of unlocking our collective potential.
About Dr Amanda Cahill
Amanda is the Founder of The Next Economy, where she supports regional communities across Australia to manage the impacts of decarbonisation and climate change in a way that builds more equitable and regenerative economies. Most of this work has been in coal and industrial regions, where she has brought together government, industry, workers and community groups to co-design transition strategies despite deep-seated tensions. Her work draws on 30 years’ experience working with changemakers across the world to address economic and health inequalities, environmental degradation, women’s rights and climate justice.
Amanda is a Churchill Fellow and has a PhD from ANU in human geography. She is also a Research Fellow at the University of Melbourne, an Industry Fellow at the University of Sydney and a co-editor of the recently published book: Regional Energy Transitions in Australia: From impossible to possible.
About The Next Economy
Next Economy works with government, industry, investment and community to create the conditions for a rapid, responsible and fair transition to a climate-safe, regenerative and socially just Australian economy.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Te Hononga hikoi: Taupō Swamp, Te Hononga hikoi: Taupō Swamp
Te Hononga hīkoi enable our members to connect with others in the Wellington Catchments Collective. It's pretty inspiring seeing the activities happening in other catchment groups.

The next Te Hononga hikoi will be at Taupo Swamp in Porirua on the morning of Sunday 21 September at 10am – 11.30pm approx.

Come for a spring stroll and bring friends and family. Bring water and own snacks or fuel up at nearby cafes in Plimmerton.

We will meet in Ulric Street by the pedestrian bridge entrance to the dog park (plenty of parking)

Friends of Taupo Swamp & Catchment Inc was formed in 2018 by a group of Porirua residents. Restoration activities have been focused on the part of the wetlands that is owned by Porirua City Council.

Back in 2018 there was a lot of blackberry on the site. Now, some of the 2019-20 locally sourced plantings by volunteers are 5 metres high. By the end of the current planting season FOTSC will have put in 18K plants. An adjacent planting programme around the Plimmerton Domain coordinated by the local Rotary Club and the Porirua City Council has resulted in 22k trees and plants.

Please register your interest/intention to attend by flicking a short email to . In the event of bad weather we will advise cancellation by 8am and rescheduling for a week later.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Trap-NZ Workshop, Trap-NZ Workshop
Join us for a hands-on workshop that empowers you to make a difference in your backyard and beyond!



Whether you're a seasoned trapper or just starting out, this free community event will teach you how to use TRAP NZ, New Zealand’s leading predator control platform.



Reino Grundling will show you how to track pests, record trap data, and support conservation efforts that protect our precious native species like kiwi, tūī, and kererū.

📍 Where: Carterton Courthouse, Holloway Street Carterton
📅 When: Saturday 20 September 2025 10am -12 noon
🎟️ Cost: Free
🧰 Bring: Smartphone or tablet (if you have one), enthusiasm, and questions!

What you'll gain:

Tips for setting and managing traps effectively

Skills to use TRAP NZ for recording and reporting activity

Knowledge about the impact of predator control on local biodiversity

Connections with like-minded conservation champions

🌱 Let’s work together to protect what makes Aotearoa unique. Light refreshments provided. This workshop is made possible with funding from WBS.

Spots are limited — register now by emailing
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Tip Shop Truck at Te Aro Zero Waste, No vehicle no worries
The Tip Shop Truck will be at Te Aro Zero Waste (formerly EcoCentre) at 2, Forresters Lane on the Last Saturday of every month for the next three months.
The Tip Shop team will be collecting any big, bulky, awkward and other forgotten reusable items.
We will be taking furniture, building and gardening materials, books, and bric-a-brac. If you turn up in your car with a big load, please be prepared that we will end up sending you to the Tip Shop directly.
You can bring your e-waste, tools, metal, bicycles and hard to recycle items at the same time to Te Aro Zero Waste.
Te Aro Zero Waste has heaps of solutions to help you reduce your waste, open 10am - 4pm Wednesday - Saturday.
Can’t make it during these hours? Feel free to drop off your items to Te Aro Zero Waste the week before 10am - 4pm Wednesday - Friday
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Volunteer Info Evening- 2/57 Willis Street, Are you ready to make waves in conservation?
Join Mountains to Sea Wellington on our journey to restore and protect our marine and freshwater environments.
This information evening will give anyone interested in volunteering with us an opportunity to hear all about our volunteer programme and meet the MTSW crew.
There are lots of ways you can help us at MTSW! Are you into photography? Do you make a mean cuppa? Love to snorkel? Love to talk about marine critters? Nau mai, haere mai! We’d love your help! In return, we promise you a summer of adventure and fun times.
You're welcome to join us anytime from 5pm, there will be a short presentation at 5.15pm, followed by drinks and kai. There will be Mountains to Sea Wellington Staff onsite, as well as some of our current volunteers who'll be able to give you the inside word on what it's like to volunteer with us!
We’ll be in the Silver Lining Room at 2/57 Willis Street. Entrance is via the lifts in the alleyway to the left of Unity Books, take the lift to level 2.
RSVP HERE: https://forms.gle/URvGHkFxRmEmALgq8 so we know how much pizza to order!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
GISH: Live at Featherston Memorial RSA, GISH: Live at Featherston Memorial RSA
Join us for GISH: Live at Featherston Memorial RSA!

Date: Sunday, 26 October 2025
Time: 6:00pm - 8:00pm
Location: Featherston Memorial RSA, Featherston, Wairarapa

Comedy icon GISH is back with a brand-new tour across Aotearoa. For over 20 years, GISH has been one of New Zealand’s most beloved comedians, famous for his outrageous parodies that mix six strings with dodgy things. Get ready for a night where no song is safe. Joining him is Canadian freestyle sensation Jesse Firebrand, a razor-sharp musical comedian known for lightning-fast improvisation comedy songs, tearing through the Australian scene, with no one in New Zealand doing what he does. Your host for the night is Anthony Wilson, an Auckland-based comic and crowd favourite who has performed across Aotearoa, Australia, and the UK, known for quick wit, polished storytelling, and pub-worthy tales. There will also be a special guest on the night.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Weeding Bee 18th October, Weeding Bee 18th October
Kia Ora Koutou

Now we have finished planting we are turning our attention to the all important W**d releasing.
This is essential to keeping the seedlings we have planted this winter from being overwhelmed by grass and weeds.
Also mulching to help with moisture retention over those hot summer days (hopefully we get a summer!)
Meeting at the Nursery on Hana Udy street at 9am
Gloves, tools and sunscreen provided along with a morning tea and an update on the Reserve afterward.
Hope to see you there !



Health & Safety Notice: When working in the Reserve, please ensure your clothing and footwear are appropriate for expected weather conditions (cold, wet or hot) and the terrain (such as holes, hidden objects, blackberry, overhead branches). Trip hazards and slippery tracks are a possibility. Stay clear of waterways. Be cautious if you have allergies and carry the necessary medication. Enjoy your time in the Reserve and please avoid blocking pathways used by other users. Report any accidents, injuries or possible hazards to the H&S Coordinator (021 071 536)
label: Conservation & Environment

Opera Gala, Opera Gala
Experience an unforgettable evening of passion, drama, and soaring melodies at the Marlborough Opera Festival Opera Gala. Bringing together some of New Zealand’s brightest young talents alongside celebrated, established artists, this glittering concert showcases the very best of opera. From beloved arias and ensembles to powerful choruses, the stage will come alive with music that stirs the heart and captivates the imagination.

Join us for a night where voices shine, stories unfold through song, and the magic of opera takes centre stage in Marlborough.

Why Electrify - South Wairarapa, 5pm - 7pm Guest speakers:
Powerco - will share what they are doing to help with rural and coastal energy resilience.
Farmlands Flex team - talking through examples of how they are finding intelligent energy solutions for farms.
Hospitality NZ will talk about new ways they are supporting food, beverage and accommodation businesses to electrify and become more sustainable.
Local success stories - we will also have local people sharing their personal experience of electrifying their homes, farms and cars.
7pm onwards - ask us and the experts anything with light refreshments.

Puku Rangi Tea- Rapa Nui to Wellington, Puku Rangi Tea- Rapa Nui to Wellington
Iorana!
From Rapa Nui Easter Island to Pōneke Wellington, come and experience Puku Rangi Tea, internationally renowned folk ballet touring Aotearoa.

This is a unique opportunity to connect with the incredible music and dance from te pito o te henua, the belly button of the Earth.

The Latin Collective is hosting this koha event as we continue to stregthen the bonds between Aotearoa and Latin America.

Nau mai haere mai. Everyone is welcome!

description:
Artsplash: Choir, ArtSplash is a week-long festival, held every two years, that celebrates tāmariki and rangatahi experiencing performance on the big stage in dance and choir concerts. This year, we have two separate groups performing – one at ArtSplash and the other at DanceSplash.
Whaea Emilee and Mrs Skippers have an amazing Choir group training to perform on Monday 25 August at the 5pm show, held at the Michael Fowler Centre.
This group will be heading into town by 8:15am and with an action-packed day planned, will stay in town until their 5pm performance.
Following the show, our students will be ready to head home with their spectator parents. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.
In the meantime, follow the link to book tickets on the Ticketmaster website– don’t miss out!
label: Festivals

description:
It's in the Ballot-HCC-Friday 5th September Production Day Pass-Instudio, It's in the Ballot-HCC-Friday 5th September Production Day Pass-Instudio
'It's in the Ballot' takes the format of the Kiwi TV classic 'It's in the Bag' game show and puts a political twist to it.

Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative. We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.
This means you can send the weblink of the YouTube Video of your electorate show to your friends and whanau to encourage them to watch the show before they cast their votes.

- Hutt City Council – Eastbourne Community Board - 3pm to 4pm
- Greater Wellington Regional Council – Te Upoko o te Ika a Māui Māori Constituency - 4pm to 6pm
- Hutt City Council – Harbour General Ward - 7pm to 9pm

Voting papers are sent to voters on Tuesday 9th September 2025 and must be delivered into a voting dropbox by 12pm Saturday 11th October 2025
label: Government & Politics

description:

Wednesday- We're back open from 3pm with our first NEW BEER ALERT! Keep an eye out on socials for more info, and don't forget we have another Mid Month Open Mic kicking off at 6:30pm! Try your hand on the stage or come check out the local talent!
Thursday- Open again from 3pm with Carl Webley kicking off the live music from 6pm.
Friday- Open for lunch at 12pm, and our second NEW BEER ALERT kicks off- keep those eyeballs peeled for the grand reveal!
Saturday- Open again from 12pm with hot food and cold beer aaaallll day!
Sunday- Kicking off at 12pm again, with Beer BINGO every hour from 1pm, and at 3pm we have Michael Kingston on stage and playing tunes into a chill avro!
See you there!

description:
Shades Of Madlib, Join us for a night at the Rogue and Vagabond where the sampler becomes the stage to pay tribute to one of the greatest, Madlib.

Madlib has more aliases than most artists have albums. You can expect some deep cuts and classics. Get ready for a real inception, dream-inside-a-dream type experience.

XTrail Spring - Rangituhi Rumble, XTrail Spring - Rangituhi Rumble
Rangituhi serves up a lush and leg-burning journey through one of Porirua’s most scenic spots. Starting from Spicers Botanical Park, all three courses wind their way up through the peaceful, green trails of Spicers Forest before breaking into the rugged beauty of the Colonial Knob Reserve. The short course offers a more forgiving climb with playful zig zags and a fun descent, while the long course takes you all the way to the summit of Rangituhi, a proper challenge rewarded with stunning views over Porirua Harbour and beyond. With a mix of forest trails, farm tracks, and fast-flowing descents, this one’s a true highlight of the region.

https://barefootxtrail.co.nz/

description:
Sound Journey - PALMERSTON NORTH, Sound Journey - PALMERSTON NORTH
This powerful experience is like a soundtrack that is crafted to go with your life.
Something between an ancient ceremony and a movie soundtrack.
Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket. Be prepared to drop into a deep space.
Door sales will be available if there is space. Advanced booking is recommended.
Sika's Sound Journeys are truly unique. They are sonic explorations that feature didgeridoos, drums, flutes, voice and orchestral elements. A collection of foraged sounds from objects he has recorded in nature, add even more textures. Many of his sounds are completely unrecognisable and abstract. Immersed in this cocoon of abstract sound, we can find ourselves in the most surprising places in our mind. In this timeless realm, beyond the normal limitations of rational reality, anything is possible.
An epic adventure deep inside yourself.
Journey to worlds within worlds on incredible sound waves.
Sika creates a safe space to relax deeply and connect with our inner guidance. This Sound Journey begins and ends with a short guided visualisation.
There will be two journeys with an interval. Most people choose to lie down, so once again, please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to get really comfortable.
A journal is also recommended.

description:
Sophie Thorn – Victoria University Photography Collection, A tour of the photographs from Ngā Puhipuhi o Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington Art Collection
Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington holds a nationally significant collection of works of art which is under the care of Te Pātaka Toi Adam Art Gallery. Known as Ngā Puhipuhi o Te Herenga Waka, or 'the feathers which adorn the waka', over half of this collection can be found on display in the various buildings on the university campuses at any one time.
For this special outing, join the gallery’s Kaiwhakarākei, Curator Collections, Sophie Thorn, for an afterhours tour of the Hunter Building focusing on the photography in the collection.
We will see photographic works by Lucien Rizos, Ans Westra, Peter Preyer, Joyce Campbell, Fiona Pardington, Ann Noble and Chris Corson Scott.
We are meeting at the foyer of the Hunter Building. This is the big set of glass doors off gate 2 between the two sets of lights on Kelburn Parade.
As the tour begins at 6pm we would suggest,that people park in the Hunter Building carpark (coming in Gate 1 (right at the bend between Salamanca Road and Kelburn Parade). While these are reserved spaces for staff after 5:30pm parking is a bit of a free-for-all on campus after hours.
Thursday, 11 September, 6:00pm start, Meet at Hunter Building (Main Entrance off Kelburn Parade)

description:
NZIFF: Sex, Returning from last year’s Festival to screen alongside the rest of his Sex Dreams Love trilogy, Dag Johan Haugerud’s comic drama takes a candid and refreshing look at modern gender roles.

There has hardly been any investigation on contemporary male identity and sexuality as candid, insightful and hilarious as Norwegian auteur Dag Johan Haugerud’s Sex. After winning all major laurels in Nordic cinema with his impressive fresco Beware of Children (2019), the acclaimed director and author embarkson an Oslo-set trilogy simply called Sex Dreams Love.

The first instalment opens on one of the most tantalising and unexpected preludes in recent cinema. Two chimney sweeps frankly open up to each other on a coffee break in their office: the first reveals that he dreamt of being intensely looked at by none other than David Bowie, who was inspecting him as if he was a woman; the other confesses that he recently accepted the sexual advances of a male customer who asked him to have sex with him. But both men are “straight” and married to women. Here, the deft tone of the film and Haugerud’s rules of the game are immediately set.

A fervent admirer of Eric Rohmer’s thickly scripted skirmishes of love and ethics, the Norwegian writer-director infuses irony, depth and compassion in each of his elegantly composed tableaux depicting how the two men cope with the turmoil these experiences bring to their relationships with their partners and family, but most of all with themselves. Featuring some of the brightest and funniest dialogues of 2024, Sex is a real eye-opener. — Paolo Bertolin
label: Film & Media

description:
Wellington Climate Fresk Workshop, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Best Practice Guidelines Workshop - Wellington, This interactive session will help you effectively manage volunteers at your organisation. The Volunteer Best Practice Guidelines provide a framework to consider and review your own practice, and learn from others.
The session includes insights into managing challenging behaviour and problem solving, and is aimed at novices right through to experts in volunteer management.
We will explore the practice areas:
Recruiting and engaging volunteers
Welcoming and onboarding volunteers
Volunteer support, leadership, and management
Train and grow volunteers
Feedback and recognition
Celebrate volunteer impact
Exiting Volunteers
We will be learning from everyone in the room, including you!
The workshop will be based on the Volunteering New Zealand's 'Best Practice Guidelines.' You can access these 
on our website here.
We will provide you with morning tea and a light lunch. You'll be asked your dietary requirements when you register.
Registration is from 9:15am. Entry to venue from Featherston Street.
What previous attendees have said:
"I just wanted to say thank you for the opportunity to attend that workshop. It was lovely talking to other people in the charity sector which I haven’t had the chance to do yet. Great discussions and ideas."
"I am very much enjoying your workshops, and have implemented some of the learnings already."
About your facilitator:
Alison Marshall is about helping others build capability through learning and development.
Ali has over 25 years’ experience in learning and development at a senior level. She has worked in a broad range of industries that includes oil and gas, professional services, retail, education and hospitality. She has worked for large global organisations, start-ups and government. Her talent is being able to build relationships across all levels of the organisation.
Alison Marshall

description:
AI in Education: Part 1, Sovereign AI in NZ Education is a two part series that invites educators, AI developers, wh`ānau, students, and other interested people to consider how we - in Aotearoa - can design, build, and use AI tools. The goal of these sessions is to spark and support the creation of AI tools and practices that best serve the aspirations of our students and whānau, and blend well with the skills and insights of New Zealand's educators.
Part 1:
Generative AI is already in Aotearoa’s primary classrooms.  It is used by many teachers for planning and by ākonga both in and out of school.  However, policy, training, and culturally safe practice haven’t always kept pace.
In this talk, David Coblentz will provide research-based insights into:
teacher adoption patterns,
what students say they’re doing (and worrying about), and
where schools are missing guidance.
We'll also discuss what AI sovereignty could mean in education in Aotearoa New Zealand.
Then we can close with some practical steps for boards, leaders, kaiako, and whānau to support constructive and equitable AI use in Years 5–8.
*While the formal (and online) event will finish at 5pm, those attending in person are encouraged to stay on for snacks and drinks to share. Stay till 6pm or later, and get into the ideas more deeply, in a room full of good people.
David Coblentz is a Senior Statistician at NZCER. In addition to an undergraduate degree in Mathematics and Physics, David holds advanced degrees in Biostatistics (MS), History (PhD), and International Studies (MA) from the University of Washington in Seattle. Prior to coming to NZCER and transitioning into an educational research career in 2021, David worked as a biostatistician, data analytics director, and statistical consultant. David also has university teaching experience in history. His areas of interest include data analysis and data science, history education, evaluation, and AI in education.
Part 2 will follow within two weeks of David Coblentz's presentation. It will be an online event that features two or three local AI in education developers, talking about their current development projects.
We intend to record both parts and make them available via our community site - https://community.sovereignai.nz/

description:
Botanical Oddities - Guided Walk, In this one-hour walk will we will see a plant that can’t decide whether it’s a lily or an asparagus, tree trunks that are not really tree trunks, plants that photosynthesise only at night, and a deadly poisonous plant that yields potent cancer-fighting drugs. And discover more on this relaxing downhill amble.
Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.
This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

The BSLA team is excited to be hosting a refresher session in Wellington, where they will showcase new resources (e.g. Better Spelling), include assessment website updates and cover links to the refreshed curriculum. The refresher session is specifically for those who have completed a BSLA micro credential.

Secure your spot and register now. The BSLA team are looking forward to connecting with you soon!

description:
Hexaflexagon, Directed by Jim Fishwick

A hexaflexagon is a brightly-coloured six-sided shape that folds in on and out of itself to reveal face upon face upon face.

This show is also a hexaflexagon.

Six brightly-coloured shape-shifting actors fold scenes in on and out of themselves to reveal face upon face upon face. We wear lip gloss and carry a sword and play Super Mario and explore the forest and cry wet tears and eat giant pink-frosted donuts and party until dawn. We’re hexaflexagons. And so are you.

HEXAFLEXAGON is a high-art, high-energy improv show drenched in neon colours and backed by a hyperpop soundtrack. Six actors improvise scenes that are simultaneously very silly and very earnest, angular and amorphous, which weave together and snap apart.

As this show is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content or themes beyond what is in the description above. The show may contain mature themes and language, but not gratuitously. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.

Image credit: Kirsty McGuire

description:
Celebrating the champion — Maurice Gee’s contribution to children’s literature, Join us for a panel presentation focusing on the children’s writing of Maurice Gee, the celebrated New Zealand writer who died in June of this year, aged 93.
Speakers: NZ’s Reading Ambassador Kate de Goldi, commentator and award-winning writer for children Claire Mabey, poet Anna Jackson, memoirist and poet Harry Ricketts, and scholars Dr Tatjana Schaefer and Dr Vivien van Rij. The discussion will be introduced by Emeritus Professor Kathryn Walls.
This free event is hosted jointly by the Friends of the Dorothy Neal White Collection and Victoria University’s International Institute of Modern Letters.
All are welcome. Light refreshments will be served.
Date: Tuesday 23 September 2025
Time: 5.30 – 7:00pm (approx.) We shall begin with tea and coffee; the presentation will begin at 6.00 pm.
Place: Floor 12, Rutherford House, Bunny Street, Wellington
Enquiries to : Kathryn.Walls@vuw.ac.nz
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Honouring Te Tiriti: Totes, What does it actually mean to honour Te Tiriti?

Join Te Waka Huia for a three-part workshop where we will unpack our nation’s constitutional founding document and explore practical ways to honour it today.

The session begins with kōrero facilitated by tauiwi (non-Māori) guides Gaayathri Nair and Krissi Smith followed by light manaaki and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975–2025. After the short break, we’ll regroup for a Q&A session and finish with a tote bag-making activity led by Paekākāriki artist Selina Tuomey.

He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition ends Sunday 12 October.




About Gaayathri

Gaayathri Nair is a double diaspora person hailing from the southwest of India via Malaysia and coming to Aotearoa through economic migration in the 1980's under Rogernomics. She grew up in Tāmaki Makaurau and now lives in Te Awakairangi and works in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. She is a counsellor and facilitator, novice gardener, passionate knitter, frazzled PhD student, and shares a home with a delightfully awkward greyhound named Kevin.



About Krissi

Krissi Smith is of primarily Scottish (Clans McColl, Ross, Hogarth, Sutherland, Buchanan, Mactavish), Irish and English descent, but she grew up in Te Upoko o te Ika on Taranaki Whānui land. She currently lives in Te Ngaengae in Te Awakairangi, still on Taranaki Whānui land, and close to Waiwhetū. Krissi is a Tiriti educator, an accredited interpreter and translator, and a teacher of te reo Māori. She co-directs Kūwaha Ltd, with two of her besties: Tāwhana Chadwick and Raihānia Tipoki. She's also a māmā to one kid, one step kid, and Nanna to one moko. She has three dogs and five chickens. She loves growing kai and cooking it for people, singing karaoke, and sewing. She's a lover of learning and is getting pretty damn comfortable with not knowing the answers!



About Selina

Selina Tuomey has an Irish father and an English mother. She came to Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa for the love of this land and a man. As a child in England, her most cherished possession was an Air New Zealand green, plastic tiki sent to her by her pen friend.

She is a mother to three sixth-generation, beautiful, young Pākehā people. Selina has a Fine Art BA Hons and is all about art and nature, acting, painting, murals, clay play and drawing. She has a love of colour, growing trees, food and going bush. Selina is a mermaid and loves people. He tangata, he tangata, he tangata.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Genealogy - Basics of Ancestry.com DNA Tests, Have you done a DNA test with Ancestry.com? Don't know what to do next? This course will cover the basics of what your DNA results mean. We'll look at the tools available on Ancestry.com and other DNA websites to help you use DNA for your family's history.

Got your test results back and still wondering what a centiMorgan or a shared match is? Find out what the size of your match means and the tools available to help you work out possible family relationships.

We'll start by looking at Clustering and how the Grouping tool on Ancestry.com can help with this. We'll also look at the ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools to see how they can provide suggestions for knocking down brick walls in your research.

Also covered during this course are other websites you can upload your results to, how to manage other family member's DNA test results and other tools available when you get a bit more advanced - and just in case you need help in the future, we'll look at some of the places you could get this from.

Please note: This course will only cover DNA tests taken through Ancestry.com

Bring a USB stick and your Ancestry.com login details.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Understand the information provided by Ancestry.com about your DNA matches
- Use the Grouping, ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools on Ancestry.com
- Use the Shared CentiMorgan tool on DNAPainter.com
- Understand where to find other tools
- Understand the options for using other DNA websites
- Understand where to get further help

Prerequisites
For those who have already done a DNA test through Ancestry.com
You will need good computing and internet skills.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Presented by Sarah Hewitt.

description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

description:
Massey University Information Evening - Palmerston North campus, Massey University Information Evening - Palmerston North campus
Looking to progress your 2026 study plans? Join us to secure your enrollment, explore alternative careers or upskill your talent.

About this Event

Whether you're a distance or online learner or planning to study on campus, you are invited to join us for an evening of panel discussions, presentations and workshops to steer you on your way to a successful learning journey in 2026.
School Leavers : A step by step session to take you through the course enrolment process to enable you to select your 2026 courses seamlessly (bring your laptop); or if you're still not sure what you're studying with us we'll be sharing what we can offer via distance or campus learning;
Career Changers: How to change careers using your existing degree. Have you been thinking about Nursing, Planning, Social Work or Teaching as the next step in your career? Come along to our presentation to find out how you can begin a new career.
Mature learners and Up-skillers: Thinking about something new for 2026 or building on your current degree into Postgraduate study? We'll be sharing what we can offer via distance or campus learning.
You'll find us in the Social Sciences Lecture Block, Massey University.
Light refreshments will be provided.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Our Lady's Home of Compassion, Join us for a tour of the newly listed Category 1 Historic Place, The Chapel of Our Lady of Compassion and Resting Place of Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert.
Three thirty minute tours will be offered over the course of each morning. Each tour will include information about the history of the building, the meanings behind the stained glass windows, and the significance of the site as an ongoing place of worship for the wider Compassion community.
Participants will have the opportunity to visit the final Resting Place of Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert who founded the Sisters of Compassion, the only religious order born in Aotearoa New Zealand. Come and experience the rich history and spirituality that are embedded in these sacred places.

Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/.../our-ladys.../

Health & Safety:

description:
Getting the Most from ChatGPT: Practical AI for Everyday Use, AI tools like ChatGPT are everywhere, but how do you get the best out of them? In this hands-on, phone-based workshop, Jon Bell will guide you through practical techniques to make ChatGPT a more useful, reliable partner in your work and life. Whether you’ve tried it a few times or use it regularly, you’ll learn how to write better prompts, refine responses, and avoid common pitfalls without needing any technical background.
We’ll cover real examples, answer your questions as they come up, and spend plenty of time experimenting together so you leave feeling confident and ready to put your new skills to use.
Please bring: A phone with the ChatGPT app installed, and enough battery to last the day.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
Write effective prompts that get clearer, more useful responses
Use ChatGPT for research, brainstorming, and creative work
Recognise the tool’s limitations (and how to work around them)
Apply practical strategies for using AI in your personal or professional projects
Confidently troubleshoot when ChatGPT gives unexpected or unhelpful answers
A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami, Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami
In lecture theatre 2 (GBLT2) in the Law School at Victoria University / Te Herenga Waka.

Ramsey Library presents a public lecture by Bradford Haami.

What happens when vastly different ways of being meet? Dame Anne Salmond writes of ‘competing cosmologies’ and ‘ontological collisions’ — European missionaries arriving in Aotearoa in the early 19th century brought a Biblical cosmology that began such a collision. In this public lecture Bradford Haami will explore the interactions between Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual worldviews that continue to evolve up to the present.

* How do Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual beliefs and thought relate?
* How 19th century rangatira negotiate between traditional beliefs and the Biblical narratives?
* Where do Christian and Māori ways of knowing and seeing clash, compete or enrich each other?
* What does being Māori and Christian look like today?


Bradford Haami (Ngāti Awa) is a Māori historian, researcher and author with research interests in Māori worldviews, spirituality, Christianity and cultural preservation. He is Pou Amorangi (Māori Director) at Laidlaw College in Auckland, New Zealand, where he lectures in biculturalism and sits on the governing board of the college. Haami has written several books on Māori history, culture and spirituality, with recent works including Urban Māori: The Second Great Migration (Oratia Media 2018) and Bringing Culture into Care (Huia 2019). He was the Māori curator/expert on the acclaimed Te Taiao / Nature exhibition at Te Papa Tongarewa Museum.

--
To browse the Ramsey Library catalogue, and sign up to borrow books (free), go to https://library.chaplaincyvuw.org.nz

description:
Pukeahu Archaeology Tour, What lies beneath Pukeahu?

The construction of Pukeahu National War Memorial Park revealed a wealth of archaeological discoveries, some expected, others surprising.

Join Principal Archaeologists Sarah Phear and Richard Shakles from Underground Overground Archaeology for a special guided tour of the park. Hear firsthand about the excavation process, uncover the stories behind the artefacts, and view a selection of conserved items unearthed from beneath Pukeahu.

The tour begins at the fountain below the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior.
This is an accessible tour. Bring clothing for the weather and any burning questions.

description:
STEAMS School BLENHEIM Term 4 2025, What is STEAMS?
STEAMS is an integrated learning programme covering Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Maths, and Society. It focuses on real-world skills, critical thinking, collaboration, and creativity through hands-on, project-based learning—not play-based, but purposeful exploration without rigid time constraints.
Students are immersed in engaging, age-appropriate activities that encourage curiosity, innovation, and independent learning.
Key Benefits:
Students in STEAMS learn to:
Think creatively and critically
Collaborate and communicate effectively
Connect ideas across disciplines
Take ownership of their learning
Explore without pressure
