description:
Soundscape Series: Danica Bryant, Danica Bryant is a force to be reckoned with. A pop-folk singer-songwriter with a gritty rock-edge, her music tackles provocative themes from celebrity culture to neurodiversity through an unabashedly queer feminist lens.

Her “playful indie pop” (Rolling Stone) has seen her open for legends like Elton John and Robbie Williams, hit #2 on the NZ Hot Singles Chart with her 2024 release ‘Acid’, and undergo mentorship with Kiwi icon Bic Runga. Bryant has undergone multiple successful New Zealand tours and played festivals including Gardens Magic, Outfield and Cuba Dupa.

With her debut album 'Feast' out this August, Bryant is “venomous yet passionate” (Ambient Light), “cynical but emotional” (NZ Musician), and an unapologetically fresh voice on the pop music scene.

About the Mostly Music Soundscape Series

A curated series of intimate live music experiences showcasing the depth, texture and emotion of sound. Each performance invites you to immerse yourself in a new soundscape, informed by genre, sonic craft, and music as an art form. Designed for music lovers who want more than a background soundtrack, this series celebrates live performance with a diverse range of acclaimed performers.

Saturday 21 June — Nick Granville Trio

Doors 7:30pm, with events starting at 8pm. Each event will be 60—90 minutes in two sets.

These events will take place inside at The Bond Store, Paraparaumu and are seated with general admission.

The Bond Store is located at 21 Birmingham Street, Paraparaumu. It operates as The Tasting Room which serves food and beverages.

description:
BANDIT QUEEN @ The Boathouse, Nelson, BANDIT QUEEN is NZ's finest (likely only) tribute to the music of The Decemberists.A Tribute to the Decemberists? BUT WHO ARE THE DECEMBERISTS?
Hailing from Portland Oregon, The Decemberists is an indie-alt folk rock band that write epic songs and have 9 studio albums to their credit. They are renowned for their musical style and unique storytelling with many song lyrics based on historical incidents and folklore. Perhaps drawing musical influence from the likes of The Beatles, Tom Waits, REM, Morrisey, their songs are exquisitely constructed and effortlessly combine folk-rock with elements of pop creating the infectious sound that is The Decemberists.
And who is BANDIT QUEEN? Experienced Christchurch based musos - Tim Kent (vocals, acoustic guitar); Justin 'Rusty' White (lead guitar); Jo-Anne Davern Fuller (vocals, keyboard); Chiara Lowe (violin, vocals); Adam Lowe (bass); Mark Newburn (drums, percussion).
The members of BANDIT QUEEN are passionate about this project and invite you to come experience and enjoy the eclectic music of USA indie-rock band THE DECEMBERISTS.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Lecrae - Reconstruction World Tour NZ | Wellington, Lecrae - Reconstruction World Tour NZ | Wellington
4x GRAMMY® Award-winning artist, author, actor and activist Lecrae has formally announced his headlining tour, ‘Reconstruction World Tour,’ on the heels of unveiling the release date for his tenth studio album, Reconstruction, due August 22nd.

Tickets will be available starting with an artist presale beginning Wed, July 30 at 10am local time. Additional presales will run throughout the week ahead of the general on sale beginning Fri, August 1 at 10am local at lecrae.com/tour.

Making his anticipated return to the stage, the tour will mark one-year since Lecrae’s last outing in 2024 for ‘The Final Church Clothes Tour!’ The fan favorite is slated to perform songs from his decorated catalog, as well as music from his upcoming album Reconstruction.

Beyond the music, Lecrae has fostered a direct relationship with his local community. Last Monday (July 21), the Grammy-winner held a back-to-school drive in the heart of Atlanta alongside nonprofit City Takers. With over 100+ people in attendance, both fans and residents alike joined Lecrae in assembling backpacks filled with essential school supplies for students across the city.

As a special treat to fans, Lecrae revealed the features on Reconstruction with a one-of-a-kind mailer that went out to 1,000 of his most active supporters. Each mailer included a handwritten note from the Reach Records founder, and a QR code linking to The Workshop – an online community where fans can access early music, content, and engage to earn points for incentives.

Continuing his mission of bringing Christ to the culture, he now gears up to make international headlines with his renewed stage presence, ultimately setting the tone for an unstoppable and intentional run. The announcement also heralds the arrival of Lecrae’s forthcoming album Reconstruction – his first solo project since 2022’s Church Clothes 4 LP.

description:
Stewart Copeland — Have I said Too Much?, He’s had an incredible life as a performer, musician, entertainer, and writer. Stewart Copeland is one of the great rock drummers. He comes to Wellington for the first time in January with his show, ‘Have I Said Too Much?’ It features Stewart in conversation with acclaimed media host Sarah Tout (RTR FM). Fans also have the opportunity to ask questions by submitting them before the show. 
Stewart’s remarkable talent helped drive The Police to world fame between 1977 and 1986, and then again in 2007 and 2008 when the band was reunited. He is a multiple Grammy Award winner and, in 2003, was inducted into the Rock and Rock Hall of Fame. He has written best-selling books, directed documentaries, formed supergroups, made films, and composed music for ballet, opera, and classical concerts. This is a rare opportunity to get an insight into a performer’s fascinating life.

description:
CMNZ Series: Four Last Songs - Wellington, CMNZ Series: Four Last Songs - Wellington
This October, Chamber Music New Zealand is proud to tour Aotearoa's own NZTrio (Amalia Hall - violin, Somi Kim - piano, Matthias Balzat - cello) and Australian soprano Emma Pearson in Four Last Songs, a concert reflecting on the nature of goodbyes, endings, and renewals.

Named for Strauss' Four Last Songs which he wrote towards the end of his life — now arranged for piano trio and soprano — the songs reflect on the serene acceptance of mortality and a closeness with nature.

The concert also features Salina Fisher's Kintsugi, about the Japanese art of putting broken ceramics back together with gold and celebrating the beauty of a life not unmarred by difficulty, but made more beautiful by the resilience of overcoming hardship.

PROGRAMME

🎶 Elena Kats-Chernin | The Spirit and the Maiden
🎶 Salina Fisher | Kintsugi
🎶 Amy Beach | 2 Songs Op. 100 A Mirage and Stella Viatoris
🎶 Sergei Rachmaninoff | Vocalise
🎶 Richard Strauss (arr. Salina Fisher) | Four Last Songs (Vier letzte Lieder) TrV 296
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Free Status, Free Status is a jazz fusion band, drawing melodic inspiration from iconic artists like Herbie Hancock and 70s jazz/funk legends with electronic flair inspired by artists like Moby.

At the heart of Free Status is Tommy David on keys, an accomplished musician/composer in the early stages of his career. He has earned recognition in numerous jazz competitions and supported legendary rock acts such as Dire Straits Legacy Band, Nazareth, Hello Sailor, and plays with popular rockabilly band, Recliner Rockers. With composition at the center of his artistry, he can’t wait to share the exciting and genuine compositions he has created.

The rhythm section features Behzad Karakia (drums) and Tyler Diprose (bass), both veterans of performances with many of New Zealand’s jazz greats.

On lead alto sax is James Dawes, recently selected for an international touring band on a year-long cruise. His versatility extends well beyond jazz.

On keys is Sam Voyle, whose primary instrument is tenor saxophone. Performing with Tommy since their school days, he has built a strong musical bond that has led to major appearances, including the America’s Cup main stage and high-profile corporate events.

On vocals is Melody Lui-Webster, an award-winning singer and accomplished musical theatre performer and actor, with numerous professional stage and television roles.

Thank you for watching!
label: Music & Concerts

description: Heaven & Earth: Celebrating 25 Years of Bold Sounds, Heaven & Earth marks 25 years of Stroma’s fearless exploration of sound and spirit since our inaugural concert Wind, Rain & Light in August 2000. We recall the theme of that first concert by similarly evoking musical impressions of the earth below and the sky above. Featuring a world premiere by New York-based NZ composer Leila Adu-Gilmore, the programme includes Olivier Messiaen’s ecstatic Louange à l’immortalité de Jésus, Gemma Peacocke’s Sky Fields, John Rimmer’s Where Sea Meets Sky 2, Michael Norris’s new piano trio The Spaces In Between, and—to mark the recent passing of Sofia Gubaidulina—her meditative Garden of Joy and Sorrow. Come join us in celebrating a quarter century of intrepid sonic exploration from the musicians of Stroma.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Dan Hayles Presents | On The Grid, On The Grid is about the marking, passing and embellishing of time. The Grid is life, time, tone, tonality, rhythm, gravity, momentum, and style. 

The musicians work at times together, other times separately as 3 ensembles (horn quintet, string quartet, piano trio), and other times as combinations conversing and improvising amongst themselves. The music covers a selection of different styles and feels within and outside the jazz sound - and it's ready for your participation as a listener of melodies, dancer of beats, expresser of moods, theorist of lore, interpreter of meaning, and feeler of feels.

On The Grid consists of brand new music arranged and composed especially for the Jazz Composer Orchestra series, originally curated and presented by Michael Costeloe with funding from Creative New Zealand in 2025. This show celebrates the release on CD of the group's first ever performance - buy a copy and help us take On The Grid to more audiences around Aotearoa and the world.

Sylvester Green - Trumpet
Tyaan Singh - Alto Saxophone
Louisa Williamson - Tenor Saxophone and Flute

description:
Porirua Parkrun, What is Porirua parkrun? It is a free 5km walk or run event - It’s not about coming first or winning. You can go at your own pace and just enjoy being with other people. It is inclusive and the perfect way to start your weekend in the outdoors chatting to people.

The start occurs just upstream of the Bothamley Park carpark. This car park is off Champion street, opposite the intersection with Windley Street. Head to end of carpark where the concrete ends and there is a gate. For location see https://goo.gl/maps/wEohfp9bRu82.

The course is following the old coach road (circa 1870's) established for the early farms in the area. Today this historic track is located within a park, away from cars and now used by walkers, runners and cyclists.

The track is generally 3 metres wide with a gentle gradient and a compacted gravel surface beside the Kenepuru Stream through a picturesque wooded wild valley. (Note there is a pinch point for a short section after the 2km marker where participants need to go single file each direction for approx 30 metres)

The valley runs east-west with mature trees which means this has to be one of the most sheltered places, out of the wind to exercise in Wellington.

What does it cost to join in? Nothing - it's free! but please register before your first run or walk, so you can get your timing results. You only need to register with parkrun once, to participate at any of the parkrun events around the world. Don't forget to bring a copy of your barcode. If you forget it, you won't get a time.

How fast do I have to be? Walking is fine as long as you can finish the 5km. Please come along and join in whatever your pace!

One dog per adult is welcome, as long as it is on a short hand held lead.

Children welcome but those 10 years and under need to be kept within arms reach of a supervising adult.

Note there is no toilets in the park, so go before you go.

We're friendly! Every week we grab a post park run/walk coffee/tea at Get Fixed within Kai Tahi at 20 Parumoana Street, to mix exercise with socialising.

There are volunteering opportunities even week. So those doing Duke of Edinburgh or similar challenges can get volunteer credits. Ensure you contact us well in advance at "porirua@parkrun.co.nz"

description:
NZIFF: Romeria, One of the standouts of Cannes 2025, Carla Simón’s personal exploration of the restlessness of a young woman without parents is a poignant example of the healing power of cinema.

After winning the Best Film in Berlin with Alcarràs (2022), Spanish director Carla Simón looks back into her own memories and heals pains from the past with her spellbinding third feature film Romería.

Eighteen-year-old Marina is an aspiring film student who sets out to trace the fate of her biological parents – who both died during the HIV epidemic of the late 1980s, early 1990s. Raised in Barcelona by her maternal grandparents, Marina visits her paternal family in Galicia, in order to obtain the paternity recognition documents that would allow her to apply for a scholarship. Guided on her journey by the pages of her mother's diary, Marina revisits her parents’ story of love and addiction...

Simón brushes with delicate touches the dynamics of a difficult family reconciliation and the motions of post-adolescent desire (the attraction between Marina and her cousin). While she initially draws from the tropes of summertime family dramas, Simón then turns Romería into a dreamlike fable where the past comes alive through the present thanks to the simple, yet enchanting true magic of cinema.— Paolo Bertolin
label: Film & Media

description:
War on Drugs Film Screening, In remembrance of the victims of human rights violations and extrajudicial killings during the War on Drugs in the Philippines, please join us for a free/koha screening of "On the President's Orders" documentary in Te Whanganui-a-Tara.

NOTE: For a list of trigger warnings, please see this document. Since we will be viewing and discussing potentially sensitive topics, the event will have an Open Door Policy, which means that you may leave the venue any time, for any reason, and will not be judged for doing so.
WHAT IS THE WAR ON DRUGS?
Spearheaded by the former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte, the War on Drugs is a violent anti-drug campaign which killed nearly 30,000 Filipinos, most of which were urban poor (Karapatan, Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch).
WHAT ARE EXTRAJUDICIAL KILLINGS?
"Extrajudicial killings, or extrajudicial executions, happen when someone in an official position deliberately kills a person without any legal process" (World Organisation Against Torture).
WHY IS IT IMPORTANT TO TALK ABOUT TODAY?
Human rights violations and extrajudicial killings are still on-going in the Philippines under President Bongbong Marcos, the son of the dictator Ferdinand Marcos Sr. who proclaimed Martial Law in 1972, and Vice President Sara Duterte, the daughter of former President Rodrigo Duterte (Karapatan).
WHY WOULD I WANT TO JOIN THE FILM SCREENING?
The film screening is for anyone who is keen to learn about the War on Drugs, wants to share their experience during the War on Drugs (or something similar) through group discussion, wants to meet new people, wants to watch a Philippine film/documentary, or just wants to have snacks.
I WANT TO JOIN BUT I'M FROM TĀMAKI MAKAURAU / CHRISTCHURCH / THE PHILIPPINES.
We will stream the film through Zoom for viewers outside Te Whanganui-a-Tara, however, there may be internet and other technical difficulties during the event itself. Also please make sure to select the "Online" ticket option when RSVPing.
HOW MUCH IS THE TICKET?
The film screening is free but we appreciate koha for the venue/snacks/donations to Philippine non-governmental organisations (NGOs).
NOTE: This is an LGBTQ+ friendly event.

description:

Get ready for a night of cinematic chills and festive frights! Since 2022, Film Talks’ Halloween Film Night has brought Wairarapa audiences together to explore classic horror films in a fun, immersive atmosphere. Over the past three years, we’ve journeyed through the shadows of 1920s German Expressionist cinema, and this year we step into 1930s Hollywood Gothic Horror with Universal Pictures’ The Bride of Frankenstein (1935)—a Gothic horror classic with unforgettable visuals, thrilling storytelling, and timeless appeal.
Doors open at 6:45 pm, and the movie begins at 7 pm at Aratoi, 12 Bruce Street, Masterton. Running time: 75 minutes.
Costumes are encouraged, with spot prizes for the best dressed, making it a night that’s as much about fun and community as it is about film. Perfect for families, friends, and cinephiles, the event promises shared laughs, playful scares, and a celebration of classic cinema. The film is not rated but recommended for ages 9+.
Book tickets to reserve your seat. Koha welcome: suggested $5. Your contribution helps support the event and keep Film Talks experiences running for the community.
Presented by Film Talks, in association with the Wellington Heritage Festival. This is an evening you won’t want to miss!
label: Film & Media

description:
Reels for Meals: Wicked: For Good, November's Reels for Meals movie fundraiser is Wicked: For Good.
Last year’s global cinematic cultural sensation, which became the most successful Broadway film adaptation of all time, now reaches its epic, electrifying, emotional conclusion in Wicked: For Good.
The final chapter of the untold story of the witches of Oz begins with Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo) and Glinda (Ariana Grande) estranged and living with the consequences of their choices.
Elphaba, now demonised as The Wicked Witch of the West, lives in exile, hidden within the Ozian forest while continuing her fight for the freedom of Oz’s silenced Animals and desperately trying to expose the truth she knows about The Wizard (Jeff Goldblum).
Glinda, meanwhile, has become the glamorous symbol of Goodness for all of Oz, living at the palace in Emerald City and revelling in the perks of fame and popularity. Under the instruction of Madame Morrible (Michelle Yeoh), Glinda is deployed to serve as an effervescent comfort to Oz, reassuring the masses that all is well under the rule of The Wizard.
As Glinda’s stardom expands and she prepares to marry Prince Fiyero (Jonathan Bailey) in a spectacular Ozian wedding, she is haunted by her separation from Elphaba. She attempts to broker a conciliation between Elphaba and The Wizard, but those efforts will fail, driving Elphaba and Glinda only further apart. The aftershocks will transform Boq (Ethan Slater) and Fiyero forever, and threaten the safety of Elphaba’s sister, Nessarose (Marissa Bode), when a girl from Kansas comes crashing into all their lives.
As an angry mob rises against the Wicked Witch, Glinda and Elphaba will need to come together one final time. With their singular friendship now the fulcrum of their futures, they will need to truly see each other, with honesty and empathy, if they are to change themselves, and all of Oz, for good.

All profits from this movie fundraiser go to the Lower Hutt Foodbank.

description:
NZIFF: The Teacher Who Promised the Sea, A progressive teacher brings new methods to a village in Burgos on the eve of the Spanish Civil War, whilst in present day Catalonia a woman searches for answers as to the whereabouts of her great-grandfather’s remains.

Catalan filmmaker Patricia Font takes us to 1930s Spain by way of real-life educator Antonio Benaiges, assigned to teach in the small village of Bañuelos de Bureba. Intertwined with these flashback sequences are scenes from present day Catalonia and Burgos where Ariadna, the granddaughter of one of Antonio's pupils, seeks to locate ancestral remains at the mass graves of La Pedraja.

Antonio’s leftist leanings and critiques of the new Francoist government anger the more conservative townsfolk, particularly the town mayor. This is despite his daughter being one of the pupils benefiting most from the free expression encouraged by Antonio’s Freinet method teachings. Meanwhile, Ariadna teeters between hope and despair in her search for closure – a human vessel embodying the plight of a nation still wrestling with the consequences of a brutal conflict.

The closing credits remark that the remains of 12,000 people have been exhumed across the country. Like Ariadna, the film attempts to seek answers from the horrors of a war that took place almost a century ago – one driven by political sentiments that feel unsettlingly familiar as some of today’s most powerful nations shift towards fascism. — Matt Bloomfield
label: Film & Media

description:
Mystery 35mm Movie Marathon, Details
UPDATE - We have added some Half Marathon ticket options for those can't make the whole event. You can either select 'Daytime' or 'Evening' which will let you watch three features total. Daytime tickets are from 1:30pm until the dinner break (around 7:00pm). Evening are from the dinner break until the end of the last film.

Surprise we are running a 35mm Mystery Marathon very soon! We have had some exciting news that we cannot share for now but as a result we must move our beautiful 35mm from its usual location into storage for a bit. We are not sure when it will be set back up so to celebrate we are running a marathon of six 35mm features across one Saturday!

We will kick off the first film at 1:30pm sharp on Saturday and will have a short dinner break after the third film. All going to plan we should be done by around 12:30am.

In terms of the features, we have films from the 1960s through to the early 2000s with a mix of comedies, sci-fi, horror and cult classics! Granted not all of these films would be considered masterpieces but there is nothing more fun than sitting in a crowd not knowing what could be coming next!

We will have a snack menu you can pre-order before the first film so aim to arrive around 1:00pm to order. The breaks between films will be very short (probably just enough time for the projectionist to thread up the next film) so make sure you come prepared for back-to-back screenings.

This event has strictly no digital projection, it’s all film all the time. Now in theory it should all playback without a hitch as we are bringing in some of the best projectionist’s Wellington has. But 35mm is a strange beast that can sometimes throw up the odd issue.

Full marathon tickets (Admit) are $50
Half Marathon - Daytime are $30
Half Marathon - Evening are $30

Seating is general admission and cinema entrance will be determined by earliest ticket purchase times.
label: Film & Media

description:
NZIFF: Twinless, A grieving brother finds an unlikely connection at a support group for siblings who have lost a twin, but his burgeoning bromance threatens to turn into something darker in this uncomfortably sharp-witted comedy.

When his brother is suddenly killed in a car accident, estranged sibling Roman (Dylan O’Brien) suffers the unique pain of being permanently severed from his twin. Inseparable in childhood, the brothers drifted apart as adults, brother Rocky (also O’Brien) living out and proud in Portland while Roman lived a (decidedly hetero) tradie life in hometown Idaho. It seems he’ll never have the chance to work through his complicated feelings towards his twin until stumbling upon a bereavement group for just such a purpose.

There he meets Dennis (James Sweeney). Neurotic, sarcastic, gay, he’s the opposite that attracts as the pair bond over trauma and a deep need for attachment. They quickly become each other’s emotional support twin-surrogate, on call for late night grocery trips, afterwork bitch sessions, and road trip singalongs. But odd couple bliss can’t last, as Dennis has more than friendship in mind, Roman grapples with explosive anger issues, and dark secrets inevitably come to light.

Sweeny’s sophomore effort as writer, director, and co-star walks an entertaining balance between discomfort and hilarity. With finely calibrated performances from both leads, Twinless is witty, warped, and surprisingly warm hearted. — Adrian Hatwell
label: Film & Media

description:
He Pō Kiriata: Kneecap, This spring, the Māoriland Hub turns into a cosy little theatre for seven weeks of kiriata and kōrero. From September to November, a selection of Thursday nights will be your chance to slow down, sink into a beanbag, sit back in a chair, and lose yourself in the magic of cinema. Bring your own pillow and blanket if you wish!

KNEECAP Synopsis:

When fate brings Belfast school teacher JJ into the Orbit of self confessed ‘low life scum’ Naoise and Liam Og, the needle drops on a hip hop act like no other. Rapping in their native language KNEECAP fast becomes the unlikely figurehead of a civil rights movement to save their mother tongue. But the trio must first overcome police, paramilitaries and politicians trying to silence their defiant sound - whilst their anarchic approach to life often makes them their own worst enemies.

In this fiercely original sex, drugs and hip-hop biotic KNEECAP play themselves laying down a global rallying cry for the defense of native cultures.

Stay for a chat afterwards where we talk all things activism and what that means today.

When:
Thursday, October 16 2025
Event start: 7:30pm
Q&A session with tea and cookies after the screening.

See you soon!
This screening is R16.
label: Film & Media

description:
NZIFF: Young Mothers, The Dardenne brothers return with a deeply affecting drama exploring the lives of five teen mothers. Hopes and fears steer the young women towards bettering their lives for themselves and their children.

Young Mothers examines the lives of underprivileged teenagers as they come to terms with motherhood for the first time. Living together temporarily in a group home, they are taught how to care for their babies, while grappling with very different personal circumstances. The Dardenne brothers treat the characters with delicate respect while humanising the tumultuous reality that often comes with teenage motherhood.

Jessica, raised in an orphanage, cannot imagine abandoning her child and desperately seeks closure from her birth mother. Julie considers giving up her daughter for adoption, yet her own troubled mother wishes to raise the child to atone for her past mistakes. Brought up by an alcoholic mother, Perla dreams of a stable family, but her delinquent boyfriend wants nothing to do with her or their child. While Ariane has the privilege of a loving partner, both are recovering drug addicts which presents its own challenges.

This is a story of hope told through characters looking for a future free from their past. — Madison Marshall
label: Film & Media

Each session is two hours long and covers an entire external/topic, giving students the chance to:
Go over all the key content they’ll need for the exam
Learn exactly what the exam will be testing
Pick up strategies for tackling the harder Merit and Excellence questions
Receive a workbook to use in the session and keep for revision afterwards
Ask questions and get support from experienced tutors who’ve been through it all before
Why Attend?
These workshops are designed to:
Fill any gaps in knowledge
Build exam confidence
Kickstart motivation heading into Term 4
Spaces are limited and workshops often sell out quickly. Register now to secure your spot and head into exams feeling prepared, confident, and ready to succeed.

description:
Massey University Information Evening - Palmerston North campus, Massey University Information Evening - Palmerston North campus
Looking to progress your 2026 study plans? Join us to secure your enrollment, explore alternative careers or upskill your talent.

About this Event

School Leavers : A step by step session to take you through the course enrolment process to enable you to select your 2026 courses seamlessly (bring your laptop); or if you're still not sure what you're studying with us we'll be sharing what we can offer via distance or campus learning;
Career Changers: How to change careers using your existing degree. Have you been thinking about Nursing, Planning, Social Work or Teaching as the next step in your career? Come along to our presentation to find out how you can begin a new career.
Mature learners and Up-skillers: Thinking about something new for 2026 or building on your current degree into Postgraduate study? We'll be sharing what we can offer via distance or campus learning.
You'll find us in the Social Sciences Lecture Block, Massey University.
Light refreshments will be provided.

In Speaking My Language / Te Korero i Toku Reo Mike shares his story of that journey to speak te reo Maori and reclaim his identity. His book is an invitation for all New Zealanders to take the first step to understand why speaking our Maori language and treasuring our culture matters.
All welcome!

'Capital Trees' walking tour with author Susette Goldsmith, Susette Goldsmith, author of 'Capital Trees' is your guide to significant and meaningful trees that have shaped our capital and its arboreal legacy.

As part of the wider Wellington Heritage Festival, this 2-hour author-led walking tour of the CBD guides you through highlights from the new Te Papa Press book, 'Capital Trees'. The book and tour trace the living legacies of the city’s rich tree heritage, including arguments around heritage tree listing, the native versus exotics debate, biodiversity, trees as monuments and more.
Starting at the Supreme Court, the tour takes in Parliament grounds, The Terrace and Plimmer Steps before ending up at Unity Books.

description:
Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami, Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami
In lecture theatre 2 (GBLT2) in the Law School at Victoria University / Te Herenga Waka.

Ramsey Library presents a public lecture by Bradford Haami.

What happens when vastly different ways of being meet? Dame Anne Salmond writes of ‘competing cosmologies’ and ‘ontological collisions’ — European missionaries arriving in Aotearoa in the early 19th century brought a Biblical cosmology that began such a collision. In this public lecture Bradford Haami will explore the interactions between Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual worldviews that continue to evolve up to the present.

* How do Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual beliefs and thought relate?
* How 19th century rangatira negotiate between traditional beliefs and the Biblical narratives?
* Where do Christian and Māori ways of knowing and seeing clash, compete or enrich each other?
* What does being Māori and Christian look like today?


Bradford Haami (Ngāti Awa) is a Māori historian, researcher and author with research interests in Māori worldviews, spirituality, Christianity and cultural preservation. He is Pou Amorangi (Māori Director) at Laidlaw College in Auckland, New Zealand, where he lectures in biculturalism and sits on the governing board of the college. Haami has written several books on Māori history, culture and spirituality, with recent works including Urban Māori: The Second Great Migration (Oratia Media 2018) and Bringing Culture into Care (Huia 2019). He was the Māori curator/expert on the acclaimed Te Taiao / Nature exhibition at Te Papa Tongarewa Museum.

--
To browse the Ramsey Library catalogue, and sign up to borrow books (free), go to https://library.chaplaincyvuw.org.nz

description:
Café Scientifique - Space: What Is Our Place In the Cosmos?, Join us for a new Café Scientifique series hosted by Pūtaiao ki te Pāpori—School of Science in Society.

At this first event in September, astrophysicist Dr Yvette Perrott and novelist Dr Tim Corballis will discuss the evolving picture physics gives us about the nature of the universe, and the ways people find their place in it.

Café Scientifique is a place where, for the price of a cup of coffee or a glass of wine, anyone can come to explore the latest ideas in science and technology in a relaxed, friendly environment.

The evening will start with a short introduction from the speakers, followed by a question-and-answer conversation.

Doors open at 5.30 pm, talks begin at 6 pm. All welcome—free entry, nibbles provided.

Please note: anyone under the age of 18 must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
For further information, please contact scienceinsociety@vuw.ac.nz.

description:
Genealogy - Basics of Ancestry.com DNA Tests, Have you done a DNA test with Ancestry.com? Don't know what to do next? This course will cover the basics of what your DNA results mean. We'll look at the tools available on Ancestry.com and other DNA websites to help you use DNA for your family's history.

Got your test results back and still wondering what a centiMorgan or a shared match is? Find out what the size of your match means and the tools available to help you work out possible family relationships.

We'll start by looking at Clustering and how the Grouping tool on Ancestry.com can help with this. We'll also look at the ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools to see how they can provide suggestions for knocking down brick walls in your research.

Also covered during this course are other websites you can upload your results to, how to manage other family member's DNA test results and other tools available when you get a bit more advanced - and just in case you need help in the future, we'll look at some of the places you could get this from.

Please note: This course will only cover DNA tests taken through Ancestry.com

Bring a USB stick and your Ancestry.com login details.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Understand the information provided by Ancestry.com about your DNA matches
- Use the Grouping, ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools on Ancestry.com
- Use the Shared CentiMorgan tool on DNAPainter.com
- Understand where to find other tools
- Understand the options for using other DNA websites
- Understand where to get further help

Prerequisites
For those who have already done a DNA test through Ancestry.com
You will need good computing and internet skills.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Presented by Sarah Hewitt.

description:
West Auckland Mathematics Leadership Community 2025, Are you the maths lead in your school? Do you feel equipped to lead the roll out of the new mathematics and statistics curriculum? Would you like to be part of a group of like-minded leads?
Register to join our Mathematics Leadership Community (MLC) and build your mathematics and statistics knowledge and leadership skills.
These MLC’s have been supporting mathematics leaders and teachers for over 18 years and we are excited to offer you the opportunity to be part of this network in 2025, which is shaping up to be a pivotal year in mathematics education.

Through engaging with current research and best practice, these meetings will enable leaders and teachers to:
stay up to date with changes and implement Te Mātaiaho, Mathematics and Statistics Curriculum
build capability in leading mathematics and statistics within and across their school
investigate effective pedagogy and strategies for teaching and assessing mathematics and statistics
connect and network with other leaders and teachers.

Testimonials from 2024
“These days have been invaluable in supporting me to lead whole school maths review with our teachers.”

“It has given me more knowledge and confidence when leading my own meetings, knowing I have research and work behind me when I lead.”

“I love the resources and the connections that develop through these meetings.”

“This year the mahi we have done around the curriculum refresh has been instrumental in beginning our school’s development of our localised curriculum.”

description:
AI in Education: Part 1, Sovereign AI in NZ Education is a two part series that invites educators, AI developers, wh`ānau, students, and other interested people to consider how we - in Aotearoa - can design, build, and use AI tools. The goal of these sessions is to spark and support the creation of AI tools and practices that best serve the aspirations of our students and whānau, and blend well with the skills and insights of New Zealand's educators.
Part 1:
Generative AI is already in Aotearoa’s primary classrooms.  It is used by many teachers for planning and by ākonga both in and out of school.  However, policy, training, and culturally safe practice haven’t always kept pace.
In this talk, David Coblentz will provide research-based insights into:
teacher adoption patterns,
what students say they’re doing (and worrying about), and
where schools are missing guidance.
We'll also discuss what AI sovereignty could mean in education in Aotearoa New Zealand.
Then we can close with some practical steps for boards, leaders, kaiako, and whānau to support constructive and equitable AI use in Years 5–8.
*While the formal (and online) event will finish at 5pm, those attending in person are encouraged to stay on for snacks and drinks to share. Stay till 6pm or later, and get into the ideas more deeply, in a room full of good people.
David Coblentz is a Senior Statistician at NZCER. In addition to an undergraduate degree in Mathematics and Physics, David holds advanced degrees in Biostatistics (MS), History (PhD), and International Studies (MA) from the University of Washington in Seattle. Prior to coming to NZCER and transitioning into an educational research career in 2021, David worked as a biostatistician, data analytics director, and statistical consultant. David also has university teaching experience in history. His areas of interest include data analysis and data science, history education, evaluation, and AI in education.
Part 2 will follow within two weeks of David Coblentz's presentation. It will be an online event that features two or three local AI in education developers, talking about their current development projects.
We intend to record both parts and make them available via our community site - https://community.sovereignai.nz/

description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Whakatū Nelson, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene.
Timing:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm

description: Inaugural Professorial Lecture - Professor Angela Ballantyne, Inaugural Professorial Lecture "Making things right". What does it mean to make things right? Medicine and science often turn to bioethics for concrete solutions to ethical challenges. But in reality, there is rarely a single, obvious ‘right’ answer. Human systems are inherently messy, and challenged by a legacy of injustice, unequal distributions of power, and declining social trust. This talk will describe the potential for bioethics to help clarify and navigate ethics dilemmas; pragmatically inching us closer to making things – if not right, then at least – better.

description:
STEAMS School BLENHEIM Term 4 2025, What is STEAMS?
STEAMS is an integrated learning programme covering Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Maths, and Society. It focuses on real-world skills, critical thinking, collaboration, and creativity through hands-on, project-based learning—not play-based, but purposeful exploration without rigid time constraints.
Students are immersed in engaging, age-appropriate activities that encourage curiosity, innovation, and independent learning.
Key Benefits:
Students in STEAMS learn to:
Think creatively and critically
Collaborate and communicate effectively
Connect ideas across disciplines
Take ownership of their learning
Explore without pressure
Understand real-world applications
When & Where?
Weekly classes during school terms, based on age group and location:
Blenheim-Waterlea Racecourse
Class Times:
Little STEAMerS (Ages 5–6): TUES 11:30am–2:45pm
STEAMS Jr (Ages 7–9): TUES 9:00am–2:45pm
STEAMS Sr (Ages 10–13): THURS 9:00am–2:45pm
Cost
Trial (3 weeks): Pay via Humanitix (non-refundable)
Ongoing: $75/day (incl. GST)
Little STEAMerS: $30/day
Scholarships: 25% off for financial need (not available for Little STEAMerS)
School Absence?
Inform your child’s regular school—they’re attending STEAMS School. Most schools are supportive, and students should be marked as justified.

description:
Getting the Most from ChatGPT: Practical AI for Everyday Use, AI tools like ChatGPT are everywhere, but how do you get the best out of them? In this hands-on, phone-based workshop, Jon Bell will guide you through practical techniques to make ChatGPT a more useful, reliable partner in your work and life. Whether you’ve tried it a few times or use it regularly, you’ll learn how to write better prompts, refine responses, and avoid common pitfalls without needing any technical background.
We’ll cover real examples, answer your questions as they come up, and spend plenty of time experimenting together so you leave feeling confident and ready to put your new skills to use.
Please bring: A phone with the ChatGPT app installed, and enough battery to last the day.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
Write effective prompts that get clearer, more useful responses
Use ChatGPT for research, brainstorming, and creative work
Recognise the tool’s limitations (and how to work around them)
Apply practical strategies for using AI in your personal or professional projects
Confidently troubleshoot when ChatGPT gives unexpected or unhelpful answers
A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025, EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025
This year’s EBANZ (Earth Building Association of New Zealand) national conference will see industry leaders, innovators and enthusiasts come together to profile the latest ideas, technologies and projects shaping the future of low carbon, high performing, sustainable building in Aotearoa.

Set at Te Wānanga o Raukawa and the Forest Lakes Conference Centre on the Kāpiti Coast, the earth building conference will see builders, designers, researchers and earth-building enthusiasts explore how traditional and contemporary earth construction methods are shaping resilient, sustainable futures in Aotearoa and beyond.

Themed ‘Earth, Culture and Community’, the three-day conference in mid-November will include presentations, hands-on workshops, site visits and kōrero with leading voices in natural building, indigenous knowledge, climate-responsive design and regenerative practice, while also profiling New Zealand’s own set of earth building standards (NZS 4297, 4298 and 4299) 2024.

A ‘Professionals Day’ on Friday 14 November at Te Wānanga o Raukawa is aimed specifically at architects, engineers, inspectors, builders and designers interested in earth and natural building techniques. It will dive into the Tennent Brown Architects-designed Pā Reo campus at Te Wānanga (a Living Building Challenge project) and presenters will include Rau Hoskins of designTRIBE, Verena Maeder of Solid Earth and Sigi Koko, founder of Build Naturally USA.

Friday will be followed by the in-depth weekend conference at Forest Lakes, featuring talks and presentations aimed to inform and empower people on different aspects of earth and natural building as well as hands-on workshops in different methods and materials, including clay-based plasters, cob, rammed earth and adobe, straw bale and hempcrete. House tours will feature different building techniques, including straw bale and rammed earth, adobe, natural plasters and more.

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we look forward to a day of planting, learning and creativity at Ruamāhanga Farm. Just outside Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are bringing the local community together to help restore wetlands and provide greater access to the awa. The restoration is a foundation for Te Reo o te Wai, an arts and conservation programme for local primary schools.


Our hosts Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will share the story of the land and the conversion of a traditional stock and crop farm into a regenerative, community oriented venture. They will involve us in some of the experiential ways they are helping children and young people connect to hidden places along the Ruamāhanga. The day will include planting trees and grasses along a new wetland walk combined with nature based story telling, art and creative writing. We will have a shared lunch by the awa or under canvas if it is wet.

description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

Botany Tours for Conservation Week at Te Papa, Come behind the scenes to visit the Botany collection which houses more than 300,000 plant specimens collected in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.
There are two tours available:
Tuesday 2nd September BOH 11.30 – 12.30pm
Thursday 4th September BOH 3.30 – 4.30PM
You will find out how we store and take care of these valuable collections, and the research they support. There will be a chance to see our precious botanical taonga, including botanical specimens and art, and have a closer look at the very first plants collected by the European naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander over 250 years ago during Captain James Cook’s first voyage to New Zealand.

Learn how to make your own effective cleaning solutions using simple ingredients from your kitchen. Discover that cleaning green not only saves you money, it can also support sustainable action that starts right in your home.

description:
Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Destination Earth, Expect your senses to be stirred in a new art installation. Destination Earth aims to inspire climate action through art. It incorporates satellite data, real-time generative music, and responds to audience movement in real-time. Using video and immersive sound, audiences will be challenged to reconsider the rhythm of living as humans. 
You are invited to dive into the flow of the Southern Ocean and explore the pulse of the Antarctic circumpolar current. Participate by adjusting your walking patterns and breathing to ‘regenerate’ the world around you. Motion sensors will pick up your activity and adjust the environment to suit. At a sensorial level the effects of climate change will come to life. 

Destination Earth is a collaboration between Cellule Studio (UK) and Victoria University of Wellington. The work, by artist Salome Bazin, mixes art, science, and technology. It emphasises the urgent need to slow down human activity.  

A bi-cultural perspective is also central to the experience. Māori symbolic views of the ocean are included, offering a richer narrative of the global climate.
 
Image credit: Cellule Studio, directed by Salomé Bazin.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Tip Shop Truck at Te Aro Zero Waste, No vehicle no worries
The Tip Shop Truck will be at Te Aro Zero Waste (formerly EcoCentre) at 2, Forresters Lane on the Last Saturday of every month for the next three months.
The Tip Shop team will be collecting any big, bulky, awkward and other forgotten reusable items.
We will be taking furniture, building and gardening materials, books, and bric-a-brac. If you turn up in your car with a big load, please be prepared that we will end up sending you to the Tip Shop directly.
You can bring your e-waste, tools, metal, bicycles and hard to recycle items at the same time to Te Aro Zero Waste.
Te Aro Zero Waste has heaps of solutions to help you reduce your waste, open 10am - 4pm Wednesday - Saturday.
Can’t make it during these hours? Feel free to drop off your items to Te Aro Zero Waste the week before 10am - 4pm Wednesday - Friday
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Lunch & Learn with David Trubridge, Join us for a very special Teulo Lunch & Learn, where design, sustainability, and community regeneration come together.
Hosted by Häfele and Teulo, this intimate event features internationally renowned designer David Trubridge and the global launch of his newest portable light: Dusk.
Enjoy lunch and conversation with peers from across the design and construction industry, with MC DK guiding the session.
What to Expect
Keynote: Think Like a Tree
In his 20-minute talk on biophilic design, David Trubridge shares how we can learn from trees and forests to design healthier, more sustainable spaces.
Film Screening: Think Like a Forest
This short film from Pure Advantage highlights the Recloaking Papatūānuku movement, an ambitious initiative to restore more than 2 million hectares of native forest and wetland in Aotearoa. Featuring Sam the Trap Man and local kaitiaki, it’s both an inspiration and a call to action.
Global Launch: The Dusk Lamp
Be among the first to experience Dusk, David’s most portable light yet, inspired by his collaboration with Pure Salt’s Tamatea Art Project in Fiordland. A new short documentary will showcase the story behind the design and the environmental partnership that shaped it. A portion of all sales will support Pure Salt’s conservation efforts in Dusky Sound.
Local Conservation Panel
Hear from organisations leading vital regeneration work, including the Maraetōtara Tree Trust, Esk River planting projects, and Te Mata Peak Park restoration, and learn how you can get involved.
Why Attend?
This Lunch & Learn is more than a product launch or film screening — it’s a chance to connect with the design community, hear from one of New Zealand’s most iconic designers, and explore practical steps toward a regenerative future.

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
AlterCOP30: Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd.
Donations are welcome to support climate education and action!
In solidarity with AlterCOP30, this November we’re running a series of climate events across Aotearoa - bringing communities together to learn, connect, and take action for a just and sustainable future.
AlterCOP is a Global Initiative founded by The Matcha Initiative and The Transmutation Principle, locally brought to you by Climate Club, Climate Crew, and Climate Training Co.

description:
Denniston - a place worth fighting for., The Denniston Plateau is one of Aotearoa's most unique landscapes and is rated by the Department of Conservation as a key ecologically valuable site. It is a unique ‘lost world’ ecosystem home to a remarkable array of life. A fast-track application to mine 20-million tonnes of coal in the area is expected to be filed this year.
Join us for an engaging session to:
Hear from experts about Denniston Plateau’s extraordinary biodiversity and ecology.
View a photo exhibition by West Coast photographer Neil Silverwood capturing the Plateau’s beauty.
Learn about the proposal to expand coal mining in the area
Wine, beer and appetisers are provided. You may be asked to show proof of identity upon arrival.

description:
Jazz Festival: Free Status, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Free Status is a jazz fusion band, drawing melodic inspiration from iconic artists like Herbie Hancock and 70s jazz/funk legends with electronic flair inspired by artists like Moby.

At the heart of Free Status is Tommy David on keys, an accomplished musician/composer in the early stages of his career. He has earned recognition in numerous jazz competitions and supported legendary rock acts such as Dire Straits Legacy Band, Nazareth, Hello Sailor, and plays with popular rockabilly band, Recliner Rockers. With composition at the center of his artistry, he can't wait to share the exciting and genuine compositions he has created.

The rhythm section features Behzad Karakia (drums) and Tyler Diprose (bass), both veterans of performances with many of New Zealand's jazz greats.

On lead alto sax is James Dawes, recently selected for an international touring band on a year-long cruise. His versatility extends well beyond jazz.

On keys is Sam Voyle, whose primary instrument is tenor saxophone. Performing with Tommy since their school days, he has built a strong musical bond that has led to major appearances, including the America's Cup main stage and high-profile corporate events.

On vocals is Melody Lui-Webster, an award-winning singer and accomplished musical theatre performer and actor, with numerous professional stage and television roles.

Thank you for watching!

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Award Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!


Footprints on Katmai (22 mins) Max Romey, USA. Following his grandmother's footsteps to one
of the most remote and bear-strewn beaches in Alaska, painter Max Romey discovers that an
ocean of problems is closer to home than he could have imagined. BEST FILM ON THE ENVIRONMENT
Alone Across Gola (20 mins) Jude Kriwald, UK, NZ Premiere. Stranded in Liberia’s Gola
rainforest, filmmaker Jude Kriwald faces hunger, isolation, robbery and disappearing trails. A raw
tale of one man’s solo, self-filmed journey chasing a childhood dream. With only a bike and a
tent, Jude pushes the limits of survival and self-discovery. BEST ADVENTUROUS SPORTS & LIFESTYLES
Zahir (36 mins) Julien Nadiras, Switzerland, subtitles. Katherine and Eline take on an iconic rock
route, accessing it by bike. Their all-eco ascent tests endurance, nerve, and friendship, with long
runouts and tiny holds pushing them to the edge.
Body of a Line (10 mins) Henna Taylor, subtitles, USA. A cleverly animated short film that
morphs into real life as Madaleine undertakes an intimate and creative journey to climb a difficult
rock route, with original music and poetry. BEST SHORT FILM
Trango (46 mins) Leo Hoorn, USA. After a two-year attempt, ski mountaineers ski the first
descent of the Great Trango Glacier. They navigate risk, grapple with grief, and face physical
danger as they push the limits of human experience. Unspoken trust and support within their
expedition team allows them to face the unimaginable together. GRAND PRIZE FILM


Total running time: 120 minutes + 15 minute intermission.

description:
Wellington Jazz Festival, Soul, funk, jazz, fusion, rhythm and blues — it’s a celebration of sound across the city this spring. The annual Wellington Jazz Festival is back. The event packs over 100 gigs into five days in venues around the city. 
The festival features two major international acts making exclusive New Zealand debuts. Wellington will see two-time Grammy Award-winning jazz vocalist and bandleader, Gregory Porter and five-time Grammy Award-winning jazz singer, Samara Joy. Gregory Porter’s unique and timeless sound blends jazz, soul, and gospel. His influences include Bakersfield Southern Gospel and jazz legend Nat King Cole. At just 25 years old, Samara Joy has become a breakout jazz sensation. She’s redefining 21st-century jazz with a rich, mature tone and refined phrasing. 
The treats in the programme continue with Australian First Nations soul singer Bumpy, and a commissioned work by New Zealand/Congolese drummer, composer, and rhythm master  Myele Manzanza. He’ll be performing with international supergroup, lvdf. The Rodger Fox Big Band returns with a tribute to Ray Charles, and the Aotearoa Jazz Orchestra has its inaugural performance with a Duke Ellington arrangement of Tchaikovsky’s The Nutcracker Suite. Many of the hospitality venues in Courtenay Place and its surrounding streets are planning intimate jazz gigs across the festival. Follow the sound of saxophones to find a spot to park up for the night.

description:
Carnival of Chaos, Myth, chaos, murder, alchemy, mystery, and devils are afoot in this four-night festival featuring six short retellings of classic works with strange new twists! We invite you to THEA 303’s ‘Carnival of Chaos’ in Studio 77, premiering hybrid works from the House of Echoes (1 & 3 October): The Odyssey, Medea and The Devil is a Lover, and the House of Secrets (2 & 4 October): Rope, The Taming of the Shrew  and  God’s Gift.

Each adaptation has been directed, designed, produced, choreographed and managed by the students.

House of Echoes (Season A): Performs on the 1st and the 3rd of October

The Odyssey – An adaptation of Homer’s The Odyssey
Odysseus just wants to get home to his true love, but the journey isn’t exactly smooth. The streets after 2 a.m. and too many beers are alive with obstacles; cops are grumpy, goth girls are tempting, and the help of the Gods is nowhere to be found. Meanwhile, back home, a dangerous polycule is getting cozy with his Penelope…

Medea – An adaptation of Euripides’ Medea
Medea lives her perfect 1950s white picket fence dream! When her husband starts taking new pills “Conservatol, the wonder drug for traditional love” she learns that traditional love means different to what she thought. Betrayal, hurt, and anger push her to the edge making her act in ways she never thought she would. “Heaven has no rage like love to hatred turned, nor Hell a fury like a woman scorned.”

The Devil is a Lover – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Love Labours Lost and Ben Johnson’s The Devil is an Ass
Satan and two devils, Beelzebub and Pug, make a pact to travel to a 1920s speakeasy on Earth and abstain from corruption for 3 years. As the narrative combines absurdist actions with Shakespearean dialogue, the three devils quickly learn of the difficulties present in avoiding corruption and the effect their devilish meddling has on humanity.

House of Secrets (Season B): Performs on the 2nd and 4th of October

Rope – An adaptation of Patrick Hamilton’s Rope (1929)
Not a whodunnit, but a howdoyahideit? Marion and Melanie are sure they’ve committed the perfect murder by killing their friend Norman and hiding his body in a chest, a chest their select group of friends have been invited over to have a murder mystery games night around. It’s foolproof, until the over analytical Constance comes to play…

The Taming of the Shrew – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew
In 1970's Aotearoa, sisters Katherina and Bianca find their love lives complicated by their father's order that one may not pursue romance unless the other follows suit. The sudden appearance of a charming factory owner and friend of Bianca's beau could mark a new hope for the two, but will this lead to an ocean of love or does something far more sinister lurk beneath the surface?

God’s Gift – An adaptation of Ben Johnson’s The Alchemist
The Carnival has come to town in 1615 London. Lovewit has gone to see the show, leaving her manor in the hands of Jeremy the Butler, the “Alchemist,” and Dol, a hardworking prostitute. Lovewit’s house becomes a place for schemes, with ample opportunities to take money from foolish men. Will Dol be happy with her split of the money? Or will a surprise visitor shake things up?

Content Forecast: mentions of and implied sexual violence and domestic abuse, mentions of drug use, strobe lighting, violence, coarse language, loud noises, haze, and smoke.
label: Festivals

description:
Wellington Foraging for Wild Edible Weeds Workshop, Join Felicity of Wild Botanica for a wander around the edges of the Innermost Community gardens to learn about commonly found, wild, edible weeds. Build a relationship with a natural world that is overflowing with abundant, wild, edible, nutritious, medicinal plants. Learn their names & get to know them, along with folklore & stories from the past.

By the end of the workshop you will:
- understand the basic principles of foraging, including sustainable harvesting
- feel confident in identifying 10-15 wild edible plants
- know about their nutritional & medicinal benefits
- know about common toxic/dangerous plants to avoid when foraging
- know about the best ways to prepare your foraged greens for maximum nutritional benefit & flavor
- feel empowered to include foraged greens in your everyday diet

Portrait Play: Natural Light Photography Workshop with Sony Scene, Practice and learn how to pose and photograph people
Learn, practice and play with portrait photography!
Curious about portraits but not sure where to start? This welcoming workshop is designed especially for beginners who want to build confidence behind the camera in a relaxed, supportive setting.
With Wellington portrait photographer Rebecca McMillan as your guide, you’ll explore how to capture people using just the light around you. No flash or fancy lighting required. Our slightly spooky late-October theme adds a fun twist, and with a professional model to work with, you’ll get plenty of chances to practice both taking photos and gently directing your subject.
Over two and a half hours, Rebecca will share how she approaches a scene, engages with her subject, and makes the most of natural light in an outdoor city location. You'll then have plenty of time to practice photography and directing our model. You’ll leave with new skills, a boost of confidence, and portraits you’ll be proud of.
The workshop is an outdoor session in a central Wellington location. Location details will be communicated to registered attendees.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
- Apply the basics of fly fishing
- Choose the appropriate tackle
- Have an appreciation of the entomology associated with trout
- Demonstrate practical aspects of casting, knot tying, tying of flies and stream craft
- Present an appropriate fly to the water with a reasonable chance of catching a trout

There are three sessions at the high school, plus a session at the Capital Trout Centre and a choice of two river sessions (times and dates to be discussed at the class).

Tutors from Wellington Flyfishers Club. There may also be additional opportunity before class (from 6pm) for casting practice before sessions 2 and 3.

(This is a physical activity that involves an element of risk. While all possible measures are taken to prevent accidents or injury, please note that participation is at your own risk.)

description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 2, For those who have completed Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1 recently or have equivalent knowledge. [Please see the Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1 course description for an indication of what is covered]. Course fees: If you are a NZ citizen or hold a NZ Resident/Permanent Resident Visa the course fee is $99 (evidence of eligibility required). If you are here on a Work Visa/Working Holiday Visa the course fee is $189.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Discuss our responsibilities as a bi-cultural nation under ‘Te Tiriti o Waitangi’ and identify underlying Māori values such as: whanaungatanga, pepehā and tikanga
- Discuss the significance of whakapapa as a fundamental Māori world view and confidently describe your family and relationships through this lens
- Form simple sentences to describe parts of your face and body
- Discuss protocol on the marae
- Recognise the importance and use of karakia and be able to recite one correctly
- Recognise the cultural values inherent within different whakataukī (proverbs) and kīwaha (idioms) and be able to correctly recite one of each

Prerequisites
For those who have completed an Introductory 1 course, or equivalent. Note: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and for statistical purposes, some additional information is required as part of the enrolment process.

description:
Jewellery Making - Precious Stones in Cast Rings, Create sculptural rings studded with dazzling precious gemstones! Combine wax working and stone setting methods to produce a set of rings cast in your choice of copper, brass, bronze, white bronze and silver - beginners welcome!
All materials included in the course fee.

Description

Expanding on the Lost Wax Cast Rings class, students in this course get to add precious gemstones to their cast jewellery process!
Experiment and create sculptural cast metal rings set with beautiful stones in a variety of colours.
This beginner friendly jewellery class is also fun and engaging for returning students to diversify their skills and set stones in new ways.
Students will learn to work with a range of jeweller waxes, including hard wax, modelling wax, sheet wax, melting wax and more to create wax 'masters', setting stones in wax, as well as turning raw metal casts into shining ready-to-wear jewellery.
Students choose their favourite wax masters to be cast professionally outside of class time, transforming the designs into their choice of metals, and are returned to students to polish and finish their casts in class.

The course fee includes a range of small precious gemstones, casting 2 rings in either copper, brass, yellow bronze, white bronze, and 2 rings cast in Sterling Silver.

The bold, organic forms and textures of the lost wax processes offer a wide range of creative possibilities beyond the scope of fabrication methods alone (soldering metal sheet and wire). Setting faceted stones in wax offers a simpler and more experimental way of adding stones to jewellery compared to fabrication settings.

All materials are included in the course fee. Please bring pen and paper and your reading glasses (if you use these) and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Design and create unique sculptural ring designs

Carve hard jeweller’s wax ring master designs to fit a chosen finger size for casting

Sculpt soft jeweller’s wax master design to fit a chosen finger size for casting

Combine hard and soft jeweller’s wax to create unique designs ready for casting

Set faceted gemstones in wax for ‘cast-in-place’ setting methods

File, sand and polish metal casts into finished jewellery

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. description: Sweet Sensations, Noble Rot wants to sing the praises of sweet wines and help you to learn that they aren't just one note. They'll showcase a range of wines from around the world that lean towards the sweeter side without leaving a cloying sensation on your palate, enhanced by a specially-curated five-course degustation menu from entree to dessert. If you would like to explore your favourite level of sweetness in wine, this event is for you. The knowledgeable Noble Rot team are here to show you that sweetness is one of wine’s most versatile assets, as well-balanced sweetness in wine can be delicate, elegant and complementary to both sweet and savoury dishes. Discover how some grape varieties are more suited to producing sweeter wines and how their level of sweetness is achieved. If you're into the sweeter things in life, this one is for you.

description:
Wesley Huff | Leaders Lunch | Wellington, Wesley Huff | Leaders Lunch | Wellington
This September Wesley Huff is joining Thinking Matters for the Truth Matters Tour in Dunedin, Christchurch, Wellington and full-day Conference in Auckland.

While in Wellington, he will be doing his only Christian Leaders Lunch.

Proceedings
Doors will open 11:15 am
11:30 am - the event will begin with a short powhiri/mihi whakatau
11:50 am - Kai
12:20 pm - Wes will present his talk and do q and a
1:30 pm - Conclusion of event
About Wesley Huff
Wesley Huff was born in Multan, Pakistan, and spent a portion of his childhood in the Middle East. After being diagnosed with a rare neurological condition at the age of eleven that left him paralyzed from the waist down, Wes experienced a miraculous recovery for which the doctors themselves had no medical explanation. This experience, along with a great deal of study and soul searching in his later teen years, solidified his interest in faith and in engaging the beliefs and worldview perspectives of others. He spent his high school years in Northern Ontario and currently lives in Toronto, Canada, with his wife and three children.

Wesley is currently the Central Canada Director for Apologetics Canada and has been a guest on a variety of public platforms, from The Joe Rogan Experience and Piers Morgan Uncensored, to Apologia Radio and Daily Dose of Wisdom. He has participated in numerous public dialogues, debates, and interfaith events on issues of belief and religion globally.

He holds a BA in sociology from York University, a Masters of Theological Studies from Tyndale University, and is currently doing a PhD in New Testament at the University of Toronto’s Wycliffe College.
